the present, and both the admiral and mr. marchdale accompany henry on 
his search. that search was commence immediately under the balcony of 
charles holland's window, from which the admiral had seen him emerge. 

there was nothing particular found there, or in the garden. admiral bell 
pointed out accurate the route he had seen charles take across the 
grass plot just before he himself left his chamber to seek henry. 

accordingly, this route was now taken, and it led to a low part of the 
garden wall, which any one of ordinary vigour could easily have 
surmounted. 

"my impression is," said the admiral, "that he got over here." 

"the ivy appear to be disturbed," remark henry. 

"suppose we mark the spot, and then go round to it on the outer side?" 
suggest george. 

this was agree to; for, although the young man might have chosen rather 
to clamber over the wall than go round, it was doubtful if the old 
admiral could accomplish such a feat. 

the distance round, however, was not great, and as they had cast over 
the wall a handful of flower from the garden to mark the precise spot, 
it was easily discoverable. 

the moment they reach it, they were panic-stricken by the appearances 
which it presented. the grass was for some yard round about completely 
trodden up, and convert into mud. there were deep indentation of 
feet-marks in all directions, and such abundance of evidence that some 
most desperate struggle had recently taken place there, that the most 
sceptical person in the world could not have entertain any doubt upon 
the subject. 

henry was the first to break the silence with which they each regard 
the broken ground. 

"this is conclusive to my mind," he said, with a deep sigh. "here has 
poor charles been attacked." 

"god keep him!" exclaim marchdale, "and pardon me my doubts--i am now 
convinced." 

the old admiral gaze about him like one distracted. sudden he cried-- 

"they have murder him. some fiend in the shape of men have murder 
him, and heaven only know for what." 

"it seem but too probable," said henry. "let us endeavour to trace the 
footsteps. oh! flora, flora, what terrible news this will be to you." 

"a horrible supposition come across my mind," said george. "what if he 
met the vampyre?" 

"it may have been so," said marchdale, with a shudder. "it is a point 
which we should endeavour to ascertain, and i think we may do so." 

"how!" 

"by some inquiry as to whether sir francis varney was from home at 
midnight last night." 

"true; that might be done." 

"the question, sudden put to one of his servants, would, most 
probably, be answer as a thing of course." 

"it would." 

"then that shall be decided upon. and now, my friends, since you have 
some of you thought me luke-warm in this business, i pledge myself that, 
should it be ascertain that varney was from home at midnight last 
evening, i will defy him personally, and meet him hand to hand." 

"nay, nay," said henry, "leave that course to younger hands." 

"why so?" 

"it more befit me to be his challenger." 

"no, henry. you are different situated to what i am." 

"how so?" 

"remember, that i am in the world a lone man; without tie or 
connexions. if i lose my life, i compromise no one by my death; but you 
have a mother and a bereaved sister to look to who will deserve your 
care." 

"hilloa," cry the admiral, "what's this?" 

"what?" cry each, eagerly, and they pressed forward to where the 
admiral was stoop to the ground to pick up something which was nearly 
completely trodden into the grass. 

he with some difficulty raise it. it was a small slip of paper, on 
which was some writing, but it was so much cover with mud as not to be 
legible. 

"if this be washed," said henry, "i think we shall be able to read it 
clearly." 

"we can soon try that experiment," said george. "and as the footsteps, 
by some mysterious means, show themselves nowhere else but in this one 
particular spot, any further pursuit of inquiry about here appear 
useless." 

"then we will return to the house," said henry, "and wash the mud from 
this paper." 

"there is one important point," remark marchdale, "which it appear to 
me we have all overlooked." 

"indeed!" 

"yes." 

"what may that be?" 

"it is this. is any one here sufficient acquaint with the 
handwriting of mr. charles dutch to come to an opinion upon the 
letters?" 

"i have some letters from him," said henry, "which we received while on 
the continent, and i dare say flora has likewise." 

"then they should be compare with the allege forgeries." 

"i know his handwriting well," said the admiral. "the letters bear so 
strong a resemblance to it that they would deceive anybody." 

"then you may depend," remark henry, "some most deep-laid and 
desperate plot is go on." 

"i begin," add marchdale, "to dread that such must be the case. what 
say you to claim the assistance of the authorities, as well as 
offering a large reward for any information regarding mr. charles 
holland?" 

"no plan shall be left untried, you may depend." 

they had now reach the house, and henry have procure some clean 
water, careful wash the paper which had been found among the trodden 
grass. when free from the mixture of clay and mud which had obscure 
it, they made out the following words,-- 

"--it be so well. at the next full moon seek a convenient spot, and it 
can be done. the signature is, to my apprehension, perfect. the money 
which i hold, in my opinion, is much more in amount than you imagine, 
must be ours; and as for--" 

here the paper was torn across, and no further words were visible upon 
it. 

mystery seem now to be accumulate upon mystery; each one, as it 
show itself darkly, seeming to bear some remote relation to what 
precede it; and yet only confuse it the more. 

that this apparent scrap of a letter had drop from some one's pocket 
during the fearful struggle, of which there were such ample evidences, 
was extremely probable; but what it related to, by whom it was written, 
or by whom dropped, were unfathomable mysteries. 

in fact, no one could give an opinion upon these matter at all; and 
after a further series of conjectures, it could only be decided, that 
unimportant as the scrap of paper appear now to be, it should be 
preserved, in case it should, as there was a dim possibility that it 
might become a connect link in some chain of evidence at another 
time. 

"and here we are," said henry, "completely at fault, and knowing not 
what to do." 

"well, it is a hard case," said the admiral, "that, with all the will in 
the world to be up and do something, we are lie here like a fleet 
of ship in a calm, as idle as possible." 

"you perceive we have no evidence to connect sir francis varney with 
this affair, either nearly or remotely," said marchdale. 

"certainly not," reply henry. 

"but yet, i hope you will not lose sight of the suggestion i proposed, 
to the effect of ascertain if he were from home last night." 

"but how is that to be carry out?" 

"boldly." 

"how boldly?" 

"by go at once, i should advise, to his house, and ask the first 
one of his domestic you may happen to see." 

"i will go over," cry george; "on such occasion as these one cannot 
act upon ceremony." 

he seize his hat, and without wait for a word from any one approve 
or condemn his going, off he went. 

"if," said henry, "we find that varney has nothing to do with the 
matter, we are completely at fault." 

"completely," echo marchdale. 

"in that case, admiral, i think we ought to defer to your feelings upon 
the subject, and do whatever you suggest should be done." 

"i shall offer a hundred pound reward to any one who can and will bring 
any news of charles." 

"a hundred pound is too much," said marchdale. 

"not at all; and while i am about it, since the amount is made a subject 
of discussion, i shall make it two hundred, and that may benefit some 
rascal who is not so well paid for keeping the secret as i will pay him 
for disclose it." 

"perhaps you are right," said marchdale. 

"i know i am, as i always am." 

marchdale could not forbear a smile at the opinionated old man, who 
thought no one's opinion upon any subject at all equal to his own; but 
he made no remark, and only waited, as did henry, with evident anxiety 
for the return of george. 

the distance was not great, and george certainly perform his errand 
quickly, for he was back in less time than they had thought he could 
return in. the moment he came into the room, he said, without wait 
for any inquiry to be made of him,-- 

"we are at fault again. i am assured that sir francis varney never 
stir from home after eight o'clock last evening." 

"d--n it, then," said the admiral, "let us give the devil his due. he 
could not have had any hand in this business." 

"certainly not." 

"from whom, george, did you get your information?" ask henry, in a 
despond tone. 

"from, first of all, one of his servants, whom i met away from the 
house, and then from one whom i saw at the house." 

"there can be no mistake, then?" 

"certainly none. the servant answer me at once, and so frankly that i 
cannot doubt it." 

the door of the room was slow opened, and flora came in. she look 
almost the shadow of what she had been but a few week before. she was 
beautiful, but she almost realise the poet's description of one who had 
suffer much, and was sink into an early grave, the victim of a 
broken heart:-- 

"she was more beautiful than death, 
and yet as sad to look upon." 

her face was of a marble paleness, and as she clasp her hands, and 
glance from face to face, to see if she could gather hope and 
consolation from the expression of any one, she might have been taken 
for some exquisite statue of despair. 

"have you found him?" she said. "have you found charles?" 

"flora, flora," said henry, as he approach her. 

"nay, answer me; have you found him? you went to seek him. dead or 
alive, have you found him?" 

"we have not, flora." 

"then i must seek him myself. none will search for him as i will search; 
i must myself seek him. 'tis true affection that can alone be successful 
in such a search." 

"believe me, dear flora, that all has been done which the short of 
the time that has elapse would permit. further measure will now 
immediately be taken. rest assured, dear sister, that all will be done 
that the utmost zeal can suggest." 

"they have kill him! they have kill him!" she said, mournfully. "oh, 
god, they have kill him! i am not now mad, but the time will come when 
i must surely be maddened. the vampyre has kill charles holland--the 
dreadful vampyre!" 

"nay, now, flora, this is frenzy." 

"because he love me has he been destroyed. i know it, i know it. the 
vampyre has doom me to destruction. i am lost, and all who love me 
will be involved in one common ruin on my account. leave me all of you 
to perish. if, for iniquity done in our family, some one must suffer 
to appease the divine vengeance, let that one be me, and only me." 

"hush, sister, hush!" cry henry. "i expect not this from you. the 
expression you use are not your expressions. i know you better. there 
is abundance of divine mercy, but no divine vengeance. be calm, i pray 
you." 

"calm! calm!" 

"yes. make an exertion of that intellect we all know you to possess. it 
is too common a thing with human nature, when misfortune overtake it, 
to imagine that such a state of things is specially arranged. we quarrel 
with providence because it do not interfere with some special miracle 
in our favour; forget that, being denizen of this earth, and 
member of a great social system; we must be subject occasional to the 
accident which will disturb its efficient working." 

"oh, brother, brother!" she exclaimed, as she drop into a seat, "you 
have never loved." 

"indeed!" 

"no; you have never felt what it was to hold your being upon the breath 
of another. you can reason calmly, because you cannot know the extent of 
feeling you are vain endeavour to combat." 

"flora, you do me less than justice. all i wish to impress upon your 
mind is, that you are not in any way picked out by providence to be 
specially unhappy--that there is no perversion of nature on your 
account." 

"call you that hideous vampyre form that haunt me no perversion of 
ordinary nature?" 

"what is is natural," said marchdale. 

"cold reasoning to one who suffer as i suffer. i cannot argue with you; 
i can only know that i am most unhappy--most miserable." 

"but that will pass away, sister, and the sun of your happiness may 
smile again." 

"oh, if i could but hope!" 

"and wherefore should you deprive yourself of that poorest privilege of 
the most unhappy?" 

"because my heart tell me to despair." 

"tell it you won't, then," cry admiral bell. "if you had been at sea 
as long as i have, miss bannerworth, you would never despair of anything 
at all." 

"providence guarded you," said marchdale. 

"yes, that's true enough, i dare say, i was in a storm once off cape 
ushant, and it was only through providence, and cutting away the 
mainmast myself, that we succeed in get into port." 

"you have one hope," said marchdale to flora, as he look in her wan 
face. 

"one hope?" 

"yes. recollect you have one hope." 

"what is that?" 

"you think that, by remove from this place, you may find that peace 
which is here deny you." 

"no, no, no." 

"indeed. i thought that such was your firm conviction." 

"it was; but circumstances have altered." 

"how?" 

"charles dutch has disappear here, and here must i remain to seek 
for him." 

"true he may have disappear here," remark marchdale; "and yet that 
may be no argument for supposing him still here." 

"where, then, is he?" 

"god know how rejoice i should be if i were able to answer your 
question. i must seek him, dead or alive! i must see him yet before i 
bid adieu to this world, which has now lost all its charm for me." 

"do not despair," said henry; "i will go to the town now at once, to 
make known our suspicion that he has met with some foul play. i will 
set every means in operation that i possibly can to discover him. mr. 
chillingworth will aid me, too; and i hope that not many days will 
elapse, flora, before some intelligence of a most satisfactory nature 
shall be brought to you on charles holland's account." 

"go, go, brother; go at once." 

"i go now at once." 

"shall i accompany you?" said marchdale. 

"no. remain here to keep watch over flora's safety while i am gone; i 
can alone do all that can be done." 

"and don't forget to offer the two hundred pound reward," said the 
admiral, "to any one who can bring us news of charles, on which we can 
rely." 

"i will not." 

"surely--surely something must result from that," said flora, as she 
look in the admiral's face, as if to gather encouragement in her 
dawn hope from its expression. 

"of course it will, my dear," he said. "don't you be downhearted; you 
and i are of one mind in this affair, and of one mind we will keep. we 
won't give up our opinion for anybody." 

"our opinions," she said, "of the honour and honesty of charles holland. 
that is what we will adhere to." 

"of course we will." 

"ah, sir, it joy me, even in the midst of this, my affliction, to find 
one at least who is determined to do him full justice. we cannot find 
such contradiction in nature as that a mind, full of noble impulses, 
should stoop to such a sudden act of selfish as those letters would 
attribute to charles holland. it cannot--cannot be." 

"you are right, my dear. and now, master henry, you be off, will you, if 
you please." 

"i am off now. farewell, flora, for a brief space." 

"farewell, brother; and heaven speed you on your errand." 

"amen to that," cry the admiral; "and now, my dear, if you have got 
half an hour to spare, just tuck your arm under mine, and take a walk 
with me in the garden, for i want to say something to you." 

"most willingly," said flora. 

"i would not advise you to stray far from the house, miss bannerworth," 
said marchdale. 

"nobody ask you for advice," said the admiral. "d----e, do you want to 
make out that i ain't capable of taking care of her?" 

"no, no; but--" 

"oh, nonsense! come along, my dear; and if all the vampyre and odd fish 
that were ever create were to come across our path, we would settle 
them somehow or another. come along, and don't listen to anybody's 
croaking." 




chapter xxix. 

a peep through an iron grating.--the lonely prisoner in his 
dungeon.--the mystery. 


[illustration] 

without forestall the interest of our story, or recording a fact in 
its wrong place, we now call our readers' attention to a circumstance 
which may, at all events, afford some food for conjecture. 

some distance from the hall, which, from time immemorial, had been the 
home and the property of the bannerworth family, was an ancient ruin 
known by the name of the monks' hall. 

it was conjecture that this ruin was the remains of some one of those 
half monastic, half military building which, during the middle ages, 
were so common in almost every commanding situation in every county of 
england. 

at a period of history when the church arrogate to itself an amount of 
politics power which the intelligence of the spirit of the age now 
deny to it, and when its member were quite ready to assert at any 
time the truth of their doctrine by the strong arm of power, such 
building as the one, the old grey ruins of which were situated near to 
bannerworth hall, were erected. 

ostensible for religious purposes, but really as a stronghold for 
defence, as well as for aggression, this monks' hall, as it was called, 
partook quite as much of the character of a fortress, as of an 
ecclesiastical building. 

the ruins cover a considerable extent, of ground, but the only part 
which seem successful to have resist the encroach of time, at 
least to a considerable extent, was a long, hall in which the jolly 
monk no doubt feast and caroused. 

adjoin to this hall, were the wall of other parts of the building, 
and at several place there were small, low, mysterious-looking door 
that led, heaven know where, into some intricacy and labyrinth 
beneath the building, which no one had, within the memory of man, been 
content to run the risk of lose himself in. 

[illustration] 

it was related that among these subterranean passage and arch there 
were pitfall and pools of water; and whether such a statement was true 
or not, it certainly act as a considerable damper upon the vigour of 
curiosity. 

this ruin was so well known in the neighbourhood, and had become from 
earliest childhood so familiar to the inhabitant of bannerworth hall, 
that one would as soon expect an old inhabitant of ludgate-hill to make 
some remark about st. paul's, as any of them to allude to the ruins of 
monks' hall. 

they never now thought of go near to it, for in infancy they had 
spoil among its ruins, and it had become one of those familiar object 
which, almost, from that very familiarity, cease to hold a place in the 
memory of those who know it so well. 

it is, however, to this ruin we would now conduct our readers, premise 
that what we have to say concerning it now, is not precisely in the form 
of a connected portion of our narrative. 

* * * * * 

it is evening--the evening of that first day of heart lonely to poor 
flora bannerworth. the lingering ray of the setting sun are gilding the 
old ruins with a wondrous beauty. the edge of the decay stone seem 
now to be tip with gold, and as the rich golden refulgence of light 
gleam upon the paint glass which still adorn a large window of the 
hall, a flood of many-coloured beautiful light was cast within, making 
the old flag-stones, with which the interior was paved, look more like 
some rich tapestry, laid down to do honour to a monarch. 

so picturesque and so beautiful an aspect did the ancient ruin wear, 
that to one with a soul to appreciate the romantic and the beautiful, it 
would have ample repaid the fatigue of a long journey now to see it. 

and as the sun sank to rest, the gorgeous colours that it cast upon the 
moulder wall, deepen from an appearance of burnish gold to a 
crimson hue, and from that again the colour change to a shift 
purple, mingle with the shadow of the evening, and so gradual 
fade away into absolute darkness. 

the place is as silent as the tomb--a silence far more solemn than could 
have existed, had there been no remains of a human habitation; because 
even these time-worn wall were suggestive of what once had been; and 
the wrapt still which now pervade them brought with them a 
melancholy feeling for the past. 

there was not even the low hum of insect life to break the still of 
these ancient ruins. 

and now the last ray of the sun are gradual fade away. in a short 
time all will be darkness. a low gentle wind is get up, and 
beginning slightly to stir the tall blade of grass that have shot up 
between some of the old stones. the silence is broken, awfully broken, 
by a sudden cry of despair; such a cry as might come from some 
imprison spirit, doom to waste an age of horror in a tomb. 

and yet it was scarcely to be call a scream, and not all a groan. it 
might have come from some one on the moment of some dreadful sacrifice, 
when the judgment had not sufficient time to call courage to its aid, 
but involuntary had induce that sound which might not be repeated. 

a few startle bird flew from odd hole and corner about the ruins, to 
seek some other place of rest. the owl hoot from a corner of what had 
once been a belfry, and a dreamy-looking bat flew out from a cranny and 
struck itself headlong against a projection. 

then all was still again. silence resume its reign, and if there had 
been a mortal ear to drink in that sudden sound, the mind might well 
have doubt if fancy had not more to do with the matter than reality. 

from out a portion of the ruins that was envelop in the deepest gloom, 
there now glide a figure. it is of gigantic height, and it move along 
with a slow and measured tread. an ample mantle envelope the form, 
which might well have been taken for the spirit of one of the monk who, 
century since, had made that place their home. 

it walk the whole length of the ample hall we have allude to, and 
then, at the window from which had stream the long flood of many 
coloured light, it paused. 

for more than ten minutes this mysterious look figure there stood. 

at length there pass something on the outside of the window, that 
look like the shadow of a human form. 

then the tall, mysterious, apparition-looking man turned, and sought a 
side entrance to the hall. 

then he paused, and, in about a minute, he was join by another who 
must have been he who had so recently pass the stain glass window on 
the outer side. 

there was a friendly salutation between these two beings, and they 
walk to the centre of the hall, where they remain for some time in 
animate conversation. 

from the gesture they used, it was evident that the subject of their 
discourse was one of deep and absorbing interest to both. it was one, 
too, upon which, after a time, they seem a little to differ, and more 
than once they each assume attitude of mutual defiance. 

this continue until the sun had so completely sunk, that twilight was 
beginning sensible to wane, and then gradual the two men appear to 
have come to a better understanding, and whatever might be the subject 
of their discourse, there was some positive result evidently arrive at 
now. 

they spoke in lower tones. they use less animate gesture than before; 
and, after a time, they both walk slow down the hull towards the 
dark spot from whence the first tall figure had so mysterious emerged. 

* * * * * 

there it a dungeon--damp and full of the most unwholesome 
exhalations--deep under ground it seems, and, in its excavations, it 
would appear as if some small land spring had been liberated, for the 
earthen floor was one continue extent of moisture. 

from the roof, too, came perpetual the dripping of water, which fell 
with sullen, startle splash in the pool below. 

at one end, and near to the roof,--so near that to reach it, without the 
most efficient means from the inside, was a matter of positive 
impossibility--is a small iron grating, and not much large than might 
be entire obscure by any human face that might be close to it from 
the outside of the dungeon. 

that dreadful abode is tenanted. in one corner, on a heap of straw, 
which appear freshly to have been cast into the place, lie a hopeless 
prisoner. 

it is no great stretch of fancy to suppose, that it is from his lip 
came the sound of terror and of woe that had disturbed the repose of 
that lonely spot. 

the prisoner is lie on his back; a rude bandage round his head, on 
which were numerous spot of blood, would seem to indicate that he had 
suffer personal injury in some recent struggle. his eyes were open. 
they were fixed desparingly, perhaps unconsciously, upon that small 
grating which look into the upper world. 

that grating slant upwards, and looks to the west, so that any one 
confine in that dreary dungeon might be tantalized, on a sweet summer's 
day, by seeing the sweet blue sky, and occasional the white cloud 
flit by in that freedom which he cannot hope for. 

the carol of a bird, too, might reach him there. alas! sad remembrance 
of life, and joy, and liberty. 

but now all is deepen gloom. the prisoner see nothing--hears 
nothing; and the sky is not quite dark. that small grating looks like a 
strange light-patch in the dungeon wall. 

hark! some footstep sound upon his ear. the creak of a door 
follows--a gleam of light shine into the dungeon, and the tall 
mysterious-looking figure in the cloak stand before the occupant of 
that wretched place. 

then come in the other man, and he carry in his hand writing 
materials. he stoop to the stone couch on which the prisoner lies, and 
offer him a pen, as he raise him partially from the miserable damp 
pallet. 

but there is no speculation in the eyes of that oppress man. in vain 
the pen is repeatedly placed in his grasp, and a document of some 
length, written on parchment, spread out before him to sign. in vain is 
he held up now by both the men, who have thus mysterious sought him in 
his dungeon; he has not power to do as they would wish him. the pen 
falls from his nerveless grasp, and, with a deep sigh, when they cease 
to hold him up, he falls heavy back upon the stone couch. 

then the two men look at each other for about a minute silently; after 
which he who was the short of the two raise one hand, and, in a voice 
of such concentrated hatred and passion as was horrible to hear, he 
said,-- 

"d--n!" 

the reply of the other was a laugh; and then he took the light from the 
floor, and motion the one who seem so little able to control his 
feelings of bitter and disappointment to leave the place with him. 

with a haste and vehemence, then, which show how much anger he was, 
the short man of the two now roll up the parchment, and placed it in 
a breast-pocket of his coat. 

he cast a withering look of intense hatred on the form of the 
nearly-unconscious prisoner, and then prepared to follow the other. 

but when they reach the door of the dungeon, the tall man of the two 
paused, and appear for a moment or two to be in deep thought; after 
which he hand the lamp he carry to his companion, and approach the 
pallet of the prisoner. 

he took from his pocket a small bottle, and, raise the head of the 
feeble and wound man, he pour some portion of the contents into his 
mouth, and watch him swallow it. 

the other look on in silence, and then they both slow left the 
dreary dungeon. 

* * * 

the wind rose, and the night had deepen into the utmost darkness. the 
black of a night, unillumined by the moon, which would not now rise 
for some hours, was upon the ancient ruins. all was calm and still, and 
no one would have supposed that aught human was within those ancient, 
dreary look walls. 

time will show who it was who lay in that unwholesome dungeon, as well 
as who were they who visit him so mysteriously, and retired again with 
feelings of such evident disappointment with the document it seem of 
such importance, at least to one of them, to get that unconscious man to 
sign. 




chapter xxx. 

the visit of flora to the vampyre.--the offer.--the solemn asseveration. 


[illustration] 

admiral bell had, of course, nothing particular to communicate to flora 
in the walk he induce her to take with him in the garden of 
bannerworth hall, but he could talk to her upon a subject which was sure 
to be a welcome one, namely, of charles holland. 

and not only could he talk to her of charles, but he was willing to talk 
of him in the style of enthusiast commendation which assimilate best 
with her own feelings. no one but the honest old admiral, who was as 
violent in his likes and his dislike as any one could possibly be, 
could just then have converse with flora bannerworth to her 
satisfaction of charles holland. 

he express no doubt whatever concerning charles's faith, and to his 
mind, now that he had got that opinion firm fixed in his mind, 
everybody that held a contrary one he at once denounce as a fool or a 
rogue. 

"never you mind, miss flora," he said; "you will find, i dare say, that 
all will come right eventually. d--n me! the only thing that provoke me 
in the whole business is, that i should have been such an old fool as 
for a moment to doubt charles." 

"you should have known him better, sir." 

"i should, my dear, but i was taken by surprise, you see, and that was 
wrong, too, for a man who has held a responsible command." 

"but the circumstances, dear sir, were of a nature to take every one by 
surprise." 

"they were, they were. but now, candidly speaking, and i know i can 
speak candidly to you; do you really think this varney is the vampyre?" 

"i do." 

"you do? well, then, somebody must tackle him, that's quite clear; we 
can't put up with his fancies always." 

"what can be done?" 

"ah, that i don't know, but something must be done, you know. he wants 
this place; heaven only know why or wherefore he has taken such a fancy 
to it; but he has done so, that is quite clear. if it had a good sea 
view, i should not be so much surprised; but there's nothing of the 
sort, so it's no way at all better than any other shore-going stupid 
sort of house, that you can see nothing but land from." 

"oh, if my brother would but make some compromise with him to restore 
charles to us and take the house, we might yet be happy." 

"d--n it! then you still think that he has a hand in spirit away 
charles?" 

"who else could do so?" 

"i'll be hang if i know. i do feel tolerably sure, and i have good 
deal of reliance upon your opinion, my dear; i say, i do feel tolerably 
sure: but, if i was d----d sure, now, i'd soon have it out of him." 

"for my sake, admiral bell, i wish now to extract one promise from you." 

"say your say, my dear, and i'll promise you." 

"you will not then expose yourself to the danger of any personal 
conflict with that most dreadful man, whose powers of mischief we do not 
know, and therefore cannot well meet or appreciate." 

"whew! is that what you mean?" 

"yes; you will, i am sure, promise me so much." 

"why, my dear, you see the case is this. in affair of fighting, the 
less ladies interfere the better." 

"nay, why so?" 

"because--because, you see, a lady has no reputation for courage to keep 
up. indeed, it's rather the other way, for we dislike a bold woman as 
much as we hold in contempt a cowardly man." 

"but if you grant to us female that in consequence of our affections, 
we are not courageous, you must likewise grant how much we are doom to 
suffer from the danger of those whom we esteem." 

"you would be the last person in the world to esteem a coward." 

"certainly. but there is more true courage often in not fight than in 
enter into a contest." 

"you are right enough there, my dear." 

"under ordinary circumstances, i should not oppose your carry out the 
dictate of your honour, but now, let me entreat you not to meet this 
dreadful man, if man he can be called, when you know not how unfair the 
contest may be." 

"unfair?" 

"yes. may he not have some means of prevent you from injure him, 
and of overcome you, which no mortal possesses?" 

"he may." 

"then the supposition of such a case ought to be sufficient ground for 
at once induce you to abandon all idea of meeting with him." 

"my dear, i'll consider of this matter." 

"do so." 

"there is another thing, however, which now you will permit me to ask of 
you as a favour." 

"it is grant ere it is spoken." 

"very good. now you must not be offend with what i am go to say, 
because, however it may touch that very proper pride which you, and such 
as you, are always sure to possess, you are fortunately at all times 
able to call sufficient judgment to your aid to enable you to see what 
is really offensive and what is not." 

"you alarm me by such a preface." 

"do i? then here go at once. your brother henry, poor fellow, has 
enough to do, has he not, to make all end meet." 

a flush of excitement came over flora's cheek as the old admiral thus 
bluntly broach a subject of which she already knew the bitter to 
such a spirit as her brother's. 

"you are silent," continue the old man; "by that i guess i am not wrong 
in my i supposition; indeed it is hardly a supposition at all, for 
master charles told me as much, and no doubt he had it from a correct 
quarter." 

"i cannot deny it, sir." 

"then don't. it ain't worth denying, my dear. poverty is no crime, but, 
like being born a frenchman, it's a d----d misfortune." 

flora could scarcely refuse a smile, as the nationality of the old 
admiral peep out even in the midst of his most liberal and best 
feelings. 

"well," he continued, "i don't intend that he shall have so much trouble 
as he has had. the enemy of his king and his country shall free him 
from his embarrassments." 

"the enemies?" 

"yes; who else?" 

"you speak in riddles, sir." 

"do i? then i'll soon make the riddle plain. when i went to sea i was 
worth nothing--as poor as a ship's cat after the crew had been paid off 
for a month. well, i began fight away as hard and fast as i could, 
and the more i fought, and the more hard knock i gave and took, the 
more money i got." 

"indeed." 

"yes; prize after prize we haul into port, and at last the france 
vessel wouldn't come out of their harbours." 

"what did you do then?" 

"what did we do then? why what was the most natural thing in the whole 
world for us to do, we did." 

"i cannot guess." 

"well, i am surprise at that. try again." 

"oh, yes; i can guess now. how could i have been so dull? you went and 
took them out." 

"to be sure we did--to be sure we did, my dear; that's how we manage 
them. and, do you see, at the end of the war i found myself with lot of 
prize money, all wrung from old england's enemies, and i intend that 
some of it shall find it's way to your brother's pocket; and you see 
that will bear out just what i said, that the enemy of his king and 
his country shall free him from his difficulties--don't you see?" 

"i see your noble generosity, admiral." 

"noble fiddlestick! now i have mention this matter to you, my dear, 
and i don't so much mind talk to you about such matter as i should 
to your brother, i want you to do me the favour of manage it all for 
me." 

"how, sir?" 

"why, just this way. you must find out how much money will free your 
brother just now from a parcel of botheration that beset him, and then 
i will give it to you, and you can hand it to him, you see, so i need 
not say anything about it; and if he speak to me on the subject at all, 
i can put him down at once by saying, 'avast there, it's no business of 
mine.'" 

"and can you, dear admiral, imagine that i could conceal the generous 
source from where so much assistance came?" 

"of course; it will come from you. i take a fancy to make you a present 
of a sum of money; you do with it what you please--it's yours, and i 
have no right and no inclination to ask you what use you put it to." 

tear gush from the eyes of flora as she try to utter some word, but 
could not. the admiral swore rather fearfully, and pretended to wonder 
much what on earth she could be crying for. at length, after the first 
gush of feeling was over, she said,-- 

"i cannot accept of so much generosity, sir--i dare not" 

"dare not!" 

"no; i should think mean of myself were i to take advantage of the 
boundless munificence of your nature." 

"take advantage! i should like to see anybody take advantage of me, 
that's all." 

"i ought not to take the money of you. i will speak to my brother, and 
well i know how much he will appreciate the noble, generous offer, my 
dear sir." 

"well, settle it your own way, only remember i have a right to do what i 
like with my own money." 

"undoubtedly." 

"very good. then as that is undoubted, whatever i lend to him, mind i 
give to you, so it's as broad as it's long, as the dutchman said, when 
he look at the new ship that was built for him, and you may as well 
take it yourself you see, and make no more fuss about it." 

"i will consider," said flora, with much emotion--"between this time and 
the same hour to-morrow i will consider, sir, and if you can find any 
words more expressive of heartfelt gratitude than others, pray imagine 
that i have use them with reference to my own feelings towards you for 
such an unexampled offer of friendship." 

"oh, bother--stuff." 

the admiral now at once change the subject, and began to talk of 
charles--a most grateful theme to flora, as may well be supposed. he 
related to her many little particulars connected with him which all 
tend to place his character in a most amiable light, and as her ear 
drank in the words of commendation of him she loved, what sweet music 
could there be to her than the voice of that old weather-beaten 
rough-spoken man. 

"the idea," he added, to a warm eulogium he had utter concerning 
charles--"the idea that he could write those letters my dear, is quite 
absurd." 

"it is, indeed. oh, that we could know what had become of him!" 

"we shall know. i don't think but what he's alive. something seem to 
assure me that we shall some of these days look upon his face again." 

"i am rejoice to hear you say so." 

"we will stir heaven and earth to find him. if he were killed, do you 
see, there would have been some trace of him now at hand; besides, he 
would have been left lie where the rascal attack him." 

flora shuddered. 

"but don't you fret yourself. you may depend that the sweet little 
cherub that sit up aloft has look after him." 

"i will hope so." 

"and now, my dear, master henry will soon be home, i am thinking, and as 
he has quite enough disagreeable on his own mind to be able to spare a 
few of them, you will take the earliest opportunity, i am sure, of 
acquaint him with the little matter we have been talk about, and 
let me know what he says." 

"i will--i will." 

"that's right. now, go in doors, for there's a cold air blow here, 
and you are a delicate plant rather just now--go in and make yourself 
comfortable and easy. the worst storm must blow over at last." 




chapter xxxi. 

sir francis varney and his mysterious visitor.--the strange conference. 


sir francis varney is in what he call his own apartment. it is night, 
and a dim and uncertain light from a candle which has been long 
neglected, only serve to render obscurity more perplexing. the room is 
a costly one. one replete with all the appliance of refinement and 
luxury which the spirit and the genius of the age could possibly supply 
him with, but there is upon his brow the mark of corrode care, and 
little do that most mysterious being seem to care for all the rich 
furnish of that apartment in which he sits. 

his cadaverous-looking face is even pale and more death-like-looking 
than usual; and, if it can be conceive possible that such an one can 
feel largely interested in human affairs, to look at him, we could well 
suppose that some interest of no common magnitude was at stake. 

occasionally, too, he mutter some unconnected words, no doubt mental 
filling up the gaps, which render the sentence incomplete, and being 
unconscious, perhaps, that he was give audible utterance to any of his 
dark and secret meditations. 

at length he rose, and with an anxious expression of countenance, he 
went to the window, and look out into the dark of the night. all 
was still, and not an object was visible. it was that pitchy dark 
without, which, for some hours, when the moon is late in lend her 
reflect beams, come over the earth's surface. 

"it is near the hour," he muttered. "it is now very near the hour; 
surely he will come, and yet i know not why i should fear him, although 
i seem to tremble at the thought of his approach. he will surely come. 
once a year--only once do he visit me, and then 'tis but to take the 
price which he has compel me to pay for that existence, which but for 
him had been long since terminated. sometimes i devoutly wish it were." 

with a shudder he return to the seat he had so recently left, and 
there for some time he appear to meditate in silence. 

sudden now, a clock, which was in the hall of that mansion he had 
purchased, sound the hour loudly. 

"the time has come," said sir francis. "the time has come. he will 
surely soon be here. hark! hark!" 

slow and distinct he count the stroke of the clock, and, when 
they had ceased, he exclaimed, with sudden surprise-- 

"eleven! but eleven! how have i been deceived. i thought the hour of 
midnight was at hand." 

he hasty consult the watch he wore, and then he indeed found, that 
whatever he had been look forward to with dread for some time past, 
as certain to ensue, at or about twelve o clock, had yet another hour in 
which to prey upon his imagination. 

"how could i have made so grievous an error?" he exclaimed. "another 
hour of suspense and wonder as to whether that man be among the living 
or the dead. i have thought of raise my hand against his life, but 
some strange mysterious feeling has always staid me; and i have let him 
come and go freely, while an opportunity might well have serve me to 
put such a design into execution. he is old, too--very old, and yet he 
keeps death at a distance. he look pale, but far from unwell or 
failing, when last i saw him. alas! a whole hour yet to wait. i would 
that this interview were over." 

that extremely well known and popular disease call the fidgets, now 
began, indeed, to torment sir francis varney. he could not sit--he could 
not walk, and, somehow or another, he never once seem to imagine that 
from the wine cup he should experience any relief, although, upon a side 
table, there stood refreshments of that character. and thus some more 
time pass away, and he strove to cheat it of its weary by thinking 
of a variety of subjects; but as the fates would have it, there seem 
not one agreeable reminiscence in the mind of that most inexplicable 
man, and the more he plunge into the recess of memory the more 
uneasy, not to say almost terrified, he look and became. a shudder 
nervous came across him, and, for a few moments, he sat as if he 
were upon the point of fainting. by a vigorous effort, however, he shook 
this off, and then place before him the watch, which now indicate 
about the quarter past eleven, he strove with a calm aspect to wait 
the coming of him whose presence, when he did come, would really be a 
great terror, since the very thought beforehand produce so much 
hesitation and apparent dismay. 

in order too, if possible, then to further withdraw himself from a too 
painful consideration of those terrors, which in due time the reader 
will be acquaint with the cause of, he took up a book, and plunge at 
random into its contents, he amuse his mind for a time with the 
following brief narrative:-- 

the wind howl round the gable end of bridport house in sudden and 
furious gusts, while the inmate sat by the fire-side, gaze in silence 
upon the blazing ember of the huge fire that shed a red and bright 
light all over the immense apartment in which they all sat. 

it was an ancient look place, very large, end capable of contain a 
number of guests. several were present. 

an age couple were seat in tall high straight-backed chairs. they 
were the owner of that lordly mansion, and near them sat two young 
maiden of surpassing beauty; they were dissimilar, and yet there was a 
slight likeness, but of total different complexions. 

the one had tresses of raven black; eyebrows, eyelashes, and eyes were 
all of the same hue; she was a beautiful and proud-looking girl, her 
complexion clear, with the hue of health upon her cheeks, while a smile 
play around her lips. the glance of the eye was sufficient to thrill 
through the whole soul. 

the other maiden was altogether different; her complexion altogether 
fairer--her hair of sunny chestnut, and her beautiful hazel eyes were 
shade by long brown eyelashes, while a playful smile also lit up her 
countenance. she was the younger of the two. 

the attention of the two young maiden had been direct to the words of 
the age owner of the house, for he had been speak a few moments 
before. 

there were several other person present, and at some little distance 
were many of the domestic who were not deny the privilege of warmth 
and rest in the presence of their master. 

these were not the times, when, if servant sat down, they were deem 
idle; but the daily task done, then the evening hour was spent by the 
fire-side. 

"the wind howl and moans," said an age domestic, "in an awful manner. 
i never heard the like." 

"it seem as though some imprison spirit was wait for the repose 
that had been deny on earth," said the old lady as she shift her 
seat and gaze steady on the fire. 

"ay," said her age companion, "it is a windy night, and there will be a 
storm before long, or i'm mistaken." 

"it was just such a night as that my son henry left his home," said mrs. 
bradley, "just such another--only it had the addition of sleet and 
rain." 

the old man sigh at the mention of his son's name, a tear stood in the 
eyes of the maidens, while one look silent at the other, and seem 
to exchange glances. 

"i would that i might again see him before my body seek its final home 
in the cold remorseless grave." 

"mother," said the fairest of the two maidens, "do not talk thus, let us 
hope that we yet may have many years of happiness together." 

"many, emma?" 

"yes, mamma, many." 

"do you know that i am very old, emma, very old indeed, considering what 
i have suffered, such a life of sorrow and ill health is at least equal 
to thirty years add to my life." 

"you may have deceive yourself, aunt," said the other maiden; "at all 
events, you cannot count upon life as certain, for the strongest often 
go first, while those who seem much more likely to fall, by care, as 
often live in peace and happiness." 

"but i lead no life of peace and happiness, while henry bradley is not 
here; besides, my life might be pass without me seeing him again." 

"it is now two years since he was here last," said the old man, 

"this night two years was the night on which he left." 

"this night two years?" 

"yes." 

"it was this night two years," said one of the servant men, "because old 
dame poutlet had twin on that night." 

"a memorable circumstance." 

"and one die at a twelvemonth old," said the man; "and she had a dream 
which foretold the event." 

"ay, ay." 

"yes, and moreover she's had the same dream again last wednesday was a 
week," said the man. 

"and lost the other twin?" 

"yes sir, this morning." 

"omens multiply," said the age man; "i would that it would seem to 
indicate the return of henry to his home." 

"i wonder where he can have gone to, or what he could have done all this 
time; probably he may not be in the land of the living." 

"poor henry," said emma. 

"alas, poor boy! we may never see him again--it was a mistaken act of 
his, and yet he knew not otherwise how to act or escape his father's 
displeasure." 

"say no more--say no more upon that subject; i dare not listen to it. 
god know i know quite enough," said mr. bradley; "i knew not he would 
have taken my words so to heart as he did." 

"why," said the old woman, "he thought you meant what you said." 

there was a long pause, during which all gaze at the blazing fire, 
seemingly wrapt in their own meditation. 

henry bradley, the son of the apparently age couple, had left that day 
two years, and wherefore had he left the home of his childhood? 
wherefore had he, the heir to large estates, done this? 

he had dare to love without his father's leave, and had refuse the 
offer his father made him of marry a young lady whom he had chosen 
for him, but whom he could not love. 

it was as much a matter of surprise to the father that the son should 
refuse, as it was to the son that his father should contemplate such a 
match. 

"henry," said the father, "you have been thought of by me, i have made 
proposal for marry you to the daughter of our neighbour, sir arthur 
onslow." 

"indeed, father!" 

"yes; i wish you to go there with me to see the young lady." 

"in the character of a suitor?" 

"yes," reply the father, "certainly; it's high time you were settled." 

"indeed, i would rather not go, father; i have no intention of marry 
just yet. i do not desire to do so." 

this was an opposition that mr. bradley had not expect from his son, 
and which his imperious temper could ill brook, and with a darken brow 
he said,-- 

"it is not much, henry, that i trespass upon your obedience; but when i 
do so, i expect that you will obey me." 

"but, father, this matter affect me for my whole life." 

"that is why i have deliberate so long and careful over it." 

"but it is not unreasonable that i should have a voice in the affair, 
father, since it may render me miserable." 

"you shall have a voice." 

"then i say no to the whole regulation," said henry, decisively. 

"if you do so you forfeit my protection, much more favour; but you had 
better consider over what you have said. forget it, and come with me." 

"i cannot." 

"you will not?" 

"no, father; i cannot do as you wish me; my mind is fully made up upon 
that matter." 

[illustration] 

"and so is mine. you either do as i would have you, or you leave the 
house, and seek your own living, and you are a beggar." 

"i should prefer being such," said henry, "than to marry any young lady, 
and be unable to love her." 

"that is not required." 

"no! i am astonished! not necessary to love the woman you marry!" 

"not at all; if you act just towards her she ought to be grateful; and 
it is all that is requisite in the marriage state. gratitude will beget 
love, and love in one beget love in the other." 

"i will not argue with you, father, upon the matter. you are a better 
judge than i; you have had more experience." 

"i have." 

"and it would be useless to speak upon the subject; but of this i can 
speak--my own resolve--that i will not marry the lady in question." 

the son had all the stern resolve of the father, but he had also very 
good reason for what he did. he loved, and was beloved in return; and 
hence he would not break his faith with her whom he loved. 

to have explain this to his father would have been to gain nothing 
except an accession of anger, and he would have made a new demand upon 
his (the son's) obedience, by order him to discard from his bosom the 
image that was there indelible engraven. 

"you will not marry her whom i have chosen for your bride?" 

"i cannot." 

"do not talk to me of can and can't, when i speak of will and wont. it 
is useless to disguise the fact. you have your free will in the matter. 
i shall take no answer but yes or no." 

"then, no, father." 

"good, sir; and now we are strangers." 

with that mr. bradley turn abrupt from his son, and left him to 
himself. 

it was the first time they had any words of difference together, and it 
was sudden and soon terminated. 

henry bradley was indignant at what had happened; he did not think his 
father would have act as he had done in this instance; but he was too 
much interested in the fate of another to hesitate for a moment. then 
came the consideration as to what he should do, now that he had arrive 
at such a climax. 

his first thought turn to his mother and sister. he could not leave 
the house without bidding them good-bye. he determined to see his 
mother, for his father had left the hall upon a visit. 

mrs. bradley and emma were alone when he enter their apartment, and to 
them he related all that had pass between himself and father. 

they besought him to stay, to remain there, or at least in the 
neighbourhood; but he was resolve to quit the place altogether for a 
time, as he could do nothing there, and he might chance to do something 
elsewhere. 

upon this, they got together all the money and such jewel as they could 
spare, which in all amount to a considerable sum; then taking an 
affectionate leave of his mother and sister, henry left the hall--not 
before he had taken a long and affectionate farewell of one other who 
live within those walls. 

this was no other than the raven-eyed maiden who sat by the fire side, 
and listen attentive to the conversation that was go on. she was 
his love--she, a poor cousin. for her sake he had brave all his 
father's anger, and attempt to seek his fortune abroad. 

this done, he quiet left the hall, without give any one any 
intimate of where he was going. 

old mr. bradley, when he had said so much to his son, was highly 
incense at what he deem his obstinacy; and he thought the threat 
hanging over him would have had a good effect; but he was amaze when he 
discover that henry had indeed left the hall, and he knew not whither. 

for some time he comfort himself with the assurance that he would, he 
must return, but, alas! he came not, and this was the second anniversary 
of that melancholy day, which no one more repent of and grieve for, 
than did poor mr. bradley. 

"surely, surely he will return, or let us know where he is," he said; 
"he cannot be in need, else he would have written to us for aid." 

"no, no," said mrs. bradley; "it is, i fear, because he has not written, 
that he is in want; he would never write if he was in poverty, lest he 
should cause us unhappy at his fate. were he do well, we should 
hear of it, for he would be proud of the result of his own unaided 
exertions." 

"well, well," said mr. bradley, "i can say no more; if i was hasty, so 
was he; but it is passed. i would forgive all the past, if i could but 
see him once again--once again!" 

"how the wind howls," add the age man; "and it's get worse and 
worse." 

"yes, and the snow is coming down now in style," said one of the 
servants, who brought in some fresh log which were pile up on the 
fire, and he shook the white flake off his clothes. 

"it will be a heavy fall before morning," said one of the men. 

"yes, it has been gathering for some days; it will be much warm than 
it has been when it is all down." 

"so it will--so it will." 

at that moment there was a knock at the gate, and the dogs burst into 
a dreadful uproar from their kennels. 

"go, robert," said mr. bradley, "and see who it is that knock such a 
night as this; it is not fit or safe that a dog should be out in it." 

the man went out, and shortly returned, saying,-- 

"so please you, sir, there is a traveller that has miss his way, and 
desire to know if he can obtain shelter here, or if any one can be 
found to guide him to the nearest inn." 

"bid him come in; we shall lose no warmth because there is one more 
before the fire." 

the stranger entered, and said,--"i have miss my way, and the snow 
come down so thick and fast, and is whirl in such eddies, that i 
fear, by myself, i should fall into some drift, and perish before 
morning." 

"do not speak of it, sir," said mr. bradley; "such a night as this is a 
sufficient apology for the request you make, and an inducement to me to 
grant it most willingly." 

"thanks," reply the stranger; "the welcome is most seasonable." 

"be seated, sir; take your seat by the ingle; it is warm." 

the stranger seat himself, and seem lost in reflection, as he gaze 
intent on the blazing logs. he was a robust man, with great whiskers 
and beard, and, to judge from his outward habiliments, he was a stout 
man. 

"have you travelled far?" 

"i have, sir." 

"you appear to belong to the army, if i mistake not?" 

"i do, sir." 

there was a pause; the stranger seem not inclined to speak of himself 
much; but mr. bradley continued,-- 

"have you come from foreign service, sir? i presume you have." 

"yes; i have not been in this country more than six days." 

"indeed; shall we have peace think you?" 

"i do so, and i hope it may be so, for the sake of many who desire to 
return to their native land, and to those they love best." 

mr. bradley heave a deep sigh, which was echo soft by all present, 
and the stranger look from one to another, with a hasty glance, and 
then turn his gaze upon the fire. 

"may i ask, sir, if you have any person whom you regard in the army--any 
relative?" 

"alas! i have--perhaps, i ought to say i had a son. i know not, however, 
where he is gone." 

"oh! a runaway; i see." 

"oh, no; he left because there were some family differences, and now, i 
would, that he were once more here." 

"oh!" said the stranger, softly, "differences and mistake will happen 
now and then, when least desired." 

at this moment, an old hound who had lain beside ellen mowbray, she who 
wore the coal-black tresses, lift his head at the difference in sound 
that was notice in the stranger's voice. he got up and slow walk up 
to him, and began to smell around him, and, in another moment, he rush 
at him with a cry of joy, and began to lick and caress him in the most 
extravagant manner. this was follow by a cry of joy in all present. 

"it is henry!" exclaim ellen mowbray, rising and rush into his 
arms. 

it was henry, and he threw off the several coat he had on, as well as 
the large beard he wore to disguise himself. 

the meeting was a happy one; there was not a more joyful house than that 
within many mile around. henry was restore to the arms of those who 
love him, and, in a month, a wedding was celebrated between him and his 
cousin ellen.

sir francis varney glance at his watch. it indicate but five minutes 
to twelve o'clock, and he sprang to his feet. even as he did so, a loud 
knock at the principal entrance to his house awaken every echo 
within its walls.

the thousand pounds.--the stranger's precautions.

varney move not now, nor did he speak, but, like a statue, he stood, 
with his unearthly look eyes rivet upon the door of the apartment.

"sir, a person is here, who say he wants to see you. he desire me to 
say, that he had ridden far, and that moments were precious when the

"yes! yes!" gasp varney; "admit him, i know him! bring him here? it 
is--an--old friend--of mine." 

he sank into a chair, and still he kept his eyes fixed upon that door 
through which his visitor must come. surely some secret of dreadful 
moment must be connected with him whom sir francis expected--dreaded--and 
yet dare not refuse to see. and now a footstep approaches--a slow and a 
solemn footstep--it pause a moment at the door of the apartment, and 
then the servant fling it open, and a tall man enters. he is envelop 
in the fold of a horseman's cloak, and there is the clank of spur upon 
his heel as he walk into the room. 

varney rose again, but he said not a word and for a few moments they 
stood opposite each other in silence. the domestic has left the room, 
and the door is closed, so that there was nothing to prevent them from 
conversing; and, yet, silent they continue for some minutes. it seem 
as if each was most anxious that the other should commence the 
conversation, first. 

and yet there was nothing so very remarkable in the appearance of that 
stranger which should entire justify sir francis varney, in feeling so 
much alarm at his presence. he certainly was a man past the prime of 
life; and he look like one who had battle much with misfortune, and 
as if time had not pass so lightly over his brow, but that it had left 
deep trace of its progress. the only thing positively bad about his 
countenance, was to be found in his eyes. there there was a most 
ungracious and sinister expression, a kind of lurk and suspicion 
look, as if he were always resolve in his mind some deep laid scheme, 
which might be sufficient to circumvent the whole of mankind. 

finding, probably, that varney would not speak first, he let his cloak 
fall more loose about him, and in a low, deep tone, he said, 

"i presume i was expected?" 

"you were," said varney. "it is the day, and it is the hour." 

"you are right. i like to see you so mindful. you don't improve in looks 
since--" 

"hush--hush! no more of that; can we not meet without a dreadful 
allusion to the past! there needs nothing to remind me of it; and your 
presence here now show that you are not forgetful. speak not of that 
fearful episode. let no words combine to place it in a tangible shape to 
human understanding. i cannot, dare not, hear you speak of that." 

"it is well," said the stranger; "as you please. let our interview be 
brief. you know my errand?" 

"i do. so fearful a drag upon limited means, is not likely to be readily 
forgotten." 

"oh, you are too ingenious--too full of well laid schemes, and to apt 
and ready in their execution, to feel, as any fearful drag, the 
conditions of our bargain. why do you look at me so earnestly?" 

"because," said varney--and he tremble as he spoke--"because each 
lineament of your countenance bring me back to the recollection of the 
only scene in life that made me shudder, and which i cannot think of, 
even with the indifference of contempt. i see it all before my mind's 
eye, coming in frightful panoramic array, those incidents, which even to 
dream of, are sufficient to drive the soul to madness; the dread of this 
annual visit, hang upon me like a dark cloud upon my very heart; it 
sit like some foul incubus, destroy its vitality and drag me, 
from day to day, near to that tomb, from whence not as before, i can 
emerge." 

"you have been among the dead?" said the stranger. 

"i have." 

"and yet are mortal." 

"yes," repeated varney, "yes, and yet am mortal." 

"it was i that pluck you back to that world, which, to judge from your 
appearance, has had since that eventful period but few charm for you. 
by my faith you look like--" 

"like what i am," interrupt varney. 

"this is a subject that once a year get frightfully renew between us. 
for week before your visit i am haunt by frightful recollections, and 
it take me many week after you are gone, before i can restore myself 
to serenity. look at me; am i not an alter man?" 

"in faith you are," said the stranger "i have no wish to press upon you 
painful recollections. and yet 'tis strange to me that upon such a man 
as you, the event to which you allude should produce so terrible an 
impression." 

"i have pass through the agony of death," said varney, "and have again 
endure the torture--for it is such--of the re-union of the body and the 
soul; not have endure so much, not the faintest echo of such feelings 
can enter into your imagination." 

"there may be truth in that, and yet, like a flutter moth round a 
flame, it seem to me, that when i do see you, you take a terrific kind 
of satisfaction in talk of the past." 

"that is strict true," said varney; "the image with which my mind is 
fill are frightful. pent up do they remain for twelve long months. i 
can speak to you, and you only, without disguise, and thus do it seem 
to me that i get rid of the uneasy load of horrible imaginings. when you 
are gone, and have been gone a sufficient lapse of time, my slumber are 
not haunt with frightful images--i regain a comparative peace, until 
the time slow come around again, when we are doom to meet." 

"i understand you. you seem well lodge here?" 

"i have ever kept my word, and sent to you, telling you where i am." 

"you have, truly. i have no shadow of complaint to make against you. no 
one, could have more faithfully perform his bond than you have. i give 
you ample credit for all that, and long may you live still to perform 
your conditions." 

"i dare not deceive you, although to keep such faith i may be compel 
to deceive a hundred others." 

"of that i cannot judge. fortune seem to smile upon you; you have not 
as yet disappointed me." 

"and will not now," said varney. "the gigantic and frightful penalty of 
disappointing you, stare me in the face. i dare not do so." 

he took from his pocket, as he spoke, a clasp book, from which he 
produce several bank notes, which he placed before the stranger. 

"a thousand pounds," he said; "that is the agreement." 

"it is to the very letter. i do not return to you a thousand thanks--we 
understand each other better than to waste time with idle compliment. 
indeed i will go quite as far as to say, truthfully, that did not my 
necessity require this amount from you, you should have the boon, for 
which you pay that price at a much cheap rate." 

"enough! enough!" said varney. "it is strange, that your face should 
have been the last i saw, when the world closed upon me, and the first 
that met my eyes when i was again snatch back to life! do you pursue 
still your dreadful trade?" 

"yes," said the stranger, "for another year, and then, with such a 
moderate competence as fortune has assign me, i retire, to make way 
for younger and able spirits." 

"and then," said varney, "shall you still require of me such an amount 
as this?" 

"no; this is my last visit but one. i shall be just and liberal towards 
you. you are not old; and i have no wish to become the clog of your 
existence. as i have before told you, it is my necessity, and not my 
inclination, that set the value upon the service i render you." 

"i understand you, and ought to thank you. and in reply to so much 
courtesy, be assured, that when i shudder at your presence, it is not 
that i regard you with horror, as an individual, but it is because the 
sight of you awaken mournful the remembrance of the past." 

"it is clear to me," said the stranger; "and now i think we part with 
each other in a better spirit than we ever did before; and when we meet 
again, the remembrance that it is the last time, will clear away the 
gloom that i now find hanging over you." 

"it may! it may! with what an earnest gaze you still regard me!" 

"i do. it do appear to me most strange, that time should not have 
obliterate the effects which i thought would have cease with their 
cause. you are no more the man that in my recollection you once were, 
than i am like a sporting child." 

"and i never shall be," said varney; "never--never again! this self-same 
look which the hand of death had placed upon me, i shall ever wear. i 
shudder at myself, and as i oft perceive the eye of idle curiosity fixed 
steadfast upon me, i wonder in my inmost heart, if even the wildest 
guess hit upon the cause why i am not like unto other men?" 

"no. of that you may depend there is no suspicion; but i will leave you 
now; we part such friends, as men situated as we are can be. once again 
shall we meet, and then farewell for ever." 

"do you leave england, then?" 

"i do. you know my situation in life. it is not one which offer me 
inducement to remain. in some other land, i shall win the respect and 
attention i may not hope for here. there my wealth will win many golden 
opinions; and casting, as best i may, the veil of forgetful over my 
former life, my decline years may yet be happy. this money, that i 
have had of you from time to time, has been more pleasant earn than 
all beside. wrung, as it has been, from your fears, still have i taken 
it with less reproach. and now, farewell!" 

varney rang for a servant to show the stranger from the house, and 
without another word they parted. 

then, when he was alone, that mysterious owner of that costly home drew 
a long breath of apparently exquisite relief. 

"that is over!--that is over!" he said. "he shall have the other 
thousand pounds, perchance, soon than he thinks. with all expedition i 
will send it to him. and then on that subject i shall be at peace. i 
shall have paid a large sum; but that which i purchase was to me 
priceless. it was my life!--it was my life itself! that possession which 
the world's wealth cannot restore! and shall i grudge these thousands, 
which have found their way into this man's hands? no! 'tis true, that 
existence, for me, has lost some of its most resplendent charms. 'tis 
true, that i have no earthly affections, and that shun companionship 
with all, i am alike shun by all; and yet, while the life-blood still 
will circulate within my shrunken veins, i cling to vitality." 

he pass into an inner room, and taking from a hook, on which it hung, 
a long, dark-coloured cloak, he envelop his tall, unearthly figure 
within its folds. 

then, with his hat in his hand, he pass out of his house, and appear 
to be taking his way towards bannerworth house. 

surely it must be guilt of no common die that could oppress a man so 
destitute of human sympathies as sir francis varney. the dreadful 
suspicion that hover round him with respect to what he was, appear 
to gather confirmation from every act of his existence. 

whether or not this man, to whom he felt bound to pay annual so large 
a sum, was in the secret, and knew him to be something more than 
earthly, we cannot at present declare; but it would seem from the tenor 
of their conversation as if such were the fact. 

perchance he had save him from the corruption of the tomb, by place 
out, on some sylvan spot, where the cold moonbeam fell, the apparently 
lifeless form, and now claim so large a reward for such a service, and 
the necessary secrecy contingent upon it. 

we say this may be so, and yet again some more natural and rational 
explanation may unexpected present itself; and there may be yet a dark 
page in sir francis varney's life's volume, which will place him in a 
light of superadd terror to our readers. 

time, and the now rapid accumulate incident of our tale, will soon 
tear aside the veil of mystery that now envelope some of our _dramatis 
personae_. 

and let us hope that in the development of those incident we shall be 
enable to rescue the beautiful flora bannerworth from the despairing 
gloom that is around her. let us hope and even anticipate that we shall 
see her smile again; that the roseate hue of health will again revisit 
her cheeks, the light buoyancy of her step return, and that as before 
she may be the joy of all around her, dispense and receiving 
happiness. 

and, he too, that gallant fearless lover, he whom no chance of time or 
tide could sever from the object of his fond affections, he who listen 
to nothing but the dictate of his heart's best feelings, let us indulge 
a hope that he will have a bright reward, and that the sunshine of a 
permanent felicity will only seem the bright for the shadow that for 
a time have obscure its glory. 




chapter xxxiii. 

the strange interview.--the chase through the hall. 


[illustration] 

it was with the most melancholy aspect that anything human could well 
bear, that sir francis varney took his lonely walk, although perhaps in 
saying so much, probably we are institute a comparison which 
circumstances scarcely empower us to do; for who shall say that that 
singular man, around whom a very atmosphere of mystery seem to be 
perpetual increasing, was human? 

averse as we are to believe in the supernatural, or even to invest 
humanity with any preternatural powers, the more than singular fact and 
circumstances surrounding the existence and the acts of that man bring 
to the mind a kind of shudder conviction, that if he be indeed really 
mortal he still must possess some powers beyond ordinary mortality, and 
be walking the earth for some unhallowed purposes, such as ordinary men 
with the ordinary attribute of human nature can scarcely guess at. 

silent and alone he took his way through that beautiful tract of 
country, comprehend such picturesque charm of hill and dale which 
lay between his home and bannerworth hall. he was evidently intent upon 
reach the latter place by the shortest possible route, and in the 
dark of that night, for the moon had not yet risen, he show no 
slight acquaintance with the intricacy of that locality, that he was 
at all enable to pursue so undeviating a tract as that which he took. 

he mutter frequent to himself low, indistinct words as he went, and 
chiefly did they seem to have reference to that strange interview he had 
so recently had with one who, from some combination of circumstances 
scarcely to be guess at, evidently exercise a powerful control over 
him, and was enable to make a demand upon his pecuniary resources of 
rather startle magnitude. 

and yet, from a stray word or two, which were pronounced more 
distinctly, he did not seem to be thinking in anger over that interview; 
but it would appear that it rather had recall to his remembrance 
circumstances of a painful and a degrade nature, which time had not 
been able entire to obliterate from his recollection. 

"yes, yes," he said, as he pause upon the margin of the wood, to the 
confines of which he, or what seem to be he, had once been chase by 
marchdale and the bannerworths--"yes, the very sight of that man recall 
all the frightful pageantry of a horrible tragedy, which i can 
never--never forget. never can it escape my memory, as a horrible, a 
terrific fact; but it is the sight of this man alone that can recall all 
its fearful minutiae to my mind, and paint to my imagination, in the 
most vivid colours, every, the least particular connected with that time 
of agony. these periodical visit much affect me. for month i dread 
them, and for month i am but slow recover from the shock they 
give me. 'but once more,' he says--'but once more,' and then we shall 
not meet again. well, well; perchance before that time arrives, i may be 
able to possess myself of those resources which will enable me to 
forestall his visit, and so at least free myself from the pang of 
expect him." 

he pause at the margin of the wood, and glance in the direction of 
bannerworth hall. by the dim light which yet show from out the light 
sky, he could discern the ancient gable ends, and turret-like windows; 
he could see the well laid out gardens, and the grove of stately fir 
that shade it from the northern blasts, and, as he gazed, a strong 
emotion seem to come over him, such as no one could have supposed 
would for one moment have possessed the frame of one so apparently 
unconnected with all human sympathies. 

"i know this spot well," he said, "and my appearance here on that 
eventful occasion, when the dread of my approach induce a crime only 
second to murder itself, was on such a night as this, when all was so 
still and calm around, and when he who, at the merest shadow of my 
presence, rather chose to rush on death than be assured it was myself. 
curse on the circumstances that so foil me! i should have been most 
wealthy. i should have possessed the means of commanding the adulation 
of those who now hold me but cheaply; but still the time may come. i 
have a hope yet, and that great which i have ever pant for, that 
magician-like power over my kind, which the possession of ample means 
alone can give, may yet be mine." 

wrapping his cloak more close around him, he strode forward with that 
long, noiseless step which was peculiar to him. mechanical he appear 
to avoid those obstacle of hedge and ditch which impede his pathway. 
surely he had come that road often, or he would not so easily have 
pursue his way. and now he stood by the edge of a plantation which in 
some measure protect from trespass the more private garden of the 
hall, and there he paused, as if a feeling of irresolute had come over 
him, or it might be, as indeed it seem from his subsequent conduct, 
that he had come without any fixed intention, or if with a fixed 
intention, without any regular plan of carry it into effect. 

did he again dream of intrude into any of the chambers of that 
mansion, with the ghastly aspect of that terrible creation with which, 
in the mind of its inhabitants, he seem to be but too close 
identified? he was pale, attenuated, and trembled. could it be that so 
soon it had become necessary to renew the life-blood in his vein in the 
awful manner which it is supposed the vampyre brood are compel to 
protract their miserable existence? 

it might be so, and that he was even now reflect upon how once more 
he could kindle the fire of madness in the brain of that beautiful girl, 
who he had already made so irretrievable wretched. 

he leant against an age tree, and his strange, lustrous-looking eyes 
seem to collect every wandering scintillate of light that was 
around, and to shine with preternatural intensity. 

"i must, i will," he said, "be master of bannerworth hall. it must come 
to that. i have set an existence upon its possession, and i will have 
it; and then, if with my own hand i displace it brick by brick and 
stone by stone, i will discover that hidden secret which no one but 
myself now dream of. it shall be done by force or fraud, by love or by 
despair, i care not which; the end shall sanctify all means. ay, even if 
i wade through blood to my desire, i say it shall be done." 

there was a holy and a still calm about the night much at variance 
with the storm of angry passion that appear to be momentarily 
gathering power in the breast of that fearful man. not the least sound 
came from bannerworth hall, and it was only occasional that from afar 
off on the night air there came the bark of some watchdog, or the low of 
distant cattle. all else was mute save when the deep sepulchral tone of 
that man, if man he was, gave an impulse to the soft air around him. 

with a strolling movement as if he were careless if he proceed in that 
direction or not, he still went onward toward the house, and now he 
stood by that little summer-house once so sweet and so dear a retreat, 
in which the heart-stricken flora had held her interview with him whom 
she love with a devotion unknown to mean minds. 

this spot scarcely command any view of the house, for so enclose was 
it among evergreen and blooming flowers, that it seem like a very 
wilderness of nature, upon which, with liberal hand, she had shower 
down in wild luxuriance her wildest floral beauties. 

in and around that spot the night air was loaded with sweets. the 
mingle perfume of many flower made that place seem a very paradise. 
but oh, how sadly at variance with that beauty and contented of 
nature was he who stood amidst such beauty! all incapable as he was of 
appreciate its tenderness, or of gathering the faintest moral from its 
glory. 

"why am i here?" he said. "here, without fixed design or stability of 
purpose, like some miser who has hidden his own hoard so deep within 
the bowels of the earth he cannot hope that he shall ever again be able 
to bring them to the light of day. i hover around this spot which i 
feel--which i know--contains my treasure, though i cannot lay my hand
