wasn't a proper english mode of fighting. shouldn't you, jack?" 

"ay, ay, sir, i should." 

"shiver me, if i see an opportunity, if i don't let some of those 
rascal know what's what." 

scarcely had these words escape the lip of the old admiral than there 
arose a loud shout from the interior of the wood. it was a shout of 
success, and seem at the very least to herald the capture of the 
unfortunate varney. 

"by heaven!" exclaim henry, "they have him." 

"god forbid!" said mr. marchdale; "this grow too serious." 

"bear a hand, jack," said the admiral: "we'll have a fight for it yet; 
they sha'n't murder even a vampyre in cold blood. load the pistol and 
send a flying shot or two among the rascals, the moment they appear." 

"no, no," said henry; "no more violence, at least there has been 
enough--there has been enough." 

even as he spoke there came rush from among the trees, at the corner 
of the wood, the figure of a man. there need but one glance to assure 
them who it was. sir francis varney had been seen, and was flying before 
those implacable foe who had sought his life. 

he had divest himself of his huge cloak, as well as of his low 
slouch hat, and, with a speed which nothing but the most absolute 
desperation could have enable him to exert, he rush onward, beating 
down before him every obstacle, and bound over the meadow at a rate 
that, if he could have continue it for any length of time, would have 
set pursuit at defiance. 

"bravo!" shout the admiral, "a stern chase is a long chase, and i wish 
them joy of it--d----e, jack, did you ever see anybody get along like 
that?" 

"ay, ay, sir." 

"you never did, you scoundrel." 

"yes, i did." 

"when and where?" 

"when you ran away off the sound." 

the admiral turn nearly blue with anger, but jack look perfectly 
imperturbable, as he added,-- 

"you know you ran away after the france frigate who wouldn't stay to 
fight you." 

"ah! that indeed. there he goes, putt on every stitch of canvass, 
i'll be bound." 

"and there they come," said jack, as he pointed to the corner of the 
wood, and some of the more active of the vampyre's pursuer show 
themselves. 

it would appear as if the vampyre had been start from some 
hiding-place in the interior of the wood, and had then thought it 
expedient altogether to leave that retreat, and make his way to some 
more secure one across the open country, where there would be more 
obstacle to his discovery than perseverance could overcome. probably, 
then, among the brushwood and trees, for a few moments he had been again 
lost sight of, until those who were closest upon his track had emerge 
from among the dense foliage, and saw him scour across the country at 
such headlong speed. these were but few, and in their extreme anxiety 
themselves to capture varney, whose precipate and terrify flight 
brought a firm conviction to their mind of his being a vampyre, they 
did not stop to get much of a reinforcement, but plunge on like 
greyhound in his track. 

"jack," said the admiral, "this won't do. look at that great lubber 
fellow with the queer smock-frock." 

"never saw such a figure-head in my life," said jack. 

"stop him." 

"ay, ay, sir." 

the man was coming on at a prodigious rate, and jack, with all the 
deliberation in the world, advanced to meet him; and when they got 
sufficient close together, that in a few moments they must encounter 
each other, jack made himself into as small a bundle as possible, and 
present his shoulder to the advance countryman in such a way, that 
he flew off it at a tangent, as if he had run against a brick wall, and 
after rolling head over heel for some distance, safe deposit 
himself in a ditch, where he disappear completely for a few moments 
from all human observation. 

"don't say i hit you," said jack. "curse yer, what did yer run against 
me for? sarve you right. lubber as don't know how to steer, in course 
runs agin things." 

"bravo," said the admiral; "there's another of them." 

the pursuer of varney the vampyre, however, now came too thick and fast 
to be so easily disposed of, and as soon as his figure could be seen 
coursing over the meadows, and spring over road and ditch with an 
agile almost frightful to look upon, the whole rabble rout was in 
pursuit of him. 

by this time, the man who had fallen into the ditch had succeed in 
making his appearance in the visible world again, and as he crawl up 
the bank, look a thing of mire and mud, jack walk up to him with 
all the careless in the world, and said to him,-- 

"any luck, old chap?" 

"oh, murder!" said the man, "what do you mean? who are you? where am i? 
what's the matter? old muster fowler, the fat crowner, will set upon me 
now." 

"have you caught anything?" said jack. 

"caught anything?" 

"yes; you've been in for eels, haven't you?" 

"d--n!" 

"well, it is odd to me, as some people can't go a fishing without 
get out of temper. have it your own way; i won't interfere with 
you;" and away jack walked. 

the man clear the mud out of his eyes, as well as he could, and look 
after him with a powerful suspicion that in jack he saw the very cause 
of his mortal mishap: but, somehow or other, his immersion in the not 
over limpid stream had wonderful cool his courage, and casting one 
despairing look upon his begrime apparel, and another at the last of 
the straggle who were pursue sir francis varney across the fields, 
he thought it prudent to get home as fast he could, and get rid of the 
disagreeable result of an adventure which had turn out for him 
anything but auspicious or pleasant. 

mr. chillingworth, as though by a sort of impulse to be present in case 
sir francis varney should really be run down and with a hope of saving 
him from personal violence, had follow the foremost of the riot in 
the wood, found it now quite impossible for him to carry on such a chase 
as that which was being undertaken across the field after sir francis 
varney. 

his person was unfortunately but ill qualified for the continuance of 
such a pursuit, and, although with the greatest reluctance, he at last 
felt himself compel to give it up. 

in making his way through the intricacy of the wood, he had been 
seriously incommode by the thick undergrowth, and he had accidental 
encounter several miry pools, with which he had involuntary made a 
close acquaintance than was at all conducive either to his personal 
appearance or comfort. the doctor's temper, though, generally speaking, 
one of the most even, was at last affected by his mishaps, and he could 
not restrain from an execrate upon his want of prudence in letting his 
wife have a knowledge of a secret that was not his own, and the 
produce an unlooked for circumstance, the termination of which might 
be of a most disastrous nature. 

tired, therefore, and nearly exhaust by the exertion he had already 
taken, he emerge now alone from the wood, and near the spot where stood 
henry bannerworth and his friends in consultation. 

the jaded look of the surgeon was quite sufficient indication of the 
trouble and turmoil he had gone through, and some expression of 
sympathy for his condition were drop by henry, to whom he replied,-- 

"nay, my young friend, i deserve it all. i have nothing but my own 
indiscretion to thank for all the turmoil and tumult that has arisen 
this morning." 

"but to what possible cause can we attribute such an outrage?" 

"reproach me as much as you will, i deserve it. a man may prate of his 
own secret if he like, but he should be careful of those of other 
people. i trust yours to another, and am properly punished." 

"enough," said henry; "we'll say no more of that, mr. chillingworth. 
what is done cannot be undone, and we had better spend our time in 
reflection of how to make the best of what is, than in useless 
lamentation over its causes. what is to be done?" 

"nay, i know not. have you fought the duel?" 

"yes; and, as you perceive, harmlessly." 

"thank heaven for that." 

"nay, i had my fire, which sir francis varney refuse to return; so the 
affair had just ended, when the sound of approach tumult came upon 
our ears." 

[illustration] 

"what a strange mixture," exclaim marchdale, "of feelings and passion 
this varney appear to be. at one moment acting with the apparent 
greatest malignity; and another, seeming to have awaken in his mind a 
romantic generous which know no bounds. i cannot understand him." 

"nor i, indeed," said henry; "but yet i somehow tremble for his fate, 
and i seem to feel that something ought to be done to save him from the 
fearful consequence of popular feeling. let us hasten to the town, and 
procure what assistance we may: but a few persons, well organised and 
properly armed, will achieve wonders against a desultory and 
ill-appointed multitude. there may be a chance of saving him, yet, from 
the imminent danger which surround him." 

"that's proper," cry the admiral. "i don't like to see anybody run 
down. a fair fight's another thing. yard arm and yard arm--stink pot 
and pipkins--broadside to broadside--and throw in your bodies, if you 
like, on the lee quarter; but don't do anything shabby. what do you 
think of it, jack?" 

"why, i means to say as how if varney only keeps on sail as he's been 
doing, that the devil himself wouldn't catch him in a gale." 

"and yet," said henry, "it is our duty to do the best we can. let us at 
once to the town, and summons all the assistance in our power. come 
on--come on!" 

his friends need no further urging, but, at a brisk pace, they all 
proceed by the nearest footpath towards the town. 

it puzzle his pursuer to think in what possible direction sir francis 
varney expect to find sustenance or succour, when they saw how 
curious he took his flight across the meadows. instead of 
endeavouring, by any circuitous path, to seek the shelter of his own 
house, or to throw himself upon the care of the authority of the town, 
who must, to the extent of their power, have protect him, he struck 
across the fields, apparently without aim or purpose, seemingly intent 
upon nothing but to distance his pursuer in a long chase, which might 
possibly tire them, or it might not, according to their or his powers of 
endurance. 

we say this seem to be the case, but it was not so in reality. sir 
francis varney had a deep purpose, and it was scarcely to be supposed 
that a man of his subtle genius, and, apparently, far-seeing and 
reflect intellect, could have so far overlook the many danger of 
his position as not to be fully prepared for some such contingency as 
that which had just now occurred. 

holding, as he did, so strange a place in society--living among men, and 
yet possess so few attribute in common with humanity--he must all 
along have felt the possibility of drawing upon himself popular 
violence. 

he could not wholly rely upon the secrecy of the bannerworth family, 
much as they might well be supposed to shrink from give publicity to 
circumstances of so fearful strange and perilous a nature as those 
which had occur amongst them. the merest accident might, at any 
moment, make him the town's talk. the overhear of a few chance words 
by some gossip domestic--some ebullition of anger or annoyance by 
some member of the family--or a communication from some friend who had 
been treat with confidence--might, at any time, awaken around him some 
such a storm as that which now rage at his heels. 

varney the vampire must have calculate this. he must have felt the 
possibility of such a state of things; and, as a matter of course, 
politic provided himself with some place of refuge. 

after about twenty minutes of hard chase across the fields, there 
could be no doubt of his intentions. he had such a place of refuge; and, 
strange a one as it might appear, he sped towards it in as direct a line 
as ever a well-sped arrow flew towards its mark. 

that place of refuge, to the surprise of every one, appear to be the 
ancient ruin, of which we have before spoken, and which was so well 
known to every inhabitant of the county. 

truly, it seem like some act of mere desperation for sir francis 
varney to hope there to hide himself. there remain within, of what had 
once been a stately pile, but a few grey crumble walls, which the 
hunt have would have pass unheeded, knowing that not for one instant 
could he have baffle his pursuer by seek so inefficient a refuge. 

and those who follow hard and fast upon the track of sir francis 
varney felt so sure of their game, when they saw whither he was 
speeding, that they relax in their haste considerably, calling loud 
to each other that the vampire was caught at last, for he could be 
easily surround among the old ruins, and drag from amongst its 
moss-grown walls. 

in another moment, with a wild dash and a cry of exultation, he sprang 
out of sight, behind an angle, form by what had been at one time one 
of the principal support of the ancient structure. 

then, as if there was still something so dangerous about him, that only 
by a great number of hand could he be hope to be secured, the 
infuriate peasantry gather in a dense circle around what they 
considered his temporary place of refuge, and as the sun, which had now 
climb above the tree tops, and dispersed, in a great measure, many of 
the heavy cloud of morning, shone down upon the excited group, they 
might have been supposed there assemble to perform some superstitious 
rite, which time had hallow as an association of the crumble ruin 
around which they stood. 

by the time the whole of the stragglers, who had persist in the chase, 
had come up, there might have been about fifty or sixty resolute men, 
each intent upon secure the person of one whom they felt, while in 
existence, would continue to be a terror to all the weak and dear 
portion of their domestic circles. 

there was a pause of several minutes. those who had come the fleetest 
were gathering breath, and those who had come up last were look to 
their more forward companion for some information as to what had 
occur before their arrival. 

all was profound still within the ruin, and then suddenly, as if by 
common consent, there arose from every throat a loud shout of 
"down with the vampyre! down with the vampyre!" 

the echo of that shout die away, and then all was still as before, 
while a superstitious feeling crept over even the boldest. it would 
almost seem as if they had expect some kind of response from sir 
francis varney to the shout of defiance with which they had just greet 
him; but the very calmness, repose, and absolute quiet of the ruin, and 
all about it, alarm them, and they look the one at the other as if 
the adventure after all were not one of the pleasantest description, and 
might not fall out so happily as they had expected. 

yet what danger could there be? there were they, more than half a 
hundred stout, strong men, to cope with one; they felt convinced that he 
was completely in their power; they knew the ruins could not hide him, 
and that five minutes time given to the task, would suffice to explore 
every nook and corner of them. 

and yet they hesitated, while an unknown terror shook their nerves, and 
seemingly from the very fact that they had run down their game 
successfully, they dread to secure the trophy of the chase. 

one bold spirit was wanting; and, if it was not a bold one that spoke at 
length, he might be compliment as being comparatively such. it was one 
who had not been foremost in the chase, perchance from want of physical 
power, who now stood forward, and exclaimed,-- 

"what are you wait for, now? you can have him when you like. if you 
want your wives and children to sleep quiet in their beds, you will 
secure the vampyre. come on--we all know he's here--why do you hesitate? 
do you expect me to go alone and drag him out by the ears?" 

any voice would have suffice to break the spell which bound them. this 
did so; and, with one accord, and yell of imprecation, they rush 
forward and plunge among the old wall of the ruin. 

less time than we have before remark would have enable any one to 
explore the totter fabric sufficient to bring a conviction to their 
mind that, after all, there might have been some mistake about the 
matter, and sir francis varney was not quite caught yet. 

it was astonish how the fact of not finding him in a moment, again 
rouse all their angry feelings against him, and dispel every feeling 
of superstitious awe with which he had been surrounded; rage gave place 
to the sort of shudder horror with which they had before contemplate 
his immediate destruction, when they had believe him to be virtually 
within their very grasp. 

over and over again the ruins were searched--hastily and impatient by 
some, careful and deliberate by others, until there could be no 
doubt upon the mind of every one individual, that somehow or somewhere 
within the shadow of those walls, sir francis varney had disappear 
most mysteriously. 

then it would have been a strange sight for any indifferent spectator to 
have seen how they shrunk, one by one, out of the shadow of those ruins; 
each seeming to be afraid that the vampyre, in some mysterious manner, 
would catch him if he happen to be the last within their sombre 
influence; and, when they had all collected in the bright, open space, 
some little distance beyond, they look at each other and at the ruins, 
with dubious expression of countenance, each, no doubt, wish that 
each would suggest something of a consolatory or practicable character. 

"what's to be done, now?" said one. 

"ah! that's it," said another, sententiously. "i'll be hang if i 
know." 

"he's given us the slip," remark a third. 

"but he can't have given us the slip," said one man, who was 
particularly famous for a dogmatic spirit of argumentation; "how is it 
possible? he must be here, and i say he is here." 

"find him, then," cry several at once. 

"oh! that's nothing to do with the argument; he's here, whether we find 
him or not." 

one very cunning fellow laid his finger on his nose, and beckon to a 
comrade to retire some paces, where he deliver himself of the 
following very oracular sentiment:-- 

"my good friend, you must know sir francis varney is here or he isn't." 

"agreed, agreed." 

"well, if he isn't here it's no use trouble our head any more about 
him; but, otherwise, it's quite another thing, and, upon the whole, i 
must say, that i rather think he is." 

all look at him, for it was evident he was big with some suggestion. 
after a pause, he resumed,-- 

"now, my good friends, i propose that we all appear to give it up, and 
to go away; but that some one of us shall remain and hide among the 
ruins for some time, to watch, in case the vampyre make his appearance 
from some hole or corner that we haven't found out." 

"oh, capital!" said everybody. 

"then you all agree to that?" 

"yes, yes." 

"very good; that's the only way to nick him. now, we'll pretend to give 
it up; let's all of us talk loud about go home." 

they did all talk loud about go home; they swore that it was not 
worth the trouble of catching him, that they gave it up as a bad job; 
that he might go to the deuce in any way he liked, for all they cared; 
and then they all walk off in a body, when, the man who had made the 
suggestion, sudden cried,-- 

"hilloa! hilloa!--stop! stop! you know one of us is to wait?" 

"oh, ay; yes, yes, yes!" said everybody, and still they move on. 

"but really, you know, what's the use of this? who's to wait?" 

that was, indeed, a knotty question, which induce a serious 
consultation, ending in their all, with one accord, pitch upon the 
author of the suggestion, as by far the best person to hide in the ruins 
and catch the vampyre. 

they then all set off at full speed; but the cunning fellow, who 
certainly had not the slightest idea of so practically carry out his 
own suggestion, scamper off after them with a speed that soon brought 
him in the midst of the throng again, and so, with fear in their looks, 
and all the evidence of fatigue about them, they reach the town to 
spread fresh and more exaggerate account of the mysterious conduct of 
varney the vampyre. 




chapter xliv. 

varney's danger, and his rescue.--the prisoner again, and the 
subterranean vault. 


[illustration] 

we have before slightly mention to the reader, and not unadvisedly, 
the existence of a certain prisoner, confine in a gloomy dungeon, into 
whose sad and blacken recess but few and faint glimmer ray of 
light ever penetrated; for, by a diabolical ingenuity, the narrow 
loophole which serve for a window to that subterraneous abode was so 
constructed, that, let the sun be at what point it might, during its 
diurnal course, but a few reflect beam of light could ever find their 
way into that abode of sorrow. 

the prisoner--the same prisoner of whom we before spoke--is there. 
despair is in his looks, and his temple are still bound with those 
cloths, which seem now for many days to have been sop in blood, 
which has become encrust in their folds. 

he still lives, apparently incapable of movement. how he has live so 
long seem to be a mystery, for one would think him scarcely in a state, 
even were nourishment placed to his lips, to enable him to swallow it. 

it may be, however, that the mind has as much to do with that apparent 
absolute prostration of all sort of physical energy as those bodily 
wound which he has received at the hand of the enemy who have 
reduce him to his present painful and hopeless situation. 

occasional a low groan burst from his lips; it seem to come from the 
very bottom of his heart, and it sound as if it would carry with it 
every remnant of vitality that was yet remain to him. 

then he move restlessly, and repeat in hurried accent the name of 
some who are dear to him, and far away--some who may, perchance, be 
mourning him, but who know not, guess not, aught of his present 
sufferings. 

as he thus moves, the rustle of a chain among the straw on which he lie 
give an indication, that even in that dungeon it has not been 
considered prudent to leave him master of his own actions, lest, by too 
vigorous an effort, he might escape from the thraldom in which he is 
held. 

the sound reach his own ears, and for a few moments, in the deep 
impatience of his wound spirit, he heap malediction on the head of 
those who have reduce him to his present state. 

but soon a better nature seem to come over him, and gentle words fall 
from his lips. he preach patience to himself--he talks not of revenge, 
but of justice, and in accent of more hopeful than he had before 
spoken, he call upon heaven to succour him in his deep distress. 

then all is still, and the prisoner appear to have resigned himself 
once more to the calm of expectation or of despair; but hark! his 
sense of hearing, render doubly acute by lie so long alone in nearly 
darkness, and in positive silence, detect sound which, to ordinary 
mortal powers of perception, would have been by far too indistinct to 
produce any tangible effect upon the senses. 

it is the sound of feet--on, on they come; far overhead he hear them; 
they beat the green earth--that sweet, verdant sod, which he may never 
see again--with an impatient tread. near and near still; and now 
they pause; he listen with all the intensity of one who listen for 
existence; some one comes; there is a lumber noise--a hasty footstep; 
he hear some one labour for breath--panting like a hunt hare; his 
dungeon door is opened, and there totter in a man, tall and gaunt; he 
reel like one intoxicated; fatigue has done more than the work of 
inebriation; he cannot save himself, and he sink exhaust by the side 
of that lonely prisoner. 

the captive raise himself as far as his chain will allow him; he 
clutches the throat of his enervate visitor. 

"villain, monster, vampyre!" he shrieks, "i have thee now;" and lock 
in a deadly embrace, they roll upon the damp earth, struggle for life 
together. 

* * * * * 

it is mid-day at bannerworth hall, and flora is look from the 
case anxious expect the arrival of her brothers. she had seen, 
from some of the topmost window of the hall, that the whole 
neighbourhood had been in a state of commotion, but little did she guess 
the cause of so much tumult, or that it in any way concerned her. 

she had seen the peasantry forsake their work in the field and the 
gardens, and apparently intent upon some object of absorbing interest; 
but she fear to leave the house, for she had promise henry that she 
would not do so, lest the former pacific conduct of the vampyre should 
have been but a new snare, for the purpose of drawing her so far from 
her home as to lead her into some danger when she should be far from 
assistance. 

and yet more than once was she tempt to forget her promise, and to 
seek the open country, for fear that those she love should be 
encounter some danger for her sake, which she would willing either 
share with them or spare them. 

the solicitation, however, of her brother kept her comparatively quiet; 
and, moreover, since her last interview with varney, in which, at all 
events, he had shown some feeling for the melancholy situation to which, 
he had reduce her, she had been more able to reason calmly, and to meet 
the suggestion of passion and of impulse with a sober judgment. 

about midday, then, she saw the domestic party returning--that party, 
which now consist of her two brothers, the admiral, jack pringle, and 
mr. chillingworth. as for mr. marchdale, he had given them a polite 
adieu on the confines of the grounds of bannerworth hall, stating, that 
although he had felt it to be his duty to come forward and second henry 
bannerworth in the duel with the vampyre, yet that circumstance by no 
means obliterate from his memory the insult he had received from 
admiral bell, and, therefore, he decline go to bannerworth hall, and 
bade them a very good morning. 

to all this, admiral bell reply that he might go and be d----d, if he 
liked, and that he considered him a swab and a humbug, and appeal to 
jack pringle whether he, jack, ever saw such a sanctify look prig 
in his life. 

"ay, ay," say jack. 

this answer, of course, produce the usual contention, which last them 
until they got fairly in the house, where they swore at each other to an 
extent that was enough to make any one's hair stand on end, until henry 
and mr. chillingworth interfered, and really beg that they would 
postpone the discussion until some more fitting opportunity. 

the whole of the circumstances were then related to flora; who, while 
she blame her brother much for fight the duel with the vampyre, 
found in the conduct of that mysterious individual, as regard the 
encounter, yet another reason for believe him to be strict sincere 
in his desire to save her from the consequence of his future visits. 

her desire to leave bannerworth hall consequently became more and more 
intense, and as the admiral really now considered himself the master of 
the house, they offer no amount of opposition to the subject, but 
merely said,-- 

"my dear flora, admiral bell shall decide in all these matters, now. we 
know that he is our sincere friend; and that whatever he say we ought 
to do, will be dictate by the best possible feelings towards us." 

"then i appeal to you, sir," said flora, turning to the admiral. 

"very good," reply the old man; "then i say--" 

"nay, admiral," interrupt mr. chillingworth; "you promise me, but a 
short time since, that you would come to no decision whatever upon this 
question, until you had heard some particulars which i have to relate to 
you, which, in my humble opinion, will sway your judgment." 

"and so i did," cry the admiral; "but i had forgotten all about it. 
flora, my dear, i'll be with you in an hour or two. my friend, the 
doctor, here, has got some sow by the ear, and fancies it's the right 
one; however, i'll hear what he has got to say, first, before we come to 
a conclusion. so, come along, mr. chillingworth, and let's have it out 
at once." 

"flora," said henry, when the admiral had left the room, "i can see that 
you wish to leave the hall." 

"i do, brother; but not to go far--i wish rather to hide from varney 
than to make myself inaccessible by distance." 

"you still cling to this neighbourhood?" 

"i do, i do; and you know with what hope i cling to it." 

"perfectly; you still think it possible that charles dutch may be 
united to you." 

"i do, i do." 

"you believe his faith." 

"oh, yes; as i believe in heaven's mercy." 

"and i, flora; i would not doubt him now for worlds; something even now 
seem to whisper to me that a bright sun of happiness will yet dawn 
upon us, and that, when the mists which at present enshroud ourselves 
and our fortune pass away, they will disclose a landscape full of 
beauty, the future of which shall know no pangs." 

"yes, brother," exclaim flora, enthusiastically; "this, after all, may 
be but some trial, grievous while it lasts, but yet tend eventually 
only to make the future look more bright and beautiful. heaven may yet 
have in store for us all some great happiness, which shall spring 
clearly and decidedly from out these misfortunes." 

"be it so, and may we ever thus banish despair by such hopeful 
propositions. lean on my arm, flora; you are safe with me. come, 
dearest, and taste the sweet of the morning air." 

there was, indeed now, a hopeful about the manner in which henry 
bannerworth spoke, such as flora had not for some weary month had the 
pleasure of listen to, and she eager rose to accompany him into the 
garden, which was glowing with all the beauty of sunshine, for the day 
had turn out to be much fine than the early morning had at all 
promise it would be. 

"flora," he said, when they had taken some turn to and fro in the 
garden, "notwithstanding all that has happened, there is no convincing 
mr. chillingworth that sir francis varney is really what to us he 
appears." 

"indeed!" 

"it is so. in the face of all evidence, he neither will believe in 
vampyre at all, nor that varney is anything but some mortal man, like 
ourselves, in his thoughts, talents, feelings, and mode of life; and 
with no more power to do any one an injury than we have." 

"oh, would that i could think so!" 

"and i; but, unhappily, we have by far too many, and too conclusive 
evidence to the contrary." 

"we have, indeed, brother." 

"and though, while we respect that strength of mind in our friend which 
will not allow him, even almost at the last extremity, to yield to what 
appear to be stern facts, we may not ourselves be so obdurate, but may 
feel that we know enough to be convinced." 

"you have no doubt, brother?" 

"most reluctantly, i must confess, that i feel compel to consider 
varney as something more than mortal." 

"he must be so." 

"and now, sister, before we leave the place which has been a home to us 
from earliest life, let us for a few moments consider if there be any 
possible excuse for the notion of mr. chillingworth, to the effect that 
sir francis varney wants possession of the house for some purpose still 
more inimical to our peace and prosperity than any he has yet 
attempted." 

"has he such an opinion?" 

"he has." 

"'tis very strange." 

"yes, flora; he seem to gather from all the circumstances, nothing but 
an overwhelming desire on the part of sir francis varney to become the 
tenant of bannerworth hall." 

"he certainly wish to possess it." 

"yes; but can you, sister, in the exercise of any possible amount of 
fancy, imagine any motive for such an anxiety beyond what he alleges?" 

"which is merely that he is fond of old houses." 

"precisely so. that is the reason, and the only one, that can be got 
from him. heaven only know if it be the true one." 

"it may be, brother." 

"as you say, it may; but there's a doubt, nevertheless, flora. i much 
rejoice that you have had an interview with this mysterious being, for 
you have certainty, since that time, been happy and more compose than 
i ever hope to see you again." 

"i have indeed." 

"it is sufficient perceivable." 

"somehow, brother, since that interview, i have not had the same sort of 
dread of sir francis varney which before made the very sound of his name 
a note of terror to me. his words, and all he said to me during that 
interview which took place so strange between us, indeed how i know 
not, tend altogether rather to make him, to a certain extent, an 
object of my sympathies rather than my abhorrence." 

"that is very strange." 

"i own that it is strange, henry; but when we come for but a brief 
moment to reflect upon the circumstances which have occurred, we shall, 
i think, be able to find some cause even to pity varney the vampyre." 

"how?" 

"thus, brother. it is said--and well may i who have been subject to an 
attack of such a nature, tremble to repeat the saying--that those who 
have been once subject to the visitation of a vampyre, are themselves 
in a way to become one of the dreadful and maddening fraternity." 

"i have heard so much, sister," reply henry. 

"yes; and therefore who know but that sir francis varney may, at one 
time, have been as innocent as we are ourselves of the terrible and 
fiendish propensity which now make him a terror and a reproach to all 
who know him, or are in any way obnoxious to his attacks." 

"that is true." 

"there may have been a time--who shall say there was not?--when he, like 
me, would have shrunk, with a dread as great as any one could have 
experienced, from the contamination of the touch even of a vampyre." 

"i cannot, sister, deny the sound of your reasoning," said henry, 
with a sigh; "but i still no not see anything, even from a full 
conviction that varney is unfortunate, which should induce us to 
tolerate him." 

"nay, brother, i said not tolerate. what i mean is, that even with the 
horror and dread we must naturally feel at such a being, we may afford 
to mingle some amount of pity, which shall make us rather seek to shun 
him, than to cross his path with a resolution of do him an injury." 

"i perceive well, sister, what you mean. rather than remain here, and 
make an attempt to defy sir francis varney, you would fly from him, and 
leave him undisputed master of the field." 

"i would--i would." 

"heaven forbid that i or any one should thwart you. you know well, 
flora, how dear you are to me; you know well that your happiness has 
ever been to us all a matter which has assume the most important of 
shapes, as regard our general domestic policy. it is not, therefore, 
likely now, dear sister, that we should thwart you in your wish to 
remove from here." 

"i know, henry, all you would say," remark flora, as a tear start to 
her eyes. "i know well all you think, and, in your love for me, i 
likewise know well i rely for ever. you are attach to this place, as, 
indeed, we all are, by a thousand happy and pleasant associations; but 
listen to me further, henry, i do not wish to wander far." 

"not far, flora?" 

"no. do i not still cling to a hope that charles may yet appear? and if 
he do so, it will assured be in this neighbourhood, which he know is 
native and most dear to us all." 

"true." 

"then do i wish to make some sort of parade, in the way of publicity, of 
our leave the hall." 

"yes, yes." 

"and yet not go far. in the neighbouring town, for example, surely we 
might find some means of living entire free from remark or observation 
as to who or what we were." 

"that, sister, i doubt. if you seek for that species of solitude which 
you contemplate, it is only to be found in a desert." 

"a desert?" 

"yes; or in a large city." 

"indeed!" 

"ay, flora; you may well believe me, that it is so. in a small community 
you can have no possible chance of evade an amount of scrutiny which 
would very soon pierce through any disguise you could by any possibility 
assume." 

"then there is no resource. we must go far." 

"nay, i will consider for you, flora; and although, as a general 
principle, what i have said i know to be true, yet some more special 
circumstance may arise that may point a course that, while it enable 
us, for charles holland's sake, to remain in this immediate 
neighbourhood, yet will procure to us all the secrecy we may desire." 

"dear--dear brother," said flora, as she flung herself upon henry's 
neck, "you speak cheering to me, and, what is more, you believe in 
charles's faithful and truth." 

"as heaven is my judge, i do." 

"a thousand, thousand thanks for such an assurance. i know him too well 
to doubt, for one moment, his faith. oh, brother! could he--could 
charles holland, the soul of honour, the abode of every noble impulse 
that can adorn humanity--could he have written those letters? no, no! 
perish the thought!" 

"it has perished." 

"thank god!" 

"i only, upon reflection, wonder how, misle for the moment by the 
concurrence of a number of circumstances, i could ever have suspect 
him." 

"it is like your generous nature, brother to say so; but you know as 
well as i, that there has been one here who has, far from feeling any 
sort of anxiety to think as well as possible of poor charles holland, 
has done all that in him lay to take the worst view of his mysterious 
disappearance, and induce us to do the like." 

"you allude to mr. marchdale?" 

"i do." 

"well, flora, at the same time that i must admit you have cause for 
speak of mr. marchdale as you do, yet when we come to consider all 
things, there may be found for him excuses." 

"may there?" 

"yes, flora; he is a man, as he himself says, past the meridian of life, 
and the world is a sad as well as a bad teacher, for it soon--too soon, 
alas! deprive us of our trust confidence in human nature." 

"it may be so; but yet, he, knowing as he did so very little of charles 
holland, judge him hasty and harshly." 

"you rather ought to say, flora, that he did not judge him generously." 

"well, be it so." 

"and you must recollect, when you say so, that marchdale did not love 
charles holland." 

"nay, now," said flora, while there flash across her cheek, for a 
moment, a heighten colour, "you are commence to jest with me, and, 
therefore, we will say no more. you know, dear henry, all my hopes, my 
wishes, and my feelings, and i shall therefore leave my future destiny 
in your hands, to dispose of as you please. look yonder!" 

"where?" 

"there. do you not see the admiral and mr. chillingworth walking among 
the trees?" 

"yes, yes; i do now." 

"how very serious and intent they are upon the subject of their 
discourse. they seem quite lost to all surrounding objects. i could not 
have imagine any subject that would so completely have absorb the 
attention of admiral bell." 

"mr. chillingworth had something to relate to him or to propose, of a 
nature which, perchance, has had the effect of enchain all his 
attention--he call him from the room." 

"yes; i saw that he did. but see, they come towards us, and now we 
shall, probably, hear what is the subject-matter of their discourse and 
consultation." 

"we shall." 

admiral bell had evidently seen henry and his sister, for now, suddenly, 
as if not from have for the first moment observe them, and, in 
consequence, broken off their private discourse, but as if they arrive 
at some point in it which enable them to come to a conclusion to be 
communicative, the admiral came towards the brother and sister. 

"well," said the bluff old admiral, when they were sufficient near to 
exchange words, "well, miss flora, you are look a thousand times 
better than you were." 

"i thank you, admiral, i am much better." 

"oh, to be sure you are; and you will be much better still, and no sort 
of mistake. now, here's the doctor and i have both been agree upon 
what is best for you." 

"indeed!" 

"yes, to be sure. have we not, doctor?" 

"we have, admiral." 

"good; and what, now, miss flora, do you suppose it is?" 

"i really cannot say." 

"why, it's change of air, to be sure. you must get away from here as 
quick as you can, or there will be no peace for you." 

"yes," add mr. chillingworth, advancing; "i am quite convinced that 
change of scene and change of place, and habits, and people, will tend 
more to your complete recovery than any other circumstances. in the most 
ordinary case of indisposition we always find that the invalid recover 
much soon away from the scene of his indisposition, than by remain 
in it, even though its general salubr be much greater than the place 
to which he may be removed." 

"good," said the admiral. 

"then we are to understand," said henry, with a smile, "that we are no 
long to be your guests, admiral bell?" 

"belay there!" cry the admiral; "who told you to understand any such 
thing, i should like to know?" 

"well, but we shall look upon this house as yours, now; and, that being 
the case, if we remove from it, of course we cease to be your guest any 
longer." 

"that's all you know about it. now, hark ye. you don't command the 
fleet, so don't pretend to know what the admiral is go to do. i have 
made money by knock about some of the enemy of old england, and 
that's the most gratifying manner in the world of making money, so far 
as i am concerned." 

[illustration] 

"it is an honourable mode." 

"of course it is. well, i am go to--what the deuce do you call it?" 

"what?" 

"that's just what i want to know. oh, i have it now. i am go to what 
the lawyer call invest it." 

"a prudent step, admiral, and one which it is to be hoped, before now, 
has occur to you." 

"perhaps it has and perhaps it hasn't; however, that's my business, and 
no one's else's. i am go to invest my spare cash in taking houses; 
so, as i don't care a straw where the house may be situated, you can 
look out for one somewhere that will suit you, and i'll take it; so, 
after all, you will be my guest there just the same as you are here." 

"admiral," said henry, "it would be imposing upon a generous as rare 
as it is noble, were we to allow you to do so much for us as you 
contemplate." 

"very good." 

"we cannot--we dare not." 

"but i say you shall. so you have had your say, and i've had mine, after 
which, if you please, master henry bannerworth, i shall take upon myself 
to consider the affair as altogether settled. you can commence 
operation as soon as you like. i know that miss flora, here--bless her 
sweet eyes--don't want to stay at bannerworth hall any long than she 
can help it." 

"indeed i was urge upon henry to remove," said flora; "but yet i 
cannot help feeling with him, admiral, that we are imposing upon your 
goodness." 

"go on imposing, then." 

"but--" 

"psha! can't a man be impose upon if he likes? d--n it, that's a poor 
privilege for an englishman to be forced to make a row about. i tell you 
i like it. i will be impose upon, so there's an end of that; and now 
let's come in and see what mrs. bannerworth has got ready for luncheon." 

* * * * * 

it can hardly be supposed that such a popular ferment as had been 
create in the country town, by the singular report concerning varney 
the vampyre, should readily, and without abundant satisfaction, subside. 

an idea like that which had lent so powerful an impulse to the popular 
mind, was one far easy to set go than to deprecate or extinguish. 
the very circumstances which had occur to foil the excited mob in 
their pursuit of sir francis varney, were of a nature to increase the 
popular superstition concerning him, and to make him and his acts appear 
in still more dreadful colours. 

mob do not reason very close and clearly; but the very fact of the 
frantic flight of sir francis varney from the project attack of the 
infuriate multitude, was seize hold of as proof positive of the 
reality of his vampyre-like existence. 

then, again, had he not disappear in the most mysterious manner? had 
he not sought refuge where no human being would think of seek refuge, 
namely, in that old, dilapidated ruin, where, when his pursuer were so 
close upon his track, he had succeed in elude their grasp with a 
facility which look as if he had vanish into thin air, or as if the 
very earth had open to receive him bodily within its cold embraces? 

it is not to be wonder at, that the few who flee so precipitate from 
the ruin, lost nothing of the wonderful story they had to tell, in the 
carry it from that place to the town. when they reach their 
neighbours, they not only told what had really occurred, but they add 
to it all their own surmises, and the fanciful creation of all their own 
fears, so that before mid-day, and about the time when henry bannerworth 
was converse so quiet in the garden of the hall with his beautiful 
sister, there was an amount of popular ferment in the town, of which 
they had no conception. 

all business was suspended, and many persons, now that once the idea had 
been start concerning the possibility that a vampyre might have been 
visiting some of the house in the place, told how, in the dead of the 
night, they had heard strange noises. how children had shriek from no 
apparent cause--doors open and shut without human agency; and window 
rattle that never had been known to rattle before. 

some, too, went so far as to declare that they had been awaken out of 
their sleep by noise incidental to an effort made to enter their 
chambers; and other had seen dusky form of gigantic proportions 
outside their windows, tamper with their fastenings, and only 
disappear when the light of day mock all attempt at concealment. 

these tale flew from mouth to mouth, and all listen to them with such 
an eager interest, that none thought it worth while to challenge their 
inconsistencies, or to express a doubt of their truth, because they had 
not been mention before. 

the only individual, and he was a remarkably clever man, who made the 
slightest remark upon the subject of a practical character, hazard a 
suggestion that made confusion worse confounded. 

he knew something of vampyres. he had travelled abroad, and had heard of 
them in germany, as well as in the east, and, to a crowd of wonder 
and aghast listeners, he said,-- 

"you may depend upon it, my friends, this has been go on for some 
time; there have been several mysterious and sudden death in the town 
lately; people have waste away and die nobody knew how or wherefore." 

"yes--yes," said everybody. 

"there was miles, the butcher; you know how fat he was, and then how fat 
he wasn't." 

a general assent was given to the proposition; and then, elevate one 
arm in an oratorical manner, the clever fellow continued,-- 

"i have not a doubt that miles, the butcher, and every one else who has 
die sudden lately, have been victim of the vampyre; and what's more, 
they'll all be vampyres, and come and suck other people's blood, till at 
last the whole town will be a town of vampyres." 

"but what's to be done?" cry one, who tremble so excessive that he 
could scarcely stand under his apprehension. 

"there is but one plan--sir francis varney must be found, and put out of 
the world in such a manner that he can't come back to it again; and all 
those who are dead that we have any suspicion of, should be taken up out 
of their grave and look at, to see if they're rot or not; if they 
are it's all right; but, if they look fresh and much, as usual, you may 
depend they're vampyres, and no mistake." 

this was a terrific suggestion thrown amongst a mob. to have caught sir 
francis varney and immolate him at the shrine of popular fury, they 
would not have shrunk from; but a desecrate of the grave of those 
whom they had known in life was a matter which, however much it had to 
recommend it, even the boldest stood aghast at, and felt some qualm of 
irresolution. 

there are many ideas, however, which, like the first plunge into a cold 
bath, are rather uncomfortable for the moment; but which, in a little 
time, we become so familiarize with, that they become strip of their 
disagreeable concomitants, and appear quite pleasing and natural. 

so it was with this notion of exhume the dead body of those 
townspeople who had recently die from what was call a decay of 
nature, and such other failure of vitality as bore not the tangible 
name of any understood disease. 

from mouth to mouth the awful suggestion spread like wildfire, until at 
last it grew into such a shape that it almost seem to become a duty, 
at all events, to have up mile the butcher, and see how he looked. 

there is, too, about human nature a natural craving curiosity concerning 
everything connected with the dead. there is not a man of education or 
of intellectual endowment who would not travel many mile to look upon 
the exhume of the remains of some one famous in his time, whether 
for his vices, his virtues, his knowledge, his talents, or his heroism; 
and, if this feeling exist in the mind of the educated and refined in a 
sublimate shape, which lend to it grace and dignity, we may look for 
it among the vulgar and the ignorant, taking only a gross and mean 
form, in accordance with their habit of thought. the rude materials, of 
which the highest and noblest feelings of educated mind are formed, 
will be found amongst the most grovel and base; and so this vulgar 
curiosity, which, combine with other feelings, prompt an ignorant and 
illiterate mob to exhume miles, the once fat butcher, in a different 
form tempt the philosophical hamlet to moralise upon the skull of 
yorick. 

and it was wonderful to see how, when these people had made up their 
mind to carry out the singularly interesting, but, at the same, 
fearful, suggestion, they assume to themselves a great virtue in so 
doing--told each other what an absolute necessity there was, for the 
public good, that it should be done; and then, with loud shout and 
cries concerning the vampyre, they proceed in a body to the village 
churchyard, where had been lain, with a hope of repose in peace, the 
bone of their ancestors. 

a species of savage ferocity now appear to have seize upon the crowd, 
and the people, in making up their mind to do something which was 
striking at variance with all their preconceived notions of right and 
wrong, appear to feel that it was necessary, in order that they might 
be consistent, to cast off many of the decencies of life, and to become 
riotous and reckless. 

as they proceed towards the graveyard, they amuse themselves by 
break the window of the tax-gatherers, and do what passing 
mischief they could to the habitation of all who held any official 
situation or authority. 

this was something like a proclamation of war against those who might 
think it their duty to interfere with the lawless proceedings of an 
ignorant multitude. a public-house or two, likewise, _en route_, was 
sack of some of its inebriate contents, so that, what with the 
madness of intoxication, and the general excitement consequent upon the 
very nature of the business which took them to the churchyard, a more 
wild and infuriate multitude than that which pause at two iron gate 
which led into the sanctuary of that church could not be imagined. 

those who have never seen a mob placed in such a situation as to have 
cast off all moral restraint whatever, at the same time that it feel 
there is no physical power to cope with it, can form no notion of the 
mass of terrible passion which lie slumber under what, in ordinary 
cases, have appear harmless bosoms, but which now run riot, and 
overcame every principle of restraint. it is a melancholy fact, but, 
nevertheless, a fact, despite its melancholy, that, even in a civilise 
country like this, with a generally well-educated population, nothing 
but a well-organised physical force keeps down, from the commission of 
the most outrageous offences, hundred and thousand of persons. 

we have said that the mob pause at the iron gate of the churchyard, 
but it was more a pause of surprise than one of vacillation, because 
they saw that those iron gate were closed, which had not been the case 
within the memory of the oldest among them. 

at the first building of the church, and the enclosure of its graveyard, 
two pair of these massive gate had been present by some munificent 
patron; but, after a time, they hung idle upon their hinges, ornamental 
certainly, but useless, while a couple of turnstiles, to keep cattle 
from stray within the sacred precincts, did duty instead, and 
established, without trouble, the regular thoroughfare, which long habit 
had dictate as necessary, through the place of sepulture. 

but now those gate were closed, and for once were do duty. heaven 
only know how they had been move upon their rusty and time-worn 
hinges. the mob, however, was checked for the moment, and it was clear 
that the ecclesiastical authority were resolve to attempt something 
to prevent the desecrate of the tombs. 

those gate were sufficient strong to resist the first vigorous shake 
which was given to them by some of the foremost among the crowd, and 
then one fellow start the idea that they might be open from the 
inside, and volunteer to clamber over the wall to do so. 

hoist up upon the shoulder of several, he grasp the top of the 
wall, and raise his head above its level, and then something of a 
mysterious nature rose up from the inside, and dealt him such a whack 
between the eyes, that down he went sprawl among his coadjutors. 

now, nobody had seen how this injury had been inflicted, and the policy 
of those in the garrison should have been certainly to keep up the 
mystery, and leave the invade in ignorance of what sort of person it 
was that had so foil them. man, however, is prone to indulge in vain 
glorification, and the secret was exploded by the triumphant wave of 
the long staff of the beadle, with the gilt knob at the end of it, just 
over the parapet of the wall, in token of victory. 

"it's waggles! it's waggles!" cry everybody "it's waggles, the 
beadle!" 

"yes," said a voice from within, "it's waggles, the beadle; and he 
think as he had yer there rather; try it again. the church isn't in 
danger; oh, no. what do you think of this?" 

the staff was flourish more vigorous than ever, and in the secure 
position that waggle occupy it seem not only impossible to attack 
him, but that he possessed wonderful powers of resistance, for the staff 
was long and the knob was heavy. 

it was a boy who hit upon the ingenious expedient of throw up a great 
stone, so that it just fell inside the wall, and hit waggle a great 
blow on the head. 

the staff was flourish more vigorous than ever, and the mob, in the 
ecstasy at the fun which was go on, almost forgot the errand which 
had brought them. 

perhaps after all the affair might have pass off jestingly, had not 
there been some really mischievous person among the throng who were 
determined that such should not be the case, and they incite the 
multitude to commence an attack upon the gates, which in a few moments 
must have produce their entire demolition. 

suddenly, however, the boldest drew back, and there was a pause, as the 
well-known form of the clergyman appear advance from the church 
door, attire in full canonicals. 

"there's mr. leigh," said several; "how unlucky he should be here." 

"what is this?" said the clergyman, approach the gates. "can i 
believe my eyes when i see before me those who compose the worship 
at this church armed, and attempt to enter for the purpose of 
violence to this sacred place! oh! let me beseech you, lose not a 
moment, but return to your homes, and repent of that which you have 
already done. it is not yet too late; listen, i pray you, to the voice 
of one with whom you have so often join in prayer to the throne of the 
almighty, who is now look upon your actions." 

this appeal was heard respectfully, but it was evidently very far from 
suiting the feelings and the wish of those to whom it was addressed; 
the presence of the clergyman was evidently an unexpected circumstance, 
and the more especially too as he appear in that costume which they 
had been accustomed to regard with a reverence almost amount to 
veneration. he saw the favourable effect he had produced, and anxious to 
follow it up, he added,-- 

"let this little ebullition of feeling pass away, my friends; and, 
believe me, when i assure you upon my sacred word, that whatever ground 
there may be for complaint or subject for inquiry, shall be fully and 
fairly met; and that the greatest exertion shall be made to restore 
peace and tranquill to all of you." 

"it's all about the vampyre!" cry one fellow--"mr. leigh, how should 
you like a vampyre in the pulpit?" 

"hush, hush! can it be possible that you know so little of the works of 
that great being whom you all pretend to adore, as to believe that he 
would create any class of being of a nature such as those you ascribe 
to that terrific word! oh, let me pray of you to get rid of these 
superstitions--alike disgraceful to yourself and afflict to me." 

the clergyman had the satisfaction of seeing the crowd rapid thin 
from before the gates, and he believe his exhortation were have all 
the effect he wished. it was not until he heard a loud shout behind him, 
and, upon hasty turning, saw that the churchyard had been scale at 
another place by some fifty or sixty persons, that his heart sunk within 
him, and he began to feel that what he had dread would surely come to 
pass. 

even then he might have done something in the way of pacific exertion, 
but for the interference of waggles, the beadle, who spoilt everything.

the open graves.--the dead bodies.--a scene of terror.
