we have said waggle spoilt everything, and so he did, for before mr. 
leigh could utter a word more, or advance two steps towards the rioters, 
waggle charged them staff in hand, and there soon ensue a riot of a 
most formidable description. 

a kind of desperation seem to have seize the beadle, and certainly, 
by his sudden and unexpected attack, he achieve wonders. when, however, 
a dozen hand got hold of the staff, and it was wrench from him, and 
he was knock down, and half-a-dozen people roll over him, waggle 
was not near the man he had been, and he would have been very well 
content to have lain quiet where he was; this, however, he was not 
permit to do, for two or three, who had felt what a weighty 
instrument of warfare the parochial staff was, lift him bodily from 
the ground, and cant him over the wall, without much regard to whether 
he fell on a hard or a soft place on the other side. 

this feat accomplished, no further attention was paid to mr. leigh, who, 
finding that his exhortation were quite unheeded, retired into the 
church with an appearance of deep affliction about him, and lock 
himself in the vestry. 

the crowd now had entire possession--without even the sort of control 
that an exhortation assume over them--of the burying-ground, and soon 
in a dense mass were these desperate and excited people collected round 
the well-known spot where lay the mortal remains of miles, the butcher. 

"silence!" cry a loud voice, and every one obey the mandate, look 
towards the speaker, who was a tall, gaunt-looking man, attire in a 
suit of fade black, and who now pressed forward to the front of the 
throng. 

"oh!" cry one, "it's fletcher, the ranter. what do he do here?" 

"hear him! hear him!" cry others; "he won't stop us." 

"yes, hear him," cry the tall man, wave his arms about like the 
sail of a windmill. "yes, hear him. son of darkness, you're all 
vampyres, and are continual suck the life-blood from each other. no 
wonder that the evil one has power over you all. you're as men who walk 
in the dark when the sunlight invite you, and you listen to the 
words of humanity when those of a diviner origin are offer to your 
acceptance. but there shall be miracle in the land, and even in this 
place, set apart with a pretended piety that is in itself most damnable, 
you shall find an evidence of the true light; and the proof that those 
who will follow me the true path to glory shall be found here within 
this grave. dig up miles, the butcher!" 

"hear, hear, hear, hurra!" said every body. "mr. fletcher's not such a 
fool, after all. he means well." 

"yes, you sinners," said the ranter, "and if you find miles, the 
butcher, decaying--even as men are expect to decay whose mortal 
tabernacle are placed within the bowels of the earth--you shall gather 
from that a great omen, and a sign that if you follow me you seek the 
lord; but i you find him look fresh and healthy, as if the warm blood 
was still within his veins, you shall take that likewise as a 
signification that what i say to you shall be as the gospel, and that by 
coming to the chapel of the little boozlehum, ye shall achieve a great 
salvation." 

"very good," said a brawny fellow, advance with a spade in his hand; 
"you get out of the way, and i'll soon have him up. here goes, like blue 
blazes!" 

the first shovelful of earth he took up, he cast over his head into the 
air, so that it fell in a shower among the mob, which of course raise a 
shout of indignation; and, as he continue so to dispose of the 
superfluous earth, a general row seem likely to ensue. mr. fletcher 
open his mouth to make a remark, and, as that feature of his face was 
rather a capacious one, a descend lump of mould, of a clayey 
consistency, fell into it, and got so wedged among his teeth, that in 
the process of extract it he nearly brought some of those essential 
portion of his anatomy with it. 

this was a state of things that could not last long, and he who had been 
so liberal with his spadesful of mould was speedy disarmed, and yet he 
was a popular favourite, and had done the thing so good-humouredly, that 
nobody touched him. six or eight others, who had brought spade and 
pickaxes, now pushed forward to the work, and in an incredible short 
space of time the grave of miles, the butcher, seem to be very nearly 
excavated. 

work of any kind or nature whatever, is speedy execute when done with 
a wish to get through it; and never, perhaps, within the memory of man, 
was a grave open in that churchyard with such a wonderful celerity. 
the excitement of the crowd grew intense--every available spot from 
which a view of the grave could be got, was occupied; for the last few 
minutes scarcely a remark had been uttered, and when, at last, the spade 
of one of those who were digging struck upon something that sound like 
wood, you might have heard a pin drop, and each one there present drew 
his breath more shortly than before. 

"there he is," said the man, whose spade struck upon the coffin. 

those few words broke the spell, and there was a general murmur, while 
every individual present seem to shift his position in his anxiety to 
obtain a better view of what was about to ensue. 

the coffin now have been once found, there seem to be an increase 
impetus given to the work; the earth was thrown out with a rapid that 
seem almost the quick result of the working of some machine; and those 
closest to the grave's brink crouch down, and, intent as they were 
upon the progress of events, heed not the damp earth that fell upon 
them, nor the frail brittle and humid remains of humanity that 
occasional roll to their feet. 

it was, indeed, a scene of intense excitement--a scene which only want 
a few prominent features in its foreground of a more intellectual and 
higher cast than compose the mob, to make it a fit theme for a painter 
of the highest talent. 

and now the last few shovelful of earth that hid the top of the coffin 
were cast from the grave, and that narrow house which contained the 
mortal remains of him who was so well known, while in life, to almost 
every one then present, was brought to the gaze of eyes which never had 
seem likely to have look upon him again. 

the cry was now for ropes, with which to raise the cumbrous mass; but 
these were not to be had, no one thought of providing himself with such 
appliances, so that by main strength, only, could the coffin be raise 
to the brink. 

the difficulty of do this was immense, for there was nothing tangible 
to stand upon; and even when the mould from the side was sufficient 
clear away, that the handle of the coffin could be laid hold of, they 
came away immediately in the grasp of those who did so. 

but the more trouble that present itself to the accomplishment of the 
designs of the mob, the more intent that body seem upon carry out 
to the full extent their original designs. 

finding it quite impossible by bodily strength to raise the coffin of 
the butcher from the position in which it had got imbed by excessive 
rains, a boy was hasty despatch to the village for ropes, and never 
did boy run with such speed before, for all his own curiosity was 
excited in the issue of an adventure, that to his young imagination was 
appalling interesting. 

as impatient as mob usually are, they had not time, in this case, for 
the exercise of that quality of mind before the boy came back with the 
necessary means of exert quite a different species of power against 
the butcher's coffin. 

strong ropes were slid under the inert mass, and twenty hand at once 
ply the task of raise that receptacle of the dead from what had been 
presume to be its last resting-place. the ropes strained and creaked, 
and many thought that they would burst asunder soon than raise the 
heavy coffin of the defunct butcher. 

it is singular what reason people find for backing their opinion. 

"you may depend he's a vampyre," said one, "or it wouldn't be so 
difficult to get him out of the grave." 

"oh, there can be no mistake about that," said one; "when did a natural 
christian's coffin stick in the mud in that way?" 

"ah, to be sure," said another; "i knew no good would come of his goings 
on; he never was a decent sort of man like his neighbours, and many 
queer things have been said of him that i have no doubt are true enough, 
if we did but know the rights of them." 

"ah, but," said a young lad, thrust his head between the two who were 
talking, "if he is a vampyre, how do he get out of his coffin of a 
night with all that weight of mould a top of him?" 

one of the men considered for a moment, and then finding no rational 
answer occur to him, he gave the boy a box on the ear, saying,-- 

"i should like to know what business that is of yours? boys, now-a-days, 
ain't like the boys in my time; they think nothing now of putt their 
spoke in grown-up people's wheels, just as if their opinion were of 
any consequence." 

now, by a vigorous effort, those who were tug at the ropes succeed 
in moving the coffin a little, and that first step was all the 
difficulty, for it was loosen from the adhesive soil in which it lay, 
and now came up with considerable facility. 

there was a half shout of satisfaction at this result, while some of the 
congregation turn pale, and tremble at the prospect of the sight 
which was about to present itself; the coffin was drag from the 
grave's brink fairly among the long rank grass that flourish in the 
churchyard, and then they all look at it for a time, and the men who 
had been most earnest in raise it wipe the perspiration from their 
brows, and seem to shrink from the task of opening that receptacle of 
the dead now that it was fairly in their power so to do. 

each man look anxious in his neighbour's face, and several audible 
wonder why somebody else didn't open the coffin. 

"there's no harm in it," said one; "if he's a vampyre, we ought to know 
it; and, if he ain't, we can't do any hurt to a dead man." 

"oughtn't we to have the service for the dead?" said one. 

"yes," said the impertinent boy who had before received the knock on the 
head, "i think we ought to have that read backwards." 

this ingenious idea was recompense by a great many kicks and cuffs, 
which ought to have been sufficient to have warn him of the great 
danger of being a little before his age in wit. 

"where's the use of shirk the job?" cry he who had been so active 
in shovel the mud upon the multitude; "why, you cowardly sneaking set 
of humbugs, you're half afraid, now." 

"afraid--afraid!" cry everybody: "who's afraid." 

"ah, who's afraid?" said a little man, advancing, and assume an heroic 
attitude; "i always notice, if anybody's afraid, it's some big fellow, 
with more bone than brains." 

at this moment, the man to whom this reproach was more particularly 
levelled, raise a horrible shout of terror, and cry out, in frantic 
accents,-- 

"he's a-coming--he's a-coming!" 

the little man fell at once into the grave, while the mob, with one 
accord, turn tail, and flee in all directions, leave him alone with 
the coffin. such a fighting, and kicking, and scramble ensue to get 
over the wall of the grave-yard, that this great fellow, who had cause 
all the mischief, burst into such peal of laughter that the majority of 
the people became aware that it was a joke, and came creep back, 
look as sheepish as possible. 

some got up very faint sort of laugh, and said "very good," and swore 
they saw what big dick meant from the first, and only ran to make the 
other run. 

"very good," said dick, "i'm glad you enjoy it, that's all. my eye, 
what a scamper there was among you. where's my little friend, who was 
so infernal cunning about bone and brains?" 

with some difficulty the little man was extricate from the grave, and 
then, oh, for the consistency of a mob! they all laugh at him; those 
very people who, heedless of all the amenity of existence, had been 
trample upon each other, and roaring with terror, actually had the 
impudence to laugh at him, and call him a cowardly little rascal, and 
say it serve him right. 

but such is popularity! 

"well, if nobody won't open the coffin," said big dick, "i will, so here 
goes. i know the old fellow when he was alive, and many a time he's 
d----d me and i've d----d him, so i ain't a-going to be afraid of him 
now he's dead. we was very intimate, you see, 'cos we was the two 
heaviest men in the parish; there's a reason for everything." 

"ah, dick's the fellow to do it," cry a number of persons; "there's 
nobody like dick for opening a coffin; he's the man as don't care for 
nothing." 

"ah, you snivel curs," said dick, "i hate you. if it warn't for my 
own satisfaction, and all for to prove that my old friend, the butcher, 
as weigh seventeen stone, and stood six feet two and-a-half on his own 
sole, i'd see you all jolly well--" 

"d----d first," said the boy; "open the lid, dick, let's have a look." 

"ah, you're a rum un," said dick, "arter my own heart. i sometimes 
think as you must be a nevy, or some sort of relation of mine. 
howsomdever, here goes. who'd a thought that i should ever had a look at 
old fat and thunder again?--that's what i use to call him; and then he 
use to request me to go down below, where i needn't turn round to light 
my blessed pipe." 

"hell--we know," said the boy; "why don't you open the lid, dick?" 

"i'm a going," said dick; "kim up." 

he introduce the corner of a shovel between the lid and the coffin, and 
give it a sudden wrench, he loosen it all down one side. 

a shudder pervade the multitude, and, popularly speaking, you might 
have heard a pin drop in that crowded churchyard at that eventful 
moment. 

dick then proceed to the other side, and execute the same manoeuvre. 

"now for it," he said; "we shall see him in a moment, and we'll think we 
seed him still." 

"what a lark!" said the boy. 

"you hold yer jaw, will yer? who axed you for a remark, blow yer? what 
do you mean by squat down there, like a cock-sparrow, with a pain in 
his tail, hanging yer head, too, right over the coffin? did you never 
hear of what they call a fluvifium coming from the dead, yer ignorant 
beast, as is enough to send nobody to blazes in a minute? get out of the 
way of the cold meat, will yer?" 

"a what, do you say, dick?" 

"request information from the extreme point of my elbow." 

dick threw down the spade, and lay hold of the coffin-lid with both 
hands, he lift it off, and flung it on one side. 

there was a visible movement and an exclamation among the multitude. 
some were pushed down, in the eager desire of those behind to obtain a 
sight of the ghastly remains of the butcher; those at a distance were 
frantic, and the excitement was momentarily increasing. 

they might all have spare themselves the trouble, for the coffin was 
empty--here was no dead butcher, nor any evidence of one ever have 
been there, not even the grave-clothes; the only thing at all in the 
receptacle of the dead was a brick. 

dick's astonishment was so intense that his eyes and mouth kept opening 
together to such an extent, that it seem doubtful when they would 
reach their extreme point of elongation. he then took up the brick and 
look at it curiously, and turn it over and over, examine the end 
and the side with a critical eye, and at length he said,-- 

"well, i'm blowed, here's a transmogrification; he's consolidify 
himself into a blessed brick--my eye, here's a curiosity." 

"but you don't mean to say that's the butcher, dick?" said the boy. 

dick reach over, and gave him a tap on the head with the brick. 

"there!" he said, "that's what i call occular demonstration. do you 
believe it now, you blessed infidel? what's more natural? he was an 
out-and-out brick while he was alive; and he's turn to a brick now 
he's dead." 

"give it to me, dick," said the boy; "i should like to have that brick, 
just for the fun of the thing." 

"i'll see you turn into a pantile first. i sha'n't part with this 
here, it looks so blessed sensible; it's a gain on me every minute as 
a most remarkable likeness, d----d if it ain't." 

by this time the bewilder of the mob had subsided; now that there 
was no dead butcher to look upon, they fancy themselves most 
grievous injured; and, somehow or other, dick, notwithstanding all his 
exertion in their service, was look upon in the light of a showman, 
who had promise some startle exhibition and then had disappointed his 
auditors. 

the first intimate he had of popular vengeance was a stone thrown at 
him, but dick's eye happen to be upon the fellow who threw it, and 
collar him in a moment, he dealt him a cuff on the side of the head, 
which confuse his faculty for a week. 

"hark ye," he then cried, with a loud voice, "don't interfere with me; 
you know it won't go down. there's something wrong here; and, as one of 
yourselves, i'm as much interested in finding out what it is as any of 
you can possibly be. there seem to be some truth in this vampyre 
business; our old friend, the butcher, you see, is not in his grave; 
where is he then?" 

the mob look at each other, and none attempt to answer the question. 

"why, of course, he's a vampyre," said dick, "and you may all of you 
expect to see him, in turn, come into your bed-room window with a 
burst, and lay hold of you like a million and a half of leech roll 
into one." 

there was a general expression of horror, and then dick continued,-- 

"you'd better all of you go home; i shall have no hand in pull up any 
more of the coffins--this is a dose for me. of course you can do what 
you like." 

[illustration] 

"pull them all up!" cry a voice; "pull them all up! let's see how many 
vampyre there are in the churchyard." 

"well, it's no business of mine," said dick; "but i wouldn't, if i was 
you." 

"you may depend," said one, "that dick know something about it, or he 
wouldn't take it so easy." 

"ah! down with him," said the man who had received the box on the ears; 
"he's perhaps a vampyre himself." 

the mob made a demonstration towards him, but dick stood his ground, and 
they pause again. 

"now, you're a cowardly set," he said; "cause you're disappointed, you 
want to come upon me. now, i'll just show what a little thing will 
frighten you all again, and i warn beforehand it will, so you sha'n't 
say you didn't know it, and were taken by surprise." 

the mob look at him, wonder what he was go to do. 

"once! twice! thrice!" he said, and then he flung the brick up into the 
air an immense height, and shout "heads," in a loud tone. 

a general dispersion of the crowd ensued, and the brick fell in the 
centre of a very large circle indeed. 

"there you are again," said dick; "why, what a nice act you are!" 

"what fun!" said the boy. "it's a famous coffin, this, dick," and he 
laid himself down in the butcher's last resting-place. "i never was in a 
coffin before--it's snug enough." 

"ah, you're a rum 'un," said dick; "you're such a inquiring genius, you 
is; you'll get your head into some hole one day, and not be able to get 
it out again, and then i shall see you a kicking. hush! lay still--don't 
say anything." 

"good again," said the boy; "what shall i do?" 

"give a sort of a howl and a squeak, when they've all come back again." 

"won't i!" said the boy; "pop on the lid." 

"there you are," said dick; "d----d if i don't adopt you, and bring you 
up to the science of nothing." 

"now, listen to me, good people all," add dick; "i have really got 
something to say to you." 

at this intimate the people slow gather again round the grave. 

"listen," said dick, solemnly; "it strike me there's some tremendous do 
go on." 

"yes, there is," said several who were foremost. 

"it won't be long before you'll all of you be most d--nably astonished; 
but let me beg of all you not to accuse me of have anything to do with 
it, provided i tell you all i know." 

"no, dick; we won't--we won't--we won't." 

"good; then, listen. i don't know anything, but i'll tell you what i 
think, and that's as good; i don't think that this brick is the butcher; 
but i think, that when you least expect it--hush! come a little closer." 

"yes, yes; we are closer." 

"well, then, i say, when you all least expect it, and when you ain't 
dream of such a thing, you'll hear something of my fat friend as is 
dead and gone, that will astonish you all." 

dick paused, and he gave the coffin a slight kick, as intimate to the 
boy that he might as well be do his part in the drama, upon which 
that ingenious young gentleman set up such a howl, that even dick 
jumped, so unearthly did it sound within the confines of that receptacle 
of the dead. 

but if the effect upon him was great, what must it have been upon those 
whom it took completely unawares? for a moment or two they seem 
completely paralysed, and then they frightened the boy, for the shout of 
terror that rose from so many throat at once was positively alarming. 

this jest of dick's was final, for, before three minutes had elapsed, 
the churchyard was clear of all human occupant save himself and the 
boy, who had play his part so well in the coffin. 

"get out," said dick, "it's all right--we've done 'em at last; and now 
you may depend upon it they won't be in a hurry to come here again. you 
keep your own counsel, or else somebody will serve you out for this. i 
don't think you're altogether averse to a bit of fun, and if you keep 
yourself quiet, you'll have the satisfaction of hearing what's said 
about this affair in every pot-house in the village, and no mistake." 




chapter xlvi. 

the preparation for leave bannerworth hall, and the mysterious 
conduct of the admiral and mr. chillingworth. 


[illustration] 

it seem now, that, by the concurrence of all parties, bannerworth hall 
was to be abandoned; and, notwithstanding henry was loth--as he had, 
indeed, from the first shown himself--to leave the ancient abode of his 
race, yet, as not only flora, but the admiral and his friend mr. 
chillingworth seem to be of opinion that it would be a prudent course 
to adopt, he felt that it would not become him to oppose the measure. 

he, however, now made his consent to depend wholly upon the full and 
free acquiesce of every member of the family. 

"if," he said, "there be any among us who will say to me 'continue to 
keep open the house in which we have pass so many happy hours, and let 
the ancient home of our race still afford a shelter to us,' i shall feel 
myself bound to do so; but if both my mother and my brother agree to a 
departure from it, and that its hearth shall be left cold and desolate, 
be it so. i will not stand in the way of any unanimous wish or 
arrangement." 

"we may consider that, then, as settled," said the admiral, "for i have 
spoken to your brother, and he is of our opinion. therefore, my boy, we 
may all be off as soon as we can convenient get under weigh." 

"but my mother? 

"oh, there, i don't know. you must speak to her yourself. i never, if i 
can help it, interfere with the women folks." 

"if she consent, then i am willing." 

"will you ask her?" 

"i will not ask her to leave, because i know, then, what answer she 
would at once give; but she shall hear the proposition, and i will leave 
her to decide upon it, unbiased in her judgment by any state opinion of 
mine upon the matter." 

"good. that'll do; and the proper way to put it, too. there's no mistake 
about that, i can tell you." 

henry, although he went through the ceremony of consulting his mother, 
had no sort of doubt before he did so that she was sufficient aware of 
the feelings and wish of flora to be prepared to yield a ready assent 
to the proposition of leave the hall. 

moreover, mr. marchdale had, from the first, been an advocate of such a 
course of proceeding, and henry well knew how strong an influence he had 
over mrs. bannerworth's mind, in consequence of the respect in which she 
held him as an old and value friend. 

he was, therefore, prepared for what his mother said, which was,-- 

"my dear henry, you know that the wish of my children, since they have 
been grown up and capable of coming to a judgment for themselves, have 
ever been law to me. if you, among you all, agree to leave this place, 
do so." 

"but will you leave it freely, mother?" 

"most freely i go with you all; what is it that has made this house and 
all its appurtenance pleasant in my eyes, but the presence in it of 
those who are so dear to me? if you all leave it, you take with you the 
only charm it ever possessed; so it become in itself as nothing. i am 
quite ready to accompany you all anywhere, so that we do but keep 
together." 

"then, mother, we may consider that as settled." 

"as you please." 

"'it's scarcely as i please. i must confess that i would fain have clung 
with a kind of superstitious reverence to this ancient abiding-place of 
my race, but it may not be so. those, perchance, who are more 
practically able to come to correct conclusions, in consequence of their 
feelings not being sufficient interested to lead them astray, have 
decided otherwise; and, therefore, i am content to leave." 

"do not grieve at it, henry. there has hung a cloud of misfortune over 
us all since the garden of this house became the scene of an event which 
we can none of us remember but with terror and shuddering." 

"two generation of our family must live and die before the remembrance 
of that circumstance can be obliterated. but we will think of it no 
more." 

there can no doubt but that the dreadful circumstance to which both mrs. 
bannerworth and henry alluded, was the suicide of the father of the 
family in the garden which before has been hint at in the course of 
this narration, as being a circumstance which had create a great 
sensation at the time, and cast a great gloom for many month over the 
family. 

the reader will, doubtless, too, recollect that, at his last moments, 
this unhappy individual was said to have utter some incoherent words 
about some hidden money, and that the rapid hand of death alone seem 
to prevent him from being explicit upon that subject, and left it merely 
a matter of conjecture. 

as years had roll on, this affair, even as a subject of speculation, 
had cease to occupy the mind of any of the bannerworth family, and 
several of their friends, among whom was mr. marchdale, were decidedly 
of opinion that the apparently pointed and mysterious words uttered, 
were but the disorder wanderings of an intellect already hover on 
the confines of eternity. 

indeed, far from any money, of any amount, being a disturbance to the 
last moments of the dissolute man, whose vice and extravagance had 
brought his family, to such ruin, it was pretty generally believe that 
he had committed suicide simply from a conviction of the impossible 
of raise any more supplies of cash, to enable him to carry on the 
career which he had pursue for so long. 

but to resume. 

henry at once communicate to the admiral what his mother had said, and 
then the whole question regarding the removal being settled in the 
affirmative, nothing remain to be done but to set about it as quick 
as possible. 

the bannerworth live sufficient distant from the town to be out of 
earshot of the disturbance which were then taking place; and so 
completely isolated were they from all sort of society, that they had no 
notion of the popular disturbance which varney the vampyre had given 
rise to. 

it was not until the following morning that mr. chillingworth, who had 
been home in the meantime, brought word of what had taken place, and 
that great commotion was still in the town, and that the civil 
authorities, finding themselves by far too weak to contend against the 
popular will, had sent for assistance to a garrison town, some twenty 
mile distant. 

it was a great grief to the bannerworth family to hear these tidings, 
not that they were in any way, except as victims, accessory to create 
the disturbance about the vampyre, but it seem to promise a kind of 
notoriety which they might well shrink from, and which they were just 
the people to view with dislike. 

view the matter how we like, however, it is not to be considered as at 
all probable that the bannerworth family would remain long in ignorance 
of what a great sensation they had create unwitting in the 
neighbourhood. 

the very reason which had induce their servant to leave their 
establishment, and prefer throw themselves completely out of place, 
rather than remain in so ill-omened a house, were sure to be bruit 
abroad far and wide. 

and that, perhaps, when they came to consider of it, would suffice to 
form another good and substantial reason for leave the hall, and 
seek a refuge in obscurity from the extremely troublesome sort of 
popularity incidental to their peculiar situation. 

mr. chillingworth felt uncommonly chary of telling them all that had 
taken place; although he was well aware that the proceedings of the 
riotous mob had not terminate with the little disappointment at the old 
ruin, to which they had so effectually chase varney the vampyre, but to 
lose him so singularly when he got there. 

no doubt he possessed the admiral with the uproar that was go on in 
the town, for the latter did hint a little of it to henry bannerworth. 

"hilloa!" he said to henry, as he saw him walking in the garden; "it 
strike me if you and your ship's crew continue in these latitudes, 
you'll get as notorious as the flying dutchman in the southern ocean." 

"how do you mean?" said henry. 

"why, it's a sure go proverb to say, that a nod's as good as a wink; 
but, the fact is, it's get rather too well known to be pleasant, 
that a vampyre has struck up rather a close acquaintance with your 
family. i understand there's a precious row in the town." 

"indeed!" 

"yes; bother the particulars, for i don't know them; but, hark ye, by 
to-morrow i'll have found a place for you to go to, so pack up the 
sticks, get all your stores ready to clear out, and make yourself scarce 
from this place." 

"i understand you," said henry; "we have become the subject of popular 
rumour; i've only to beg of you, admiral, that you'll say nothing of 
this to flora; she has already suffer enough, heaven knows; do not let 
her have the additional infliction of thinking that her name is made 
familiar in every pothouse in the town." 

"leave me alone for that," said the admiral. "do you think i'm an ass?" 

"ay, ay," said jack pringle, who came in at that moment, and thought the 
question was address to him. 

"who spoke to you, you bad-looking horse-marine?" 

"me a horse-marine! didn't you ask a plain question of a fellow, and get 
a plain answer?" 

"why, you son of a bad look gun, what do you mean by that? i tell you 
what it is, jack; i've let you come sneaking too often on the 
quarter-deck, and now you come poke your fun at your officers, you 
rascal!" 

"i poke fun!" said jack; "couldn't think of such a thing. i should 
just as soon think of you making a joke as me." 

"now, i tell you what it is, i shall just strike you off the ship's 
books, and you shall just go and cruise by yourself; i've done with 
you." 

"go and tell that to the marines, if you like," said jack. "i ain't done 
with you yet, for a jolly long watch. why, what do you suppose would 
become of you, you great babby, without me? ain't i always a convey 
you from place to place, and steer you through all sort of 
difficulties?" 

"d---n your impudence!" 

"well, then, d---n yours." 

"shiver my timbers!" 

"ay, you may do what you like with your own timbers." 

"and you won't leave me?" 

"sartingly not." 

"come here, then?" 

jack might have expect a gratuity, for he advanced with alacrity. 

"there," said the admiral, as he laid his stick across his shoulders; 
"that's your last month's wages; don't spend it all at once." 

"well, i'm d----d!" said jack; "who'd have thought of that?--he's a 
turning rumgumtious, and no mistake. howsomdever, i must turn it over in 
my mind, and be even with him, somehow--i owe him one for that. i say, 
admiral." 

"what now, you lubber?" 

"nothing; turn that over in your mind;" and away jack walked, not quite 
satisfied, but feeling, at least, that he had made a demonstration of 
attack. 

as for the admiral, he considered that the thump he had given jack with 
the stick, and it was no gentle one, was a decided balance of account 
up to that period, and as he remain likewise master of the field, he 
was upon the whole very well satisfied. 

these last few words which had been spoken to henry by admiral bell, 
more than any others, induce him to hasten his departure from 
bannerworth hall; he had walk away when the altercation between jack 
pringle and the admiral began, for he had seen sufficient of those wordy 
conflict between those original to be quite satisfy that neither of 
them meant what he said of a discourage character towards the other, 
and that far from there being any unfriend feeling contingent upon 
those little affairs, they were only a species of friendly sparring, 
which both party enjoy extremely. 

he went direct to flora, and he said to her,-- 

"since we are all agree upon the necessity, or, at all events, upon the 
expediency of a departure from the hall, i think, sister, the soon we 
carry out that determination the better and the pleasant for us all it 
will be. do you think you could remove so hasty as to-morrow?" 

"to-morrow! that is soon indeed." 

"i grant you that it is so; but admiral bell assure me that he will 
have everything in readiness, and a place provided for us to go to by 
then." 

"would it be possible to remove from a house like this so very quickly?" 

"yes, sister. if you look around you, you will see that a great portion 
of the comfort you enjoy in this mansion belong to it as a part of its 
very structure, and are not remove at pleasure; what we really have 
to take away is very little. the urgent want of money during our 
father's lifetime induce him, as you may recollect even, at various 
times to part with much that was ornamental, as well as useful, which 
was in the hall. you will recollect that we seldom return from those 
little continental tour which to us were so delightful, without finding 
some old familiar object gone, which, upon inquiry, we found had been 
turn into money, to meet some more than usually pressing demand." 

"that is true, brother; i recollect well." 

"so that, upon the whole, sister, there is little to remove." 

"well, well, be it so. i will prepare our mother for this sudden step. 
believe me, my heart go with it; and as a force of vengeful 
circumstances have induce us to remove from this home, which was once 
so full of pleasant recollections, it is certainly better, as you say, 
that the act should be at once consummated, than left hanging in terror 
over our minds." 

"then i'll consider that as settled," said henry.

the removal from the hall.--the night watch, and the alarm. 


[illustration] 

mrs. bannerworth's consent have been already given to the removal, she 
said at once, when appeal to, that she was quite ready to go at any 
time her children thought expedient. 

upon this, henry sought the admiral, and told him as much, at the same 
time adding,-- 

"my sister fear that we should have considerable trouble in the 
removal, but i have convinced her that such will not be the case, as we 
are by no means overburden with cumbrous property." 

"cumbrous property," said the admiral, "why, what do you mean? i beg 
leave to say, that when i took the house, i took the table and chair 
with it. d--n it, what good do you suppose an empty house is to me?" 

"the table and chairs!" 

"yes. i took the house just as it stands. don't try and bamboozle me out 
of it. i tell you, you've nothing to move but yourself and immediate 
personal effects." 

"i was not aware, admiral, that that was your plan." 

"well, then, now you are, listen to me. i've circumvent the enemy too 
often not to know how to get up a plot. jack and i have manage it all. 
to-morrow evening, after dark, and before the moon's got high enough to 
throw any light, you and your brother, and miss flora and your mother, 
will come out of the house, and jack and i will lead you where you're to 
go to. there's plenty of furniture where you're a-going, and so you will 
get off free, without anybody knowing anything about it." 

"well, admiral, i've said it before, and it is the unanimous opinion of 
us all, that everything should be left to you. you have prove yourself 
too good a friend to us for us to hesitate at all in obey your 
commands. arrange everything, i pray you, according to your wish and 
feelings, and you will find there shall be no cavil on our parts." 

"that's right; there's nothing like give a command to some one person. 
there's no good done without. now i'll manage it all. mind you, seven 
o'clock to-morrow evening everything is to be ready, and you will all be 
prepared to leave the hall." 

"it shall be so." 

"who's that give such a thundering ring at the gate?" 

"nay, i know not. we have few visitor and no servants, so i must e'en 
be my own gate porter." 

henry walk to the gate, and have open it, a servant in a handsome 
livery step a pace or two into the garden. 

"well," said henry. 

"is mr. henry bannerworth within, or admiral bell?" 

"both," cry the admiral. "i'm admiral bell, and this is mr. henry 
bannerworth. what do you want with us, you d----d gingerbread-looking 
flunkey?" 

"sir, my master desire his compliments--his very best compliments--and 
he wants to know how you are after your flurry." 

"what?" 

"after your--a--a--flurry and excitement." 

"who is your master?" said henry. 

"sir francis varney." 

"the devil!" said the admiral; "if that don't beat all the impudence i 
ever came near. our flurry! ah! i like that fellow. just go and tell 
him--" 

"no, no," said henry, interposing, "send back no message. say to your 
master, fellow, that mr. henry bannerworth feel that not only has he no 
claim to sir francis varney's courtesy, but that he would rather be 
without it." 

"oh, ha!" said the footman, adjust his collar; "very good. this seem 
a d----d, old-fashioned, outlandish place of yours. any ale?" 

"now, shiver my hulks!" said the admiral. 

"hush! hush!" said henry; "who know but there may be a design in this? 
we have no ale." 

"oh, ah! dem!--dry as dust, by god! what do the old commodore say? any 
message, my ancient greek?" 

"no, thank you," said the admiral; "bless you, nothing. what did you 
give for that waistcoat, d--n you? ha! ha! you're a clever fellow." 

"ah! the old gentleman's ill. however, i'll take back his compliments, 
and that he's much oblige at sir francis's condescension. at the same 
time, i suppose may place in my eye what i may get out of either of you, 
without hinder me seeing my way back. ha! ha! adieu--adieu." 

"bravo!" said the admiral; "that's it--go it--now for it. d--n it, it is 
a _do!_" 

the admiral's calm during the latter part of the dialogue arose from 
the fact that over the flunkey's shoulder, and at some little distance 
off, he saw jack pringle taking off his jacket, and rolling up his 
sleeve in that deliberate sort of way that seem to imply a 
determination of setting about some species of work that combine the 
pleasant with the useful. 

jack execute many nod to and wink at the livery-servant, and jerk 
his thumb likewise in the direction of a pump near at hand, in a manner 
that spoke as plainly as possible, that john was to be pump upon. 

and now the conference was ended, and sir francis's messenger turn to 
go; but jack pringle bother him completely, for he dance round him in 
such a singular manner, that, turn which way he would, there stood jack 
pringle, in some grotesque attitude, intercept him; and so he edge 
him on, till he got him to the pump. 

"jack," said the admiral. 

"ay, ay, sir." 

"don't pump on that fellow now." 

"ay, ay, sir; give us a hand." 

jack laid hold of him by the two ears, and holding him under the pump, 
kick his shin until he completely gather himself beneath the spout. 
it was in vain that he shout "murder! help! fire! thieves!" jack was 
inexorable, and the admiral pumped. 

jack turn the fellow's head about in a very scientific manner, so as 
to give him a fair dose of hydropathic treatment, and in a few minutes, 
never was human being more thorough saturate with moisture than was 
sir francis varney's servant. he had left off hallooe for aid, for he 
found that whenever he did so, jack held his mouth under the spout, 
which was decidedly unpleasant; so, with a patience that look like 
heroic fortitude, he was compel to wait until the admiral was tired 
of pumping. 

"very good," at length he said. "now, jack, for fear this fellow catcher 
cold, be so good as to get a horsewhip, and see him off the premises 
with it." 

"ay, ay, sir," said jack. "and i say, old fellow, you can take back all 
our blessed compliments now, and say you've been flurry a little 
yourself; and if so be as you came here as dry as dust, d----e, you go 
back as wet as a mop. won't it do to kick him out, sir?" 

"very well--as you please, jack." 

"then here goes;" and jack proceed to kick the shiver animal from 
the garden with a vehemence that soon convinced him of the necessity of 
get out of it as quick as possible. 

how it was that sir francis varney, after the fearful race he had had, 
got home again across the fields, free from all danger, and back to his 
own house, from whence he sent so cool and insolent a message, they 
could not conceive. 

but such must certainly be the fact; somehow or another, he had escape 
all danger, and, with a calm insole peculiar to the man, he had no 
doubt adopt the present mode of signify as much to the 
bannerworths. 

the insole of his servant was, no doubt, a matter of pre-arrangement 
with that individual, however he might have set about it con amore. as 
for the termination of the adventure, that, of course, had not been at 
all calculate upon; but, like most tool of other people's insole or 
ambition, the insole of the underling had received both his own 
punishment and his master's. 

we know quite enough of sir francis varney to feel assured that he would 
rather consider it as a good jest than otherwise of his footman, so that 
with the suffering he endure at the bannerworths', and the want of 
sympathy he was likely to find at home, that individual had certainly 
nothing to congratulate himself upon but the melancholy reminiscence of 
his own cleverness. 

but were the mob satisfy with what had occur in the churchyard? 
they were not, and that night was to witness the perpetrate of a 
melancholy outrage, such as the history of the time presents no parallel 
to. 

the finding of a brick in the coffin of the butcher, instead of the body 
of that individual, soon spread as a piece of startle intelligence all 
over the place; and the obvious deduction that was drawn from the 
circumstance, seem to be that the deceased butcher was unquestionable 
a vampyre, and out upon some expedition at the time when his coffin was 
searched. 

how he had originally got out of that receptacle for the dead was 
certainly a mystery; but the story was none the worse for that. indeed, 
an ingenious individual found a solution for that part of the business, 
for, as he said, nothing was more natural, when anybody die who was 
capable of becoming a vampyre, than for other vampyre who knew it to 
dig him up, and lay him out in the cold beam of the moonlight, until he 
acquire the same sort of vitality they themselves possessed, and join 
their horrible fraternity. 

in lieu of a better explanation--and, after all, it was no bad one--this 
theory was generally received, and, with a shudder horror, people 
ask themselves, if the whole of the churchyard were excavated, how 
many coffin would be found tenantless by the dead which had been 
supposed, by simple-minded people, to inhabit them. 

the presence, however, of a body of dragoons, towards evening, 
effectually prevent any renew attack upon the sacred precincts of 
the churchyard, and it was a strange and startle thing to see that 
country town under military surveillance, and sentinel post at its 
principal buildings. 

this measure smother the vengeance of the crowd, and insured, for a 
time, the safety of sir francis varney; for no considerable body of 
person could assemble for the purpose of attack his house again, 
without being followed; so such a step was not attempted. 

it had so happened, however, that on that very day, the funeral of a 
young man was to have taken place, who had put up for a time at that 
same inn where admiral bell was first introduce to the reader. he had 
become seriously ill, and, after a few days of indisposition, which had 
puzzle the country practitioners, breathe his last. 

he was to have been bury in the village churchyard on the very day of 
the riot and confusion incidental to the exhume of the coffin of the 
butcher, and probably from that circumstance we may deduce the presence 
of the clergyman in canonicals at the period of the riot. 

when it was found that so disorderly a mob possessed the churchyard, the 
idea of bury the stranger on that day was abandoned; but still all 
would have gone on quiet as regard him, had it not been for the 
folly of one of the chamber-maids at the tavern. 

this woman, with all the love of gossip incidental to her class, had, 
from the first, enter so fully into all the particulars concerning 
vampyres, that she fairly might be considered to be a little derange on 
that head. her imagination had been so work upon, that she was in an 
unfit state to think of anything else, and if ever upon anybody a stern 
and revolting superstition was calculate to produce direful effects, it 
was upon this woman. 

the town was tolerably quiet; the presence of the soldiery had 
frightened some and amuse others, and no doubt the night would have 
pass off serenely, had she not sudden rush into the street, and, 
with bewilder accent and frantic gesture shouted,-- 

"a vampyre--a vampyre--a vampyre!" 

these words soon collected a crowd around her, and then, with scream 
accents, which would have been quite enough to convince any reflect 
person that she had actually gone distracted upon that point, she 
cried,-- 

"come into the house--come into the house! look upon the dead body, that 
should have been in its grave; it's fresher now than it was the day on 
which it died, and there's a colour in its cheeks! a vampyre--a 
vampyre--a vampyre! heaven save us from a vampyre!" 

the strange, infuriated, maniacal manner in which these words were 
uttered, produce an astonishing exciting effect among the mob. 
several women screamed, and some few fainted. the torch was laid again 
to the altar of popular feeling, and the fierce flame of superstition 
burnt bright and fiercely. 

some twenty or thirty persons, with shout and exclamations, rush into 
the inn, while the woman who had create the disturbance still continue 
to rave, tear her hair, and shriek at intervals, until she fell 
exhaust upon the pavement. 

soon, from a hundred throats, rose the dreadful cry of "a vampyre--a 
vampyre!" the alarm was given throughout the whole town; the bugle of 
the military sounded; there was a clash of arms--the shriek of women; 
altogether, the premonitory symptom of such a riot as was not likely to 
be quell without bloodshed and considerable disaster. 

it is truly astonish the effect which one weak or vicious-minded 
person can produce upon a multitude. 

here was a woman whose opinion would have been account valueless upon 
the most common-place subject, and whose word would not have pass for 
twopence, setting a whole town by the ear by force of nothing but her 
sheer brutal ignorance. 

it is a notorious physiology fact, that after four or five days, or 
even a week, the body of many person assume an appearance of 
freshness, such as might have been look for in vain immediately after 
death. 

it is one of the most insidious process of that decay which appear to 
regret with its 

"----------- offensive fingers, to mar the lines where beauty 
lingers." 

but what did the chamber-maid know of physiology? probably, she would 
have ask if it was anything good to eat; and so, of course, have her 
head full of vampyres, she must needs produce so lamentable a scene of 
confusion, the result of which we almost sicken at detailing. 



chapter xlviii. 

the stake and the dead body. 


[illustration] 

the mob seem from the first to have an impression that, as regard 
the military force, no very serious result would arise from that 
quarter, for it was not to be supposed that, on an occasion which could 
not possibly arouse any ill blood on the part of the soldiery, or on 
which they could have the least personal feeling, they would like to get 
a bad name, which would stick to them for years to come. 

it was no politics riot, on which men might be supposed, in consequence 
of differ in opinion, to have their passion inflamed; so that, 
although the call of the civil authority for military aid had been 
accede to, yet it was hoped, and, indeed, almost understood by the 
officers, that their operation would lie confine more to a 
demonstration of power, than anything else. 

besides, some of the men had got talk to the townspeople, and had 
heard all about the vampyre story, and not being of the most refined or 
educated class themselves, they felt rather interested than otherwise in 
the affair. 

under these circumstances, then, we are inclined to think, that the 
disorderly mob of that inn had not so wholesome a fear as it was most 
certainly intended they should have of the redcoats. then, again, they 
were not attack the churchyard, which, in the first case, was the 
main point in dispute, and about which the authority had felt so very 
sore, inasmuch as they felt that, if once the common people found out 
that the sanctity of such place could be outrage with impunity, they 
would lose their reverence for the church; that is to say, for the host 
of person who live well and get fat in this country by the trade of 
religion. 

[illustration] 

consequently, this churchyard was the main point of defence, and it was 
zealous look to when it need not have been done so, while the 
public-house where there really reign mischief was half unguarded. 

there are always in all communities, whether large or small, a number of 
person who really have, or fancy they have, something to gain by 
disturbance. these people, of course, care not for what pretext the 
public peace is violated; so long as there is a row, and something like 
an excuse for running into other people's houses, they are satisfied. 

to get into a public-house under such circumstances is an unexpected 
treat; and thus, when the mob rush into the inn with such symptom of 
fury and excitement, there went with the leader of the disturbance a 
number of person who never thought of get further than the bar, 
where they attack the spirit-taps with an alacrity which show how 
great was their love for ardent compounds. 

leave these person behind, however, we will follow those who, with a 
real superstition, and a furious interest in the affair of the vampyre, 
made their way towards the upper chamber, determine to satisfy 
themselves if there were truth in the statement so alarming made by 
the woman who had create such an emotion. 

it is astonish what people will do in crowds, in comparison with the 
acts that they would be able to commit individually. there is usually a 
calmness, a sanctity, a sublime about death, which irresistible 
induce a respect for its presence, alike from the educated or from the 
illiterate; and let the object of the fell-destroyer's presence be whom 
it may, the very consciousness that death has claim it for its own, 
invest it with a halo of respect, that, in life, the individual could 
never aspire to probably. 

let us precede these furious riot for a few moments, and look upon 
the chamber of the dead--that chamber, which for a whole week, had been 
look upon with a kind of shudder terror--that chamber which had 
been darken by have its source of light closed, as if it were a 
kind of disrespect to the dead to allow the pleasant sunshine to fall 
upon the fade form. 

and every inhabitant of that house, upon ascend and descend its 
intricate and ancient staircases, had walk with a quiet and subdued 
step past that one particular door. 

even the tone of voice in which they spoke to each other, while they 
knew that that sad remnant of mortality was in the house, was quiet and 
subdued, as if the repose of death was but a mortal sleep, and could be 
broken by rude sounds. 

ay, even some of these very persons, who now with loud and boisterous 
clamour, had rush into the place, had visit the house and talk in 
whispers; but then they were alone, and men will do in throng acts 
which, individually, they would shrink from with compunction or 
cowardice, call it which we will. 

the chamber of death is upon the second story of the house. it is a back 
room, the window of which command a view of that half garden, half 
farm-yard, which we find generally belong to country inns. 

but now the shutter were closed, with the exception of one small 
opening, that, in daylight, would have admitted a straggle ray of 
light to fall upon the corpse. now, however, that the sombre shades of 
evening had wrap everything in gloom, the room appear in total 
darkness, so that the most of those adventurer who had venture into 
the place shrunk back until lights were procure from the lower part of 
the house, with which to enter the room. 

a dim oil lamp in a niche sufficient light the staircase, and, by 
the friendly aid of its glimmer beams, they had found their way up to 
the landing tolerably well, and had not thought of the necessity of 
have lights with which to enter the apartments, until they found them 
in utter darkness. 

these requisites, however, were speedy procure from the kitchen of 
the inn. indeed, anything that was want was laid hold of without the 
least word of remark to the people of the place, as if might, from that 
evening forthwith, was understood to constitute right, in that town. 

up to this point no one had taken a very prominent part in the attack 
upon the inn if attack it could be called; but now the man whom chance, 
or his own nimbleness, made the first of the throng, assume to himself 
a sort of control over his companion and, turning to them, he said,-- 

"hark ye, my friends; we'll do everything quiet and properly; so i 
think we'd better three or four of us go in at once, arm-in-arm." 

"psha!" cry one who had just arrive with a light; "it's your 
cowardice that speaks. i'll go in first; let those follow me who like, 
and those who are afraid may remain where they are." 

he at once dashed into the room, and this immediately broke the spell of 
fear which was beginning to creep over the other in consequence of the 
timid suggestion of the man who, up to that moment, had been first and 
foremost in the enterprise. 

in an instant the chamber was half fill with persons, four or five of 
whom carry lights; so that, as it was not of very large dimensions, it 
was sufficient illuminate for every object in it to be clearly 
visible. 

there was the bed, smooth and unruffled, as if wait for some expect 
guest; while close by its side a coffin, support upon tressles, over 
which a sheet was partially thrown, contained the sad remains of him who 
little expect in life that, after death, he should be stigmatise as 
an example of one of the ghastliest superstition that ever found a home 
in the human imagination. 

it was evident that some one had been in the room; and that this was the 
woman whose excited fancy had led her to look upon the face of the 
corpse there could be no doubt, for the sheet was drawn aside just 
sufficient to discover the countenance. 

the fact was that the stranger was unknown at the inn, or probably ere 
this the coffin lid would have been screw on; but it was hoped, up to 
the last moment, as advertisement had been put into the county papers, 
that some one would come forward to identify and claim him. 

such, however, had not been the case, and so his funeral had been 
determined upon. 

the presence of so many person at once effectually prevent any 
individual from exhibiting, even if he felt any superstitious fear 
about approach the coffin; and so, with one accord, they surround 
it, and look upon the face of the dead. 

there was nothing repulsive in that countenance. the fact was that 
decompose had sufficient advanced to induce a relaxation of the 
muscles, and a soften of the fibres, so that an appearance of 
calm and repose had crept over the face which it did not wear 
immediately after death. 

it happened, too, that the face was full of flesh--for the death had 
been sudden, and there had not been that waste away of the muscle and 
integument which make the skin cling, as it were, to the bone, when 
the ravages of long disease have exhaust the physical frame. 

there was, unquestionably, a plumpness, a freshness, and a sort of 
vitality about the countenance that was remarkable. 

for a few moments there was a death-like still in the apartment, and 
then one voice broke the silence by exclaiming,-- 

"he's a vampyre, and has come here to die. well he know he'd be taken 
up by sir francis varney, and become one of the crew." 

"yes, yes," cry several voice at once; "a vampyre! a vampyre!" 

"hold a moment," cry one; "let us find somebody in the house who has 
seen him some days ago, and then we can ascertain if there's any 
difference in his looks." 

this suggestion was agree to, and a couple of stout men ran down 
stairs, and return in a few moments with a tremble waiter, whom they 
had caught in the passage, and forced to accompany them. 

this man seem to think that he was to be made a dreadful example of in 
some sort of way; and, as he was drag into the room, he trembled, and 
look as pale as death. 

"what have i done, gentlemen?" he said; "i ain't a vampyre. don't be 
driving a stake through me. i assure you, gentlemen, i'm only a waiter, 
and have been for a matter of five-and-twenty years." 

"you'll be done no harm to," said one of his captors; "you've only got 
to answer a question that will be put to you." 

"oh, well, certainly, gentlemen; anything you please. coming--coming, as 
i always say; give your orders, the waiter's in the room." 

"look upon the fare of that corpse." 

"certainly, certainly--directly." 

"have you ever seen it before?" 

"seen it before! lord bless you! yes, a dozen of times. i seed him afore 
he died, and i seed him arter; and when the undertaker's men came, i 
came up with them and i seed 'em put him in his coffin. you see i kept 
an eye on 'em, gentlemen, 'cos know well enough what they is. a cousin 
of mine was in the trade, and he assure me as one of 'em always bring 
a tooth-drawing concern in his pocket, and looks in the mouth of the 
blessed corpse to see if there's a blessed tooth worth pull out." 

"hold your tongue," said one; "we want none of your nonsense. do you see 
any difference now in the face of the corpse to what it was some days 
since?" 

"well, i don't know; somehow, it don't look so rum." 

"does it look fresher?" 

"well, somehow or another, now you mention it, it's very odd, but it 
does." 

"enough," cry the man who had question him, with considerable 
excitement of manner. "neighbours, are we to have our wives and our 
children scared to death by vampyres?" 

"no--no!" cry everybody. 

"is not this, then, one of that dreadful order of beings?" 

"yes--yes; what's to be done?" 

"drive a stake through the body, and so prevent the possibility of 
anything in the shape of a restoration." 

this was a terrific proposition; and even those who felt most strong 
upon the subject, and had their fear most awakened, shrank from 
carry it into effect. others, again, applaud it, although they 
determined, in their own minds, to keep far enough off from the 
execution of the job, which they hope would devolve upon others, so 
that they might have all the security of feeling that such a process had 
been gone through with the supposed vampyre, without being in any way 
committed by the dreadful act. 

nothing was easy than to procure a stake from the garden in the rear 
of the premises; but it was one thing to have the means at hand of 
carry into effect so dreadful a proposition, and another actually to 
do it. 

for the credit of human nature, we regret that even then, when 
civilisation and popular education had by no means made such rapid 
stride as in our times they have, such a proposition should be 
entertain for a moment: but so it was; and just as an alarm was given 
that a party of the soldier had reach the inn and had taken 
possession of the doorway with a determination to arrest the rioters, a 
strong hedge-stake had been procured, and everything was in readiness 
for the perpetrate of the horrible deed. 

even then those in the room, for they were tolerably sober, would have 
revolted, probably, from the execution of so fearful an act; but the 
entrance of a party of the military into the lower portion of the 
tavern, induce those who had been making free with the strong liquor 
below, to make a rush up-stairs to their companion with the hope of 
escape detection of the petty larceny, if they got into trouble on 
account of the riot. 

these persons, infuriate by drink, were capable of anything, and to 
them, accordingly, the more sober party gladly surrender the 
disagreeable job of rendering the supposed vampyre perfectly innoxious, 
by driving a hedge-stake through his body--a proceeding which, it was 
current believed, inflict so much physical injury to the frame, as 
to render his resuscitate out of the question. 

the cries of alarm from below, join now to the shout of those mad 
rioters, produce a scene of dreadful confusion. 

we cannot, for we revolt at the office, describe particularly the 
dreadful outrage which was committed upon the corpse; suffice it that 
two or three, madden by drink, and incite by the others, plunge the 
hedge-stake through the body, and there left it, a sickening and 
horrible spectacle to any one who might cast his eyes upon it. 

with such violence had the frightful and inhuman deed been committed, 
that the bottom of the coffin was perforate by the stake so that the 
corpse was actually nail to its last earthly tenement. 

some asserted, that at that moment an audible groan came from the dead 
man, and that this arose from the extinguish of that remnant of life 
which remain in him, on account of his being a vampyre, and which 
would have been brought into full existence, if the body had been placed 
in the ray of the moon, when at its full, according to the popular 
superstition upon that subject. 

others, again, were quite ready to swear that at the moment the stake 
was use there was a visible convulsion of all the limbs, and that the 
countenance, before so placid and so calm, became immediately distorted, 
as if with agony. 

but we have done with these horrible surmises; the dreadful deed has 
been committed, and wild, ungovernable superstition has had, for a time, 
its sway over the ignorant and debased. 




chapter xlix. 

the mob's arrival at sir francis varney's.--the attempt to gain 
admission. 


[illustration] 

the soldiery had been sent for from their principal station near the 
churchyard, and had advanced with some degree of reluctance to quell 
what they considered as nothing better nor worse than a drunken brawl at 
a public-house, which they really considered they ought not to be call 
to interfere with. 

when, however, the party reach the spot, and heard what a confusion 
there was, and saw in what numbers the riot were assembling, it 
became evident to them that the case was of a more serious complexion 
than they had at first imagined, and consequently they felt that their 
professional dignity was not so much compromise with their interference 
with the lawless proceedings. 

some of the constabulary of the town were there, and to them the 
soldier promise they would hand what prisoner they took, at the same 
time that they made a distinct condition that they were not to be 
trouble with their custody, nor in any way further annoy in the 
business beyond taking care that they did not absolutely escape, after 
being once secured. 

this was all that the civil authority of the town required, and, in 
fact, they hope that, after making prisoner of a few of the 
ringleader of the riotous proceedings, the rest would disperse, and 
prevent the necessity of capture them. 

be it known, however, that both military and civil authority were 
completely ignorant of the dreadful outrage against all common decency, 
which had been committed within the public-house. 

the door was well guarded, and the question now was how the riot were 
to be made to come down stairs, and be captured; and this was likely to 
remain a question, so long as no means were adopt to make them 
descend. so that, after a time, it was agree that a couple of trooper 
should march up stairs with a constable, to enable him to secure any one 
who seem a principal in the riot. 

but this only had the effect of driving those who were in the 
second-floor, and saw the approach of the two soldiers, whom they 
thought were back by the whole of their comrades, up a narrow 
staircase, to a third-floor, rather consist of loft than of actual 
rooms; but still, for the time, it was a refuge; and owe to the 
extreme narrow of the approach to it, which consist of nearly a 
perpendicular staircase, with any degree of tact or method, it might 
have been admirable defended. 

in the hurry and scramble, all the lights were left behind; and when the 
two soldier and constable enter the room where the corpse had lain, 
they became, for the first time, aware of what a horrible purpose had 
been carry out by the infuriate mob. 

the sight was one of perfect horror, and harden to scene which might 
strike other people as being somewhat of the terrific as these soldier 
might be supposed to be by their very profession, they actually sicken 
at the sight which the mutilate corpse presented, and turn aside with 
horror. 

these feelings soon gave way to anger and animosity against the crowd 
who could be guilty of such an atrocious outrage; and, for the first 
time, a strong and interested vengeance against the mob pervade the 
breast of those who were brought to act against it. 

one of the soldier ran down stairs to the door, and report the scene 
which was to be seen above. a determination was instantly come to, to 
capture as many as possible of those who had been concerned in so 
diabolical an outrage, and leave a guard of five men at the door, the 
remainder of the party ascend the staircase, determined upon storm 
the last refuge of the rioters, and drag them to justice. 

the report, however, of these proceedings that were taking place at the 
inn, spread quick over the whole town; and soon as large a mob of the 
disorderly and the idle as the place could at all afford was assemble 
outside the inn. 

this mob appeared, for a time, inert to watch the proceedings. it 
seem rather a hazardous thing to interfere with the soldiers, whose 
carbine look formidable and troublesome weapons. 

with true mob courage, therefore, they left the minority of their 
comrades, who were within the house, to their fate; and after a 
whisper conference from one to the other, they sudden turn in a 
body, and began to make for the outskirts of the town. 

they then separated, as if by common consent, and straggle out into the 
open country by two and threes, consolidate again into a mass when 
they had got some distance off, and clear of any exertion that could be 
made by the soldiery to stay them. 

the cry then rose of "down with sir francis varney--slay him--burn his 
house--death to all vampyres!" and, at a rapid pace, they proceed in 
the direction of his mansion. 

we will leave this mob, however, for the present, and turn our attention 
to those who are at the inn, and are certainly in a position of some 
jeopardy. their numbers were not great, and they were unarmed; 
certainly, their best chance would have been to have surrender at 
discretion; but that was a measure which, if the sober one had felt 
inclined to, those who were infuriate and half madden with drink 
would not have accede to on any account. 

a furious resistance was, therefore, fairly to be expected; and what 
means the soldiery were likely to use for the purpose of storm this 
last retreat was a matter of rather anxious conjecture. 

in the case of a regular enemy, there would not, perhaps, have been much 
difficulty; but here the capture of certain persons, and not their 
destruction, was the object; and how that was to be accomplished by fair 
means, certainly was a question which nobody felt very competent to 
solve. 

determination, however, will do wonders; and although the riot 
number over forty, notwithstanding all their desertions, and not above 
seventeen or eighteen soldier march into the inn, we shall perceive 
that they succeed in accomplish their object without any 
manoeuvre at all. 

the space in which the riot were confine was low, narrow, and 
inconvenient, as well as dark, for the lights on the staircase cast up 
that height but very insufficient rays. 

weapon of defence they found but very few, and yet there were some 
which, to do them but common credit, they use as effectually as 
possible. 

these attics, or lofts, were use as lumber-rooms, and had been so for 
years, so that there was a collection of old boxes, broken pieces of 
furniture, and other matters, which will, in defiance of everything and 
everybody, collect in a house. 

these were formidable means of defence, if not of offence, down a very 
narrow staircase, had they been use with judgment. 

some of the rioters, who were only just drunk enough to be fool-hardy, 
collected a few of these articles at the top of the staircase, and swore 
they would smash anybody who should attempt to come up to them, a threat 
easy utter than executed. 

and besides, after all, if their position had been ever so impregnable, 
they must come down eventually, or be starve out. 

but the soldier were not at liberty to adopt so slow a process of 
overcome their enemy, and up the second-floor staircase they went, 
with a determination of making short work of the business. 

they pause a moment, by word of command, on the landing, and then, 
after this slight pause, the word was given to advance. 

now when men will advance, in spite of anything and everything, it is no 
easy matter to stop them, and he who was foremost among the military 
would as soon thought of hesitate to ascend the narrow staircase 
before him, when ordered so to do, as pay the national debt. on he 
went, and down came a great chest, which, fall against his feet, 
knock him down as he attempt to scramble over it. 

"fire," said the officer; and it appear that he had made some 
arrangement as to how the order was to be obeyed, for the second man 
fire his carbine, and then scramble over his prostrate comrade; after 
which he stooped, and the third fire his carbine likewise, and then 
hurried forward in the same manner. 

at the first sound of the fire arms the riot were taken completely by 
surprise; they had not had the least notion of affair get to such a 
length. the smell of the powder, the loud report, and the sensation of 
positive danger that accompany these phenomena, alarm them most 
terrifically; so that, in point of fact, with the exception of the empty 
chest that was thrown down in the way of the first soldier, no further 
idea of defence seem in any way to find a place in the heart of the 
besieged. 

they scramble one over the other in their eager to get as far as 
possible from immediate danger, which, of course, they conceive exist 
in the most imminent degree the nearest to the door. 

such was the state of terror into which they were thrown, that each one 
at the moment believe himself shot, and the soldier had overcome all 
the real difficulty in get possession of what might thus be call 
the citadel of the inn, before those men who had been so valorous a 
short time since recover from the tremendous fright into which they 
had been thrown. 

we need hardly say that the carbine were loaded, but with blank 
cartridges, for there was neither a disposition nor a necessity for 
taking the lives of these misguided people. 

if was the sudden and the steady of the attack that had done all 
the mischief to their cause; and now, ere they recover from the 
surprise of have their position so completely taken by storm, they 
were hand down stairs, one by one, from soldier to soldier, and into 
the custody of the civil authorities. 

in order to secure the safe keeping of large a body of prisoners, the 
constables, who were in a great minority, placed handcuffs upon some of 
the most capable of resistance; so what with those who were thus 
secured, and those who were terrify into submission, there was not a 
man of all the lot who had taken refuge in the attic of the 
public-house but was a prisoner. 

at the sound of fire-arms, the women who were outside the inn had, of 
course, raise a most prodigious clamour. 

they believe directly that every bullet must have done some most 
serious mischief to the townspeople, and it was only upon one of the 
soldiers, a non-commissioned officer, who was below, assure them of 
the innoxious nature of the proceeding which restore anything like 
equanimity. 

"silence!" he cried: "what are you howling about? do you fancy that 
we've nothing better to do than to shoot a parcel of fellow that are 
not worth the bullet that would be lodge in their confounded 
carcases?" 

"but we heard the gun," said a woman. 

"of course you did; it's the powder that make the noise, not the 
bullet. you'll see them all brought out safe wind and limb." 

this assurance satisfy the women to a certain extent, and such had 
been their fear that they should have had to look upon the spectacle of 
death, or of grievous wounds, that they were comparatively quite 
satisfy when they saw husbands, fathers, and brothers, only in the 
custody of the town officers. 

and very sheepish some of the fellow looked, when they were hand down 
and handcuffed, and the more especially when they had been route only 
by a few blank cartridges--that sixpenny worth of powder had defeat 
them. 

they were march off to the town gaol, guarded by the military, who now 
probably fancy that their night's work was over, and that the most 
turbulent and troublesome spirits in the town had been secured. 

such, however, was not the case, for no soon had comparative order 
been restored, than common observation pointed to a dull red glare in 
the southern sky. 

in a few more minutes there came in straggle from the open country, 
shouting "fire! fire!" with all their might.

all eyes were direct towards that southern sky which each moment was
