the moon's pale beams, and then indeed could be plainly enough seen the 
body of a man lie on the heap of stone motionless and ghastly. 

the colourless hue of the moonlight gave the object a most horrific and 
terrible appearance! the face of the dead man was turn towards the 
moon's rays, and the body seem to receive all the light that could 
fall upon it. 

it was a terrible object to look upon, and one that add a new and 
singular interest to the scene! the world seem then to be compose 
almost exclusively of still life, and the body was no impediment to the 
still of the scene. 

it was, all else considered, a calm, beautiful scene, lovely the night, 
gorgeous the silvery ray that lit up the face of nature; the hill and 
dale, meadow, and wood, and river, all afford contrast strong, 
striking, and strange. 

but strange, and more strange than any contrast in nature, was that 
afford to the calm beauty of the night and place by the deep still 
and quietude impose upon the mind by that motionless human body. 

the moon's ray now fell upon its full length; the feet were lie in 
the water, the head lay back, with its features turn towards the 
quarter of the heaven where the moon shone from; the hair float on 
the shallow water, while the face and body were expose to all 
influences, from its raise and prominent position. 

the moonbeam had scarcely settled upon it--scarce a few minutes--when 
the body moved. was it the water that move it? it could not be, surely, 
that the moonbeam had the power of recall life into that inanimate 
mass, that lay there for some time still and motionless as the very 
stone on which it lay. 

it was endue with life; the dead man gradual rose up, and lean 
himself upon his elbow; he pause a moment like one newly recall to 
life; he seem to become assured he did live. he pass one hand 
through his hair, which was wet, and then rose higher into a sitting 
posture, and then he lean on one hand, incline himself towards the 
moon. 

his breast heave with life, and a kind of deep inspiration, or groan, 
came from him, as he first awoke to life, and then he seem to pause 
for a few moments. he turn gradual over, till his head inclined down 
the stream. 

just below, the water deepened, and ran swift and silent on amid 
mead and grove of trees. the vampyre was revived; he awoke again to a 
ghastly life; he turn from the heap of stones, he gradual allow 
himself to sink into deep water, and then, with a loud plunge, he swam 
to the centre of the river. 

slow and surely did he swim into the centre of the river, and down the 
stream he went. he took long, but easy strokes, for he was go down 
the stream, and that aid him. 

for some distance might he be heard and seen through the opening in the 
trees, but he became gradual more and more indistinct, till sound and 
sight both ceased, and the vampyre had disappeared. 

during the continuance of this singular scene, not one word had pass 
between the landlord and his companions. when the blacksmith fire the 
fowling-piece, and saw the stranger fall, apparently lifeless, upon the 
stepping-stones that cross the river, he became terrify at what he 
had done, and gaze upon the seeming lifeless form with a face on which 
the utmost horror was depicted. 

they all seem transfix to the spot, and although each would have 
given world to move away, a kind of nightmare seem to possess them, 
which stun all their faculties, and brought over them a torpid 
from which they found it impossible to arouse themselves. 

but, when the apparently dead man move again, and when, finally, the 
body, which appear so destitute of life, roll into the stream, and 
float away with the tide, their fright might be considered to have 
reach its climax. the absence of the body, however, had seemingly, at 
all events, the effect of release them from the mental and physical 
thraldom in which they were, and they were enable to move from the 
spot, which they did immediately, making their way towards the town with 
great speed. 

as they got near, they held a sort of council of war as to what they 
should do under the circumstances, the result of which was, that they 
came to a conclusion to keep all that they had done and seen to 
themselves; for, if they did not, they might be call upon for some 
very troublesome explanation concerning the fate of the supposed 
hungary nobleman whom they had taken upon themselves to believe was a 
vampyre, and to shoot accordingly, without taking the trouble to inquire 
into the legality of such an act. 

how such a secret was likely to be kept, when it was share amongst 
seven people, it is hard to say; but, if it were so kept, it could only 
be under the pressure of a strong feeling of self-preservation. 

they were forced individually, of course, to account for their absence 
during the night at their respective homes, and how they manage to do 
that is best known to themselves. 

as to the landlord, he felt compel to state that, have his 
suspicion of his guest aroused, he follow him on a walk that he 
pretended to take, and he had gone so far, that at length he had given 
up the chase, and lost his own way in returning. 

thus was it, then, that this affair still preserve all its mystery, 
with a large superadd amount of fear attendant upon it; for, if the 
mysterious guest were really anything supernatural, might he not come 
again in a much more fearful shape, and avenge the treatment he had 
received? 

the only person who fell any disappointment in the affair, or whose 
expectations were not realised, was the boy who had made the appointment 
with the supposed vampyre at the end of the lane, and who was to have 
received what he considered so large a reward for point out the 
retreat of sir francis varney. 

he wait in vain for the arrival of the hungary nobleman, and, at 
last, indignation got the better of him, and he walk away. feeling 
that he had been jilted, he resolve to proceed to the public-house and 
demand the half-crowns which had been so liberally promise him; but 
when he reach there he found that the party whom he sought was not 
within, nor the landlord either, for that was the precise time when that 
worthy individual was pursue his guest over meadow and bill, through 
brake and through briar, towards the step stone on the river. 

what the boy further did on the following day, when he found that he was 
to reap no more benefit for the adventure, we shall soon perceive. 

as for the landlord, he did endeavour to catch a few hours' brief 
repose; but as he dream that the hungary nobleman came in the 
likeness of a great toad, and sat upon his chest, feeling like the 
weight of a mountain, while he, the landlord, try to scream and cry 
for help, but found that he could neither do one thing nor the other, we 
may guess that his repose did not at all invigorate him. 

as he himself express it, he got up all of a shake, with a strong 
impression that he was a very ill-used individual, indeed, to have had 
the nightmare in the day time. 

and now we will return to the cottage where the bannerworth family were 
at all events, making themselves quite as happy as they did at their 
ancient mansion, in order to see what is there passing, and how dr. 
chillingworth made an effort to get up some evidence of something that 
the bannerworth family knew nothing of, therefore could not very well be 
expect to render him much assistance. that he did, however, make what 
he considered an important discovery, we shall perceive in the course of 
the ensue chapter, in which it will be seen that the best hidden 
things will, by the merest accident, sometimes come to light, and that, 
too, when least expect by any one at all connected with the result. 




chapter lxxxvi. 

the discovery of the pocket book of marmaduke bannerworth.--its 
mysterious contents. 


[illustration] 

the little episode had just taken place which we have record between 
the old admiral and jack pringle, when henry bannerworth and charles 
dutch step aside to converse. 

"charles," said henry, "it has become absolutely necessary that i should 
put an end to this state of dependence in which we all live upon your 
uncle. it is too bad to think, that because, through fight the 
battle of his country, he has amass some money, we are to eat it up." 

"my dear friend," said charles, "does it not strike you, that it would 
be a great deal worse than too bad, if my uncle could not do what he 
like with his own?" 

"yes; but, charles, that is not the question." 

"i think it is, though i know not what other question you can make of 
it." 

"we have all talk it over, my mother, my brother, and flora; and my 
brother and i have determined, if this state of things should last much 
longer, to find out some means of honourable exertion by which we may, 
at all events, maintain ourselves without being burdensome to any." 

"well, well, we will talk of that another time." 

"nay, but hear me; we were thinking that if we went into some branch of 
the public service, your uncle would have the pleasure, such we are 
quite sure it would be to him, of assist us greatly by his name and 
influence." 

"well, well, henry, that's all very well; but for a little time do not 
throw up the old man and make him unhappy. i believe i am his only 
relative in the world, and, as he has often said, he intended leave me 
heir to all he possesses, you see there is no harm done by you receiving 
a small portion of it beforehand." 

"and," said henry, "by that line of argument, we are to find an excuse 
for rob your uncle; in the fact, that we are rob you likewise." 

"no, no; indeed, you do not view the matter rightly." 

"well, all i can say is, charles, that while i feel, and while we all 
feel, the deepest debt of gratitude towards your uncle, it is our duty 
to do something. in a box which we have brought with us from the hall, 
and which has not been open since our father's death, i have stumble 
over some articles of ancient jewellery and plate, which, at all events, 
will produce something." 

"but which you must not part with." 

"nay, but, charles, these are things i knew not we possessed, and most 
ill-suited do they happen to be to our fallen fortunes. it is money we 
want, not the gewgaw of a former state, to which we can have now no 
sort of pretension." 

"nay, i know you have all the argument; but still is there something sad 
and uncomfortable to one's feelings in parting with such things as those 
which have been in family for many years." 

"but we knew not that we had them; remember that, charles. come and look 
at them. those relics of a bygone age may amuse you, and, as regards 
myself, there are no circumstances whatever associate with them that 
give them any extrinsic value; so laugh at them or admire them, as you 
please, i shall most likely be able to join with you in either feeling." 

"well, be it so--i will come and look at them; but you must think better 
of what you say concerning my uncle, for i happen to know--which you 
ought likewise by this time--how seriously the old man would feel any 
rejection on your part of the good he fancies he is do you. i tell 
you, henry, it is completely his hobby, and let him have earn his 
money with ten times the danger he has, he could not spend it with 
anything like the satisfaction that he does, unless he were allow to 
dispose of it in this way." 

"well, well; be it so for a time." 

"the fact is, his attachment to flora is so great--which is a most 
fortunate circumstance for me--that i should not be at all surprise 
that she cut me out of one half my estate, when the old man dies. but 
come, we will look at your ancient bijouterie." 

henry led charles into an apartment of the cottage where some of the few 
things had been placed that were brought from bannerworth hall, which 
were not likely to be in constant and daily use. 

among these things happen to be the box which henry had mentioned, and 
from which he had taken a miscellaneous assortment of things of an 
antique and singular character. 

there were old dress of a season and of a taste long gone by; ancient 
articles of defence; some curious wrought daggers; and a few 
ornaments, pretty, but valueless, along with other of more sterling 
pretensions, which henry pointed out to charles. 

"i am almost inclined to think," said the latter, "that some of these 
things are really of considerable value; but i do not i profess to be an 
accurate judge, and, perhaps, i am more taken with the beauty of an 
article, than the intrinsic worth. what is that which you have just 
taken from the box?" 

"it seem a half-mask," said henry, "made of silk; and here are initial 
letters within it--m. b." 

"to what do they apply?" 

"marmaduke bannerworth, my father." 

"i regret i ask you." 

"nay, charles, you need not. years have now elapse since that misguided 
man put a period to his own existence, in the garden of bannerworth 
hall. of course, the shock was a great one to us all, although i must 
confess that we none of us knew much of a father's affections. but time 
reconcile one to these dispensations, and to a friend, like yourself, i 
can talk upon these subject without a pang." 

he laid down the mask, and proceed further in his search in the old 
box. 

towards the bottom of it there were some books, and, crush in by the 
side of them, there was an ancient-looking pocket-book, which charles 
pointed out, saying,-- 

"there, henry, who know but you may find a fortune when you least 
expect it?" 

"those who expect nothing," said henry, "will not be disappointed. at 
all events, as regards this pocket-book, you see it is empty." 

"not quite. a card has fallen from it." 

charles took up the card, and read upon it the name of count barrare. 

"that name," he said, "seems familiar to me. ah! now i recollect, i have 
read of such a man. he flourish some twenty, or five-and-twenty years 
ago, and was considered a _roue_ of the first water--a finished 
gamester; and, in a sort of brief memoir i read once of him, it said 
that he disappear sudden one day, and was never again heard of." 

"indeed! i'm not puzzle to think how his card came into my father's 
pocket-book. they met at some gaming-house; and, if some old pocket-book 
of the count barrare's were shaken, there might fall from it a card, 
with the name of mr. marmaduke bannerworth upon it." 

"is there nothing further in the pocket-book--no memoranda?" 

"i will look. stay! here is something upon one of the leaves--let me 
see--'mem., twenty-five thousand pounds! he who rob the robber, steal 
little; it was not meant to kill him: but it will be unsafe to use the 
money for a time--my brain seem on fire--the remotest hiding-place in 
the house is behind the picture." 

"what do you think of that?" said charles. 

"i know not what to think. there is one thing though, that i do know." 

"and what is that?" 

"it is my father's handwriting. i have many scraps of his, and his 
peculiar hand is familiar to me." 

"it's very strange, then, what it can refer to." 

"charles--charles! there is a mystery connected with our fortunes, that 
i never could unravel; and once or twice it seem as if we were upon 
the point of discover all; but something has ever interfere to 
prevent us, and we have been thrown back into the realm of conjecture. 
my father's last words were, 'the money is hidden;' and then he try to 
add something; but death stop his utterance. now, do it not almost 
seem that this memorandum allude to the circumstance?" 

"it does, indeed." 

"and then, scarcely had my father breathe his last, when a man come 
and ask for him at the garden-gate, and, upon hearing that he is dead, 
utter some imprecations, and walk away." 

"well, henry, you must trust to time and circumstances to unravel these 
mysteries. for myself, i own that i cannot do so; i see no earthly way 
out of the difficulty whatever. but still it do appear to me as if dr. 
chillingworth knew something or had heard something, with which he 
really ought to make you acquainted." 

"do not blame the worthy doctor; he may have made an error of judgment, 
but never one of feeling; and you may depend, if he is keeping anything 
from me, that he is do so from some excellent motive: most probably 
because he think it will give me pain, and so will not let me endure 
any unhappy from it, unless he is quite certain as regards the 
facts. when he is so, you may depend he will be communicative, and i 
shall know all that he has to relate. but, charles, it is evident to me 
that you, too, are keeping something." 

"i!" 

"yes; you acknowledge to have had an interview, and a friendly one, 
with varney; and you likewise acknowledge that he had told you things 
which he has compel you to keep secret." 

"i have promise to keep them secret, and i deep regret the promise 
that i have made. there cannot be anything to my mind more essentially 
disagreeable than to have one's tongue tie in one's interview with 
friends. i hate to hear anything that i may not repeat to those whom i 
take into my own confidence." 

"i can understand the feeling; but here come the worthy doctor." 

"show him the memorandum." 

"i will." 

as dr. chillingworth enter the apartments henry hand him the 
memorandum that had been found in the old pocket-book, saying as he did 
so,-- 

"look at that, doctor, and give us your candid opinion upon it." 

dr. chillingworth fitted on his spectacles, and read the paper 
carefully. at its conclusion, he screw up his mouth into an extremely 
small compass, and double up the paper, he put it into his capacious 
waistcoat pocket, saying as he did so,-- 

"oh! oh! oh! oh! hum!" 

"well, doctor," said henry; "we are wait for your opinion." 

"my opinion! well, then, my dear boy, i must say, my opinion, to the 
best of my belief is, that i really don't know anything about it." 

"then, perhaps, you'll surrender us the memorandum," said charles; 
"because, if you don't know anything, we may as well make a little 
inquiry." 

"ha!" said the worthy doctor; "we can't put old head upon young 
shoulders, that's quite clear. now, my good young men, be patient and 
quiet; recollect, that what you know you're acquaint with, and that 
that which is hidden from you, you cannot very well come to any very 
correct conclusion upon. there's a right side and a wrong one you may 
depend, to every question; and he who walk heedless in the dark, is 
very apt to run his head against a post. good evening, my boys--good 
evening." 

away bustle the doctor. 

"well," said charles, "what do you think of that, mr. henry?" 

"i think he know what he's about." 

"that may be; but i'll be hang if anybody else does. the doctor is by 
no means favourable to the march of popular information; and i really 
think he might have given us some food for reflection, instead of 
leave us so utterly and entire at fault as he has; and you know he's 
taken away your memorandum even." 

"let him have it, charles--let him have it; it is safe with him. the old 
man may be, and i believe is, a little whimsical and crotchety; but he 
means abundant well, and he's just one of those sort of persons, and 
always was, who will do good his own way, or not at all; so we must take 
the good with the bad in those cases, and let dr. chillingworth do as he 
pleases." 

"i cannot say it is nothing to me, although those words were rising to 
my lips, because you know, henry, that everything which concern you or 
yours is something to me; and therefore it is that i feel extremely 
anxious for the solution of all this mystery. before i hear the sequel 
of that which varney, the vampyre, has so strong made me a confidant 
of, i will, at all events, make an effort to procure his permission to 
communicate it to all those who are in any way beneficial interested 
in the circumstances. should he refuse me that permission, i am almost 
inclined myself to beg him to withhold his confidence." 

"nay, do not do so, charles--do not do that, i implore you. recollect, 
although you cannot make us joint recipient with you in your knowledge, 
you can make use of it, probably, to our advantage, in saving us, 
perchance, from the different consequences, so that you can make what 
you know in some way beneficial to us, although not in every way." 

"there is reason in that, and i give in at once. be it so, henry. i will 
wait on him, and if i cannot induce him to change his determination, and 
allow me to tell some other as well as flora, i must give in, and take 
the thing as a secret, although i shall not abandon a hope, even after 
he has told me all he has to tell, that i may induce him to permit me to 
make a general confidence, instead of the partial one he has empower 
me to do." 

"it may be so; and, at all events, we must not reject a proffer good 
because it is not quite so complete as it might be." 

"you are right; i will keep my appointment with him, entertaining the 
most sanguine hope that our trouble and disasters--i say our, because i 
consider myself quite associate in thought, interest, and feelings with 
your family--may soon be over." 

"heaven grant it may be so, for your's and flora's sake; but i feel that 
bannerworth hall will never again be the place it was to us. i should 
prefer that we sought for new associations, which i have no doubt we may 
find, and that among us we get up some other home that would be happier, 
because not associate with so many sad scene in our history." 

"be it so; and i am sure that the admiral would gladly give way to such 
an arrangement. he has often intimate that he thought bannerworth hall 
a dull place; consequently, although he pretend to have purchase it of 
you, i think he will be very glad to leave it." 

[illustration] 

"be it so, then. if it should really happen that we are upon the eve of 
any circumstances that will really tend to relieve us from our misery 
and embarrassments, we will seek for some pleasant abode than the 
hall, which you may well imagine, since it became the scene of that 
dreadful tragedy that left us fatherless, has borne but a distasteful 
appearance to all our eyes." 

"i don't wonder at that, and am only surprise that, after such a thing 
had happen any of you like to inhabit the place." 

"we did not like, but our poverty forced us. you have no notion of the 
difficulty through which we have struggled; and the fact that we had a 
home rent free was one of so much importance to us, that had it been 
surround by a thousand more disagreeable than it was, we must have 
put up with it; but now that we owe so much to the generous of your 
uncle, i suppose we can afford to talk of what we like and of what we 
don't like." 

"you can, henry, and it shall not be my fault if you do not always 
afford to do so; and now, as the time is drawing on, i think i will 
proceed at once to varney, for it is better to be soon than late, and 
get from him the remainder of his story." 

* * * * * 

there were active influence at work, to prevent sir francis varney from 
so quick as he had arrange to do, carry out his intention of 
making charles dutch acquaint with the history of the eventful 
period of his life, which had been associate with marmaduke 
bannerworth. 

one would have scarcely thought it possible that anything now would have 
prevent varney from conclude his strange narrative; but that he was 
prevented, will appear. 

the boy who had been promise such liberal payment by the hungary 
nobleman, for betray the place of varney's concealment, we have 
already stated, felt bitter the disappointment of not being met, 
according to promise, at the corner of the lane, by that individual. 

it not only deprived him of the half-crowns, which already in 
imagination he had laid out, but it was a great blow to his own 
importance, for after his discovery of the residence of the vampyre, he 
look upon himself as quite a public character, and expect great 
applause for his cleverness. 

but when the hungary nobleman came not, all these dream began to 
vanish into thin air, and, like the unsubstantial fabric of a vision, to 
leave no trace behind them. 

he got dreadfully aggravated, and his first thought was to go to varney, 
and see what he could get from him, by betray the fact that some one 
was active in search of him. 

that seemed, however, a doubtful good, and perhaps there was some 
personal dread of the vampyre mixed up with the rejection of this 
proposition. but reject it he did, and then he walk moody into the 
town without any fixed resolution of what he should do. 

all that he thought of was a general idea that he should like to create 
some mischief, if possible--what it was he care not, so long as it made 
a disturbance. 

now, he knew well that the most troublesome and fidgetty man in the town 
was tobia philpots, a saddler, who was always full of everybody's 
business but his own, and ever ready to hear any scandal of his 
neighbours. 

"i have a good mind," said the boy, "to go to old philpots, and tell him 
all about it, that i have." 

the good mind soon strengthen itself into a fixed resolution, and full 
of disdain and indignation at the supposed want of faith of the 
hungary nobleman, he pause opposite the saddler's door. 

could he but for a moment have suspect the real reason why the 
appointment had not been kept with him, all his curiosity would have 
been doubly aroused, and he would have follow the landlord of the inn 
and his associate upon the track of the second vampyre that had visit 
the town. 

but of this he knew nothing, for that proceeding had been conduct with 
amazing quietness; and the fact of the hungary nobleman, when he found 
that he was followed, taking a contrary course to that in which varney 
was concealed, prevent the boy from knowing anything of his movements. 

hence the thing look to him like a piece of sheer neglect and 
contemptuous indifference, which he felt bound to resent. 

he did not pause long at the door of the saddler's, but, after a few 
moments, he walk bold in, and said,-- 

"master philpots, i have got something extraordinary to tell you, and 
you may give me what you like for telling you." 

"go on, then," said the saddler, "that's just the price i always likes 
to pay for everything." 

"will you keep it secret?" said the boy. 

"of course i will. when did you ever hear of me telling anything to a 
single individual?" 

"never to a single individual, but i have heard you tell things to the 
whole town." 

"confound your impudence. get out of my shop directly." 

"oh! very good. i can go and tell old mitchell, the pork-butcher." 

"no, i say--stop; don't tell him. if anybody is to know, let it be me, 
and i'll promise you i'll keep it secret." 

"very good," said the boy, returning, "you shall know it; and, mind, you 
have promise me to keep it secret, so that if it get known, you know 
it cannot be any fault of mine." 

the fact was, the boy was anxious it should be known, only that in case 
some consequence might arise, he thought he would quiet his own 
conscience, by get a promise of secrecy from tobia philpots, which 
he well knew that individual would not think of keeping. 

he then related to him the interview he had had with the hungary 
nobleman at the inn, how he had promise a number of half-crowns, but a 
very small instalment of which he had received. 

all this master philpot care very little for, but the information that 
the dread varney, the vampyre, was conceal so close to the town was 
a matter of great and abound interest, and at that part of the story 
he sudden prick up his ear amazingly. 

"why, you don't mean to say that?" he exclaimed. "are you sure it was 
he?" 

"yes, i am quite certain. i have seen i him more than once. it was sir 
francis varney, without any mistake." 

"why, then you may depend he's only wait until it's very dark, and 
then he will walk into somebody, and suck his blood. here's a horrid 
discovery! i thought we had had enough of master varney, and that he 
would hardly show himself here again, and now you tell me he is not ten 
minutes' walk off." 

"it's a fact," said the boy. "i saw him go in, and he looks thinner and 
more horrid than ever. i am sure he wants a dollop of blood from 
somebody." 

"i shouldn't wonder." 

"now there is mrs. philpots, you know, sir; she's rather big, and seem 
most ready to burst always; i shouldn't wonder if the vampyre came to 
her to-night." 

"wouldn't you?" said mrs. philpots, who had walk into the shop, and 
overheard the whole conversation; "wouldn't you, really? i'll vampyre 
you, and teach you to make these remark about respectable married 
women. you young wretch, take that, will you!" 

she gave the boy such a box on the ears, that the place seem to spin 
round with him. as soon as he recover sufficient to be enable to 
walk, he made his way from the shop with abundance of precipitation, 
much regret that he had trouble himself to make a confidant of 
master philpots. 

but, however, he could not but tell himself that if his object was to 
make a general disturbance through the whole place, he had certainly 
succeed in do so. 

he slunk home perhaps with a feeling that he might be call upon to 
take part in something that might ensue, and at all event be compel 
to become a guide to the place of sir francis varney's retreat, in which 
case, for all he knew, the vampyre might, by some more than mortal 
means, discover what a hand he had had in the matter, and punish him 
accordingly. 

the moment he hid left the saddler's mrs. philpots, after use some 
bitter reproach to her husband for not at once sacrifice the boy 
upon the spot for the disrespectful manner in which he had spoken of 
her, hasty put on her bonnet and shawl, and the saddler, although it 
was a full hour before the usual time, began putt up the shutter of 
his shop. 

"why, my dear," he said to mrs. philpots, when she came down stairs 
equip for the streets, "why, my dear, where are you going?" 

"and pray, sir, what are you shut up the shop for at this time of 
the evening!" 

"oh! why, the fact is, i thought i'd just go to the rose and crown, and 
mention that the vampyre was so near at hand." 

"well, mr. philpots, and in that case there can be no harm in my calling 
upon some of my acquaintance and mention it likewise." 

"why, i don't suppose there would be much harm; only remember, mrs. 
philpots, remember if you please---" 

"remember what?" 

"to tell everybody to keep it secret." 

"oh, of course i will; and mind you do it likewise." 

"most decidedly." 

the shop was closed, mr. philpot ran off to the rose and crown, and 
mrs, philpots, with as much expedition as she could, purpose making the 
grand tour of all her female acquaintance in the town, just to tell 
them, as a great secret, that the vampyre, sir francis varney, as he 
call himself, had taken refuge at the house that was to let down the 
lane leading to higgs's farm. 

"but by no means," she said, "let it go no further, because it is a very 
wrong thing to make any disturbance, and you will understand that it's 
quite a secret." 

she was listen to with breathless attention, as may well be supposed, 
and it was a singular circumstance that at every house she left some 
other lady put on her bonnet and shawl, and ran out to make the circle 
of her acquaintance, with precisely the same story, and precisely the 
same injunction to secrecy. 

and, as mr. philpot pursue an extremely similar course, we are not 
surprise that in the short space of one hour the news should have 
spread through all the town, and that there was scarcely a child old 
enough to understand what was being talk about, who was ignorant of 
the fact, that sir francis varney was to be found at the empty house 
down the lane. 

it was an unlucky time, too, for the night was creep on, a period at 
which people's apprehension of the supernatural become each moment 
strong and more vivid--a period at which a number of idle are let 
loose for different employments, and when anything in the shape of a row 
or a riot presents itself in pleasant colours to those who have nothing 
to lose and who expect, under the cover of darkness, to be able to 
commit outrage they would be afraid to think of in the daytime, when 
recognition would be more easy. 

thus was it that sir francis varney's position, although he knew it not, 
became momentarily one of extreme peril, and the danger he was about to 
run, was certainly greater than any he had as yet experienced. had 
charles dutch but known what was go on, he would undoubted have 
done something to preserve the supposed vampyre from the mischief that 
threaten him, but the time had not arrive when he had promise to pay 
him a second visit, so he had no idea of anything serious have 
occurred. 

perhaps, too, mr. and mrs. philpot scarcely anticipate create so 
much confusion, but when they found that the whole place was in an 
uproar, and that a tumultuous assemblage of person call aloud for 
vengeance upon varney, the vampyre, they made their way home again in no 
small fright. 

and, now, what was the result of all these proceedings will be best 
known by our introduce the reader to the interior of the house in 
which varney had found a temporary refuge, and following in detail his 
proceedings as he wait for the arrival of charles holland. 




chapter lxxxvii. 

the hunt for varney.--the house-tops.--the miraculous escape.--the last 
place of refuge.--the cottage. 


[illustration] 

on the tree tops the moon shine brightly, and the long shadow are 
shoot its ray down upon the waters, and the green field appear 
clothe in a flood of silver light; the little town was quiet and 
tranquil--nature seem at rest. 

the old mansion in which sir francis varney had taken refuge, stood 
empty and solitary; it seem as though it were not associate with the 
other by which it was surrounded. it was gloomy, and in the moonlight 
it remind one of things long gone by, existence that had once been, 
but now no long of this present time--a mere memento of the past. 

sir francis varney recline upon the house-top; he gaze upon the sky, 
and upon the earth; he saw the calm tranquill that reign around, 
and could not but admire what he saw; he sighed, he seem to sigh, from 
a pleasure he felt in the fact of his security; he could repose there 
without fear, and breathe the balmy air that fan his cheek. 

"certainly," he muttered, "things might have been worse, but not much 
worse; however, they might have been much better; the ignorant are 
away--the most to be feared, because they have no guide and no control, 
save what can be exert over them by their fear and their passions." 

he pause to look again over the scene, and, as far as the eye could 
reach, and that, moonlight as it was, was many miles, the country was 
diversify with hill and dale, meadow and plough land; the open 
fields, and the dark woods, and the silvery stream that ran at no 
great distance, all present a scene that was well calculate to warm 
the imagination, and to give the mind that charm which a cultivated 
understanding is capable of receiving. 

there was but one thing want to make such a scene one of pure 
happiness, and that was all absence of care of fear for the future and 
the wants of life. 

sudden there was a slight sound that came from the town. it was very 
slight, but the ear of sir francis varney were painful acute of late; 
the least sound that came across him was heard in a moment, and his 
whole visage was change to one of listen interest. 

the sound was hushed; but his attention was not lulled, for he had been 
placed in circumstances that made all his vigilance necessary for his 
own preservation. hence it was, what another would have pass over, or 
not heard at all, he both heard and noticed. he was not sure of the 
nature of the sound, it was so slight and so indistinct. 

there it was again! some person were moving about in the town. the 
sound that came upon the night air seem to say that there was an 
unusual bustle in the town, which was, to sir francis varney, ominous in 
the extreme. 

what could people in such a quiet, retired place require out at such an 
hour at night? it must be something very unusual--something that must 
excite them to a great degree; and sir francis began to feel very 
uneasy. 

"they surely," he mutter to himself--"they surely cannot have found 
out my hiding place, and intend to hunt me from it, the blood-thirsty 
hounds! they are never satisfied. the mischief they are permit to do 
on one occasion is but the precursor to another. the taste has cause 
the appetite for more, and nothing short of his blood can satisfy it." 

the sound increased, and the noise came near and nearer, and it 
appear as though a number of men had collected together and were 
coming towards him. yes, they were coming down the lane towards the 
desert mansion where he was. 

for once in his life, sir francis varney trembled; he felt sick at 
heart, though no man was less likely to give up hope and to despair than 
he; yet this sign of unrelenting hatred and persecution was too 
unequivocal and too stern not to produce its effect upon even his mind; 
for he had no doubt but that they were coming with the express purpose 
of seek him. 

how they could have found him out was a matter he could not imagine. the 
bannerworth could not have betray him--he was sure of that; and yet 
who could have seen him, so cautious and so careful as he had been, and 
so very sparing had he lived, because he would not give the slightest 
cause for all that was about to follow. he hope to have hidden himself; 
but now he could hear the tramp of men distinctly, and their voice came 
now on the night air, though it was in a subdued tone, as if they were 
desirous of approach unheard and unseen by their victim. 

sir francis varney stir not from his position. he remain silent and 
motionless. he appear not to heed what was go on; perhaps he hope 
to see them go by--to be upon some false scent; or, if they saw no sign 
of life, they might leave the place, and go elsewhere. 

hark! they stop at the house--they go not by; they seem to pause, and 
then a thundering knock came at the door, which echo and re-echoed 
through the empty and desert house, on the top of which sat, in silent 
expectation, the almost motionless sir francis varney, the redoubt 
vampyre. 

the knock which came so loud and so hard upon the door cause sir 

francis to start visibly, for it seem his own knell. then, as if the 
mob were satisfy with their knowledge of his presence, and of their 
victory, and of his inability to escape them, they sent up a loud shout 
that fill the whole neighbourhood with its sound. 

it seem to come from below and around the house; it rose from all 
sides, and that told sir francis varney that the house was surround 
and all escape was cut off; there was no chance of his being able to 
rush through such a multitude of men as that which now encircle him. 

with the calmest despair, sir francis varney lay still and motionless on 
the house-top, and listen to the sound that proceed from below. 
shout after shout arose on the still, calm air of the night; knock after 
knock came upon the stout old door, which awaken responsive echo 
throughout the house that had for many years lain dormant, and which now 
seem disturbed, and resound in hollow murmur to the voice from 
without. 

then a loud voice shout from below, as if to be heard by any one who 
might be within,-- 

"sir francis varney, the vampyre, come out and give yourself up at 
discretion! if we have to search for you, you may depend it will be to 
punish you; you will suffer by burning. come out and give yourself up." 

there was a pause, and then a loud shout. 

sir francis varney paid no attention to this summons, but sat, 
motionless, on the house-top, where he could hear all that pass below 
in the crowd. 

"he will not come out," said one. 

"ah! he's much too cunning to be caught in such a trap. why, he know 
what you would do with him; he know you would stake him, and make a 
bonfire about him." 

"so he has no taste for roasting," remark another; "but still, it's no 
use hiding; we have too many hands, and know the house too well to be 
easily baffled." 

"that may be; and, although he don't like burning, yet we will unearth 
the old fox, somehow or other; we have discover his haunt at last, and 
certainly we'll have him out." 

"how shall we get in?" 

"knock in the door--break open the door! the front door--that is the 
best, because it leads to all parts of the house, and we can secure any 
one who attempt to move from one to the other, as they come down." 

"hurrah!" shout several men in the crowd. 

"hurrah!" echo the mob, with one accord, and the shout rent the air, 
and disturbed the quietude and serene that scarce five minutes before 
reign through the place. 

then, as if actuate by one spirit, they all set to work to force the 
door in. it was strong, and capable of great defence, and employ them, 
with some labour, for fifteen or twenty minutes, and then, with a loud 
crash, the door fell in. 

"hurrah!" again shout the crowd. 

these shout announce the fall of the door, and then, and not until 
then, did sir francis varney stir. 

"they have broken in the door," he muttered, "well, if die i must, i 
will sell my life dearly. however, all is not yet lost, and, in the 
struggle for life, the loss is not so much felt." 

he got up, and crept towards the trap that led into the house, or out of 
it, as the occasion might require. 

"the vampyre! the vampyre!" shout a man who stood on a garden wall, 
holding on by the arm of an apple-tree. 

"varney, the vampyre!" shout a second. 

"hurrah! boys, we are on the right scent; now for a hunt; hurrah! we 
shall have him now." 

they rush in a tumultuous riot up the stone steps, and into the hall. 
it was a large, spacious place, with a grand staircase that led up to 
the upper floor, but it had two ends, and then terminate in a gallery. 

it could not be defend by one man, save at the top, where it could not 
long be held, because the assailant could unite, and throw their whole 
weight against the entrance, and thus storm it. this actually happened. 

they look up, and, seeing nobody, they rush up, some by one stair, 
and some by the other; but it was dark; there were but few of the moon's 
ray that pierce the gloom of that place, and those who first reach 
the place which we have named, were seize with astonishment, staggered, 
and fell. 

sir francis varney had met them; he stood there with a staff--something 
he had found about the house--not quite so long as a broom-handle, but 
somewhat thick and heavier, being made of stout ash. 

this formidable weapon, sir francis varney wield with strength and 
resolution; he was a tall man, and one of no mean activity and personal 
strength, and such a weapon, in his hands, was one of a most fearful 
character, and, for the occasion, much better than his sword. 

man after man fell beneath the fearful brace of these blows, for though 
they could not see sir francis, yet he could see them, or the 
hall-lights were behind them at the time, while he stood in the dark, 
and took advantage of this to deal murderous blow upon his assailants. 

this continue for some minutes, till they gave way before such a 
vigorous defence, and paused. 

"on, neighbours, on," cry one; "will you be beaten off by one man? 
rush in at once and you must force him from his position--push him hard, 
and he must give way." 

"ay," said one fellow who sat upon the ground rubbing his head; "it's 
all very well to say push him hard, but if you felt the weight of that 
d----d pole on your head, you wouldn't be in such a blessed hurry." 

however true that might be, there was but little attention paid to it, 
and a determined rush was made at the entrance to the gallery, and they 
found that it was unoccupied; and that was explain by the slam of 
a door, and its being immediately lock upon them; and when the mob 
came to the door, they found they had to break their way through another 
door. 

this did not take long in effecting; and in less than five minutes they 
had broken through that door which led into another room; but the first 
man who enter it fell from a crashing blow on the head from the ashen 
staff of sir francis varney, who hurried and fled, close pursued, 
until he came to another door, through which he dashed. 

here he endeavour to make a stand and close it, but was immediately 
struck and grapple with; but he threw his assailant, and turn and 
flee again. 

his object had been to defend each inch of the ground as long as he was 
able; but he found they came too close upon his steps, and prevent his 
turning in time to try the strength of his staff upon the foremost. 

he dashed up the first staircase with surprising rapidity, leave his 
pursuer behind; and when he had gain the first landing, he turn 
upon those who pursue him, who could hardly follow him two abreast. 

"down with the vampyre!" shout the first, who rush up heedless of 
the staff. 

"down with a fool!" thunder varney, as he struck the fellow a terrific 
blow, which cover his face with blood, and he fell back into the arms 
of his companions. 

a bitter groan and execrate arose from them below, and again they 
shouted, and rush up headlong. 

"down with the vampyre!" was again shouted, and met by a corresponding, 
but deep guttural sound of-- 

"down with a fool!" 

and sure enough the first again came to the earth without any 
preparation, save the application of an ashen stick to his skull, which, 
by-the-bye, no means aid the operation of thinking. 

several more share a similar fate; but they pressed hard, and sir 
francis was compel to give ground to keep them at the necessary 
length from him, as they rush on regardless of his blows, and if he 
had not he would soon have been engaged in a personal struggle, for they 
were get too close for him to use the staff. 

"down with the vampyre!" was the renew cry, as they drove him from 
spot to spot until he reach the roof of the house, and then he ran up 
the steps to the loft, which he had just reach when they came up to 
the bottom. 

varney attempt to draw the ladder up but four or five stout men held 
that down; then by a sudden turn, as they were get up, he turn it 
over, threw those on it down, and the ladder too, upon the head of 
those who were below. 

"down with the vampyre!" shout the mob, as they, with the most 
untiring energy, set the ladder, or steps, against the loft, and as many 
as could held it, while other rush up to attack varney with all the 
ferocity and courage of so many bull dogs. 

it was strange, but the more they were baffle the more enrage and 
determined they rush on to a new attack, with greater resolution than 
ever. 

on this occasion, however, they were met with a new kind of missile, for 
sir francis had either collected and placed there for the occasion, or 
they had been left there for years, a number of old bricks, which lay 
close at hand. these he took, one by one, and deliberate took aim at 
them, and flung them with great force, striking down every one they hit. 

this cause them to recoil; the brick cause fearful gash in their 
heads, and the wound were serious, the flesh being, in many places, 
torn completely off. they however, only paused, for one man said,-- 

"be of good heart, comrades, we can do as he does; he has furnish us 
with weapons, and we can thus attack him in two ways, and he must give 
way in the end." 

"hurrah! down with the vampyre!" sound from all sides, and the shout 
was answer by a corresponding rush. 

it was true; sir francis had furnish them with weapon to attack 
himself, for they could throw them back at him, which they did, and 
struck him a severe blow on the head, and it cover his face with blood 
in a moment. 

"hurrah!" shout the assailants; "another such a blow, and all will be 
over with the vampyre." 

"he's got--" 

"press him sharp, now," cry another man, as he aim another blow with 
a brick, which struck varney on the arm, cause him to drop the brick 
he held in his hand. he stagger back, apparently in great pain. 

"up! up! we have him now; he cannot get away; he's hurt; we have him--we 
have him." 

and up they went with all the rapid they could scramble up the steps; 
but this had given varney time to recover himself; and though his right 
arm was almost useless, yet he contrived, with his left, to pitch the 
brick so as to knock over the first three or four, when, seeing that he 
could not maintain his position to advantage, he rush to the outside 
of the house, the last place he had capable of defence. 

there was a great shout by those outside, when they saw him come out and 
stand with his staff, and those who came first got first served, for the 
blow resounded, while he struck them, and sent them over below. 

then came a great shout from within and without, and then a desperate 
rush was made at the door, and, in the next instant, varney was seen 
flying, follow by his pursuers, one after the other, some tumble 
over the tiles, to the imminent hazard of their necks. 

sir francis varney rush along with a speed that appear by far too 
great to admit of being safe followed, and yet those who follow 
appear infect by his example, and appear heedless of all 
consequence by which their pursuit might be attend to themselves. 

"hurrah!" shout the mob below. 

"hurrah!" answer the mob on the tiles. 

then, over several housetops might be seen the flying figure of sir 
francis varney, pursue by different men at a pace almost equal to his 
own. 

they, however, could keep up the same speed, and not improve upon it, 
while he kept the advantage he first obtain in the start. 

then sudden he disappeared. 

it seem to the spectator below that he had drop through a house, 
and they immediately surround the house, as well as they could, and 
then set up another shout. 

this took place several times, and as often was the miserable man hunt 
from his place of refuge only to seek another, from which he was in like 
manner hunt by those who thirst for his blood. 

on one occasion, they drove him into a house which was surrounded, save 
at one point, which had a long room, or building in it, that ran some 
distance out, and about twenty feet high. 

at the entrance to the roof of this place, or leads, he stood and 
defend himself for some moments with success; but have received a 
blow himself, he was compel to retire, while the mob behind forced 
those in front forward fast than he could by any exertion wield the 
staff that had so much befriend him on this occasion. 

he was, therefore, on the point of being overwhelm by numbers, when he 
fled; but, alas! there was no escape; a bare coping stone and rails ran 
round the top of that. 

there was not much time for hesitation, but he jump over the rails and 
look below. it was a great height, but if he fell and hurt himself, he 
knew he was at the mercy of the bloodhound behind him, who would do 
anything but show him any mercy, or spare him a single pang. 

he look round and beheld his pursuer close upon him, and one was so 
close to him that he seize upon his arm, saying, as he shout to his 
companions,-- 

"hurrah, boys! i have him." 

with an execration, sir francis wield his staff with such force, that 
he struck the fellow on the head, crush in his hat as if it had been 
only so much paper. the man fell, but a blow follow from some one else 
which cause varney to relax his hold, and finding himself falling, he, 
to save himself, sprang away. 

the rails, at that moment, were crowded with men who lean over to 
ascertain the effect of the leap. 

"he'll be killed," said one. 

"he's sure to be smashed," said another. 

"i'll lay any wager he'll break a limb!" said a third. 

varney came to the earth--for a moment he lay stunned, and not able to 
move hand or foot. 

"hurrah!" shout the mob. 

their triumph was short, for just as they shout varney arose, and 
after a moment or two's stagger he set off at full speed, which produce 
another shout from the mob; and just at that moment, a body of his 
pursuer were seen scale the wall after him. 

there was now a hunt through all the adjoin fields--from cover after 
cover they pursue him until he found no rest from the hungry wolf 
that beset him with cries, resemble beast of prey rather than any 
human multitude. 

sir francis heard them, at the same time, with the despair of a man who 
is struggle for life, and yet know he is struggle in vain; he knew 
his strength was decaying--his immense exertion and the blow he had 
received, all weaken him, while the number and strength of his foe 
seem rather to increase than to diminish. 

once more he sought the houses, and for a moment he believe himself 
safe, but that was only a momentary deception, for they had trace him. 

he arrive at a garden wall, over which he bounded, and then he rush 
into the house, the door of which stood open, for the noise and 
disturbance had awaken most of the inhabitants, who were out in all 
directions. 

he took refuge in a small closet on the stairs, but was seen to do so by 
a girl, who scream out with fear and fright, 

"murder! murder!--the wampyre!--the wampyre!" with all her strength, and 
in the way of scream that was no little, and then she went off into a 
fit. 

this was signal enough, and the house was at once entered, and beset on 
all side by the mob, who came impatient of obtain their victim who 
had so often baffle them. 

"there he is--there he is," said the girl, who came to as soon as other 
people came up. 

"where?--where?" 

"in that closet," she said, point to it with her finger. "i see'd him 
go in the way above." 

sir francis, finding himself betrayed, immediately came out of the 
closet, just as two or three were advance to open it, and dealt so 
hard a blow on the head of the first that came near him that he fell 
without a groan, and a second share the same fate; and then sir francis 
found himself grapple with, but with a violent effort he relieved 
himself and rush up stairs. 

"oh! murder--the wampyre! what shall i do--fire--fire!" 

these exclamation were utter in consequence of varney in his haste to 
get up stairs, have inadvertent step into the girl's lap with one 
foot, while he kick her in the chin with the other, besides scratch 
her nose till it bled. 

"after him--stick to him," shout the mob, but the girl kick and 
sprawl so much they were impeded, till, regardless of her cries, they 
ran over her and pursue varney, who was much distress with the 
exertion he had made. 

after about a minute's race he turn upon the head of the stair, not so 
much with the hope of defend it as of taking some breathing time: but 
seeing his enemy so close, he drew his sword, and stood panting, but 
prepared. 

"never mind his toasting-fork," said one bulky fellow, and, as he spoke, 
he rush on, but the point of the weapon enter his heart and he fell 
dead. 

there was a dreadful execrate utter by those who came up after him, 
and there was a momentary pause, for none like to rush on to the bloody 
sword of sir francis varney, who stood so willing and so capable of 
use it with the most deadly effect. they paused, as well they might, 
and this pause was the most welcome thing next to life to the 
unfortunate fugitive, for he was dreadfully distress and bleeding. 

"on to him boys! he can hardly stand. see how he pants. on to him, i 
say--push him hard." 

"he push hard, i tell you," said another. "i felt the point of his 
sword, as it came through giles's back.". 

"i'll try my luck, then," said another, and he rush up; but he was met 
by the sword of sir francis, who pierce it through his side, and he 
fell back with a groan. 

sir francis, fearful of stopping any long to defend that point, 
appear desirous of making good his retreat with some little advantage, 
and he rush up stairs before they had recover from the momentary 
consternation into which they had been thrown by the sudden disaster 
they had received. 

[illustration] 

but they were quick after him, and before he, weary as he was, could 
gain the roof, they were up the ladder after him. 

the first man who came through the trap was again set upon by varney, 
who made a desperate thrust at him, and it took effect; but the sword 
snap by the handle. 

with an execration, sir francis threw the hilt at the head of the next 
man he saw; then rushing, with headlong speed, he distance his pursuer 
for some house tops. 

but the row of house end at the one he was then at, and he could go 
no further. what was to be done? the height was by far too great to be 
jumped; death was certain. a hideous heap of crush and mangle bone 
would be the extent of what would remain of him, and then, perhaps, life 
not extinct for some hour afterwards. 

he turn round; he saw them coming hallooe over the house tops, like 
a pack of hounds. sir francis struck his hand together, and groaned. he 
look round, and perceive some ivy peep over the coping-stone. a 
thought struck him, and he instantly ran to the spot and lean over. 

"saved--saved!" he exclaimed. 

then, place his hand over, he felt for the ivy; then he got over, and 
hung by the coping-stone, in a perilous position, till he found a spot 
on which he could rest his foot, and then he grasp the ivy as low down 
as he could, and thus he lower himself a short way, till he came to 
where the ivy was strong and more secure to the wall, as the upper 
part was very dangerous with his weight attach to it. 

the mob came on, very sure of have sir francis varney in their power, 
and they did not hurry on so violently, as their position was dangerous 
at that hour of the night. 

"easy, boys, easy," was the cry. "the bird is our own; he can't get 
away, that's very certain." 

they, however, came on, and took no time about it hardly; but what was 
their amaze and rage at finding he had disappeared. 

"where is he?" was the universal inquiry, and "i don't know," an almost 
universal answer. 

there was a long pause, while they search around; but they saw no 
vestige of the object of their search. 

"there's no trap door open," remark one; "and i don't think he could 
have got in at any one." 

"perhaps, finding he could not get away, he has taken the desperate 
expedient of jump over, and commit suicide, and so escape the 
doom he ought to be subject to." 

"probably he has; but then we can run a stake through him and burn him 
all the same." 

they now approach the extreme verge of the houses, and look over the 
sides, but they could see nothing. the moon was up, and there was light 
enough to have seen him if he had fallen to the earth, and they were 
quite sure that he could not have got up after such a fall as he must 
have received. 

"we are beaten after all, neighbours." 

"i am not so sure of that," was the reply. "he may now be hidden about, 
for he was too far spent to be able to go far; he could not do that, i 
am sure." 

"i think not either." 

"might he not have escape by means of that ivy, yonder?" said one of 
the men, point to the plant, as it climb over the coping-stones of 
the wall. 

"yes; it may be possible," said one; "and yet it is very dangerous, if 
not certain destruction to get over." 

"oh, yes; there is no possibility of escape that way. why, it wouldn't 
bear a cat, for there are no nail driven into the wall at this height." 

"never mind," said another, "we may as well leave no stone unturned, as 
the saying is, but at once set about look out for him." 

the individual who spoke now leant over the coping stone, for some 
moments, in silence. he could see nothing, but yet he continue to gaze 
for some moments. 

"do you see him?" inquire one. 

"no," was the answer. 

"ay, ay, i thought as much," was the reply. "he might as well have got 
hold of a corner of the moon, which, i believe, is more likely--a great 
deal more likely." 

"hold still a moment," said the man, who was look over the edge of 
the house. 

"what's the matter now? a gnat flew into your eye?" 

"no; but i see him--by jove, i see him!" 

"see who--see who?" 

"varney, the vampyre!" shout the man. "i see him about half-way down 
clinging, like a fly, to the wall. odd zounds! i never saw the like 
afore!" 

"hurrah! after him then, boys!" 

"not the same way, if you please. go yourself, and welcome; but i won't 
go that way." 

"just as you please," said the man; "but what's good for the goose is 
good for the gander is an old saying, and so is jack as good as his 
master." 

"so it may be; but cuss me if you ain't a fool if you attempt that!" 

the man made no reply, but did as varney had done before, got over the 
coping stone, and then laid hold of the ivy; but, whether his weight was 
heavy than varney's, or whether it was that the latter had loosen 
the hold of the ivy or not, but he had no soon left go of the coping 
stone than the ivy gave way, and he was precipitate from the height of 
about fifty feet to the earth--a dreadful fall! 

there was a pause--no one spoke. the man lay motionless and dead--he had 
dislocate his neck! 

the fall had not, however, been without its effect upon varney, for the 
man's heel struck him so forcibly on his head as he fell, that he was 
stunned, and let go his hold, and he, too, fell to the earth, but not 
many feet. 

he soon recover himself, and was staggering away, when he was assail 
by those above with groans, and curse of all kinds, and then by stones, 
and tiles, and whatever the mob could lay their hand upon. 

some of these struck him, and he was cut about in various places, so 
that he could hardly stand. 

the hoot and shout of the mob above had now attract those below to 
the spot where sir francis varney was try to escape, but he had not 
gone far before the loud yell of those behind him told him that he was 
again pursued. 

half dead, and almost wholly spent, unarmed, and defenceless, he scarce 
knew what to do; whether to fly, or to turn round and die as a refuge 
from the greater evil of endeavour to prolong a struggle which seem 
hopeless. instinct, however, urge him on, at all risks, and though he 
could not go very far, or fast, yet on he went, with the crowd after 
him. 

"down with the vampyre!--seize him--hold him--burn him! he must be down 
presently, he can't stand!" 

this gave them new hopes, and render varney's fate almost certain. 
they renew their exertion to overtake him, while he exert himself 
anew, and with surprising agility, considering how he had been employ 
for more than two hours. 

there were some tree and hedge now that oppose the progress of both 
parties. the height of sir francis varney gave him a great advantage, 
and, had he been fresh, he might have shown it to advantage in vaulting 
over the hedge and ditches, which he jump when obliged, and walk 
through when he could. 

every now and then, the party in pursuit, who had been behind him some 
distance, now they gain on him; however, they kept, every now and 
then, lose sight of him among the tree and shrubs, and he made direct 
for a small wood, hope that when there, he should to be able to 
conceal himself for some time, so as to throw his pursuer off the 
track. 

they were well aware of this, for they increase their speed, and one or 
two swift of foot than the others, got a-head of them and cry out 
aloud as they ran,-- 

"keep up! keep up! he's making for the wood." 

"he can't stop there long; there are too many of us to beat that cover 
without finding our game. push, lads, he's our own now, as sure as we 
know he's on a-head." 

they did push on, and came in full sight as they saw sir francis enter 
the wood, with what speed he could make; but he was almost spent. this 
was a cheering sight to them, and they were pretty certain he would not 
leave the wood in the state he was then--he must seek concealment. 

however, they were mistaken, for sir francis varney, as soon as he got 
into the wood, plunge into the thickest of it, and then pause to gain 
breath. 

"so far safe," he muttered; "but i have had a narrow escape; they are 
not yet done, though, and it will not be safe here long. i must away, 
and seek shelter and safety elsewhere, if i can;--curses on the hound 
that run yelp over the fields!" 

he heard the shout of his pursuers, and prepared to quit the wood when 
he thought the first had enter it. 

"they will remain here some time in beating about," he muttered; "that 
is the only chance i have had since the pursuit; curse them! i say 
again. i may now get free; this delay must save my life, but nothing 
else will." 

he move away, and, at a slow and lazy pace, left the wood, and then 
made his way across some fields, towards some cottages, that lay on the 
left. 

the moon yet shone on the fields; he could hear the shout of the mob, 
as various party went through the wood from one covert to another, and 
yet unable to find him. 

then came a great shout upon his ears, as though they had found out he 
had left the wood. this cause him to redouble his speed, and, fearful 
lest he should be seen in the moonlight, he leap over the first fence 
that he came to, with almost the last effort he could make, and then 
stagger in at an open door--through a passage--into a front parlour, 
and there fell, faint, and utterly spent and speechless, at the feet of 
flora bannerworth. 




chapter lxxxviii. 

the reception of the vampyre by flora.--varney subdued. 


[illustration] 

we must say that the irruption into the house of the bannerworth by sir 
francis varney, was certainly unpremeditated by him, for he knew not 
into whose house he had thus sudden rush for refuge from the 
numerous foe who were pursue him with such vengeful ire. it was a 
strange and singular incident, and one well calculate to cause the mind 
to pause before it pass it by, and consider the means to an end which 
are sometimes as wide of the mark, as it is in nature possible to be. 

but truth is strong than fiction by far, and the end of it was, that, 
pressed on all side by danger, bleeding, faint, and exhausted, he 
rush into the first house he came to, and thus placed himself in the 
very house of those whom he had brought to such a state of misfortune. 

flora bannerworth was seat at some embroidery, to pass away an hour or 
so, and thus get over the tedium of time; she was not thinking, either, 
upon the unhappy past; some trifling object or other engaged her 
attention. but what was her anguish when she saw a man staggering into 
the room bleeding, and bearing the mark of a bloody contest, and 
sink at her feet. 

her astonishment was far greater yet, when she recognise that man to be 
sir francis varney. 

"save me!--save me! miss bannerworth, save me!--only you can save me 
from the ruthless multitude which follows, crying aloud for my blood." 

as he spoke, he sank down speechless. flora was so much amazed, not to 
say terrified, that she knew not what to do. she saw sir francis a 
suppliant at her feet, a fugitive from his enemies, who would show him 
no mercy--she saw all this at a moment's glance; and yet she had not 
recover her speech and presence of mind enough to enable her to make 
any reply to him. 

"save me! miss flora bannerworth, save me!" he again said, raise 
himself on his hands. "i am beset, hunt like a wild beast--they seek 
my life--they have pursue me from one spot to another, and i have 
unwitting intrude upon you. you will save me: i am sure your kindness 
and goodness of heart will never permit me to be turn out among such a 
crew of blood-thirsty butcher as those who pursue me are." 

"rise, sir francis varney," said flora, after a moment's hesitation; "in 
such an extremity as that which you are in, it would be inhuman indeed 
to thrust you out among your enemies." 

"oh! it would," said varney. "i had thought, until now, i could have 
face such a mob, until i was in this extremity; and then, disarm and 
thrown down, bruised, beaten, and incapable of stem such a torrent, 
i flee from one place to another, till hunt from each, and then 
instinct alone urge me to greater exertion than before, and here i 
am--this is now my last and only hope." 

"rise, sir francis." 

"you will not let me be torn out and slaughter like an ox. i am sure 
you will not." 

"sir francis, we are incapable of such conduct; you have sought refuge 
here, and shall find it as far as we are able to afford it to you." 

"and your brother--and--" 

"yes--yes--all who are here will do the same; but here they come to 
speak for themselves." 

as she spoke, mrs. bannerworth entered, also charles holland, who both 
start on seeing the vampyre present, sir francis varney, who was too 
weak to rise without assistance. 

"sir francis varney," said flora, speak to them as they entered, "has 
sought refuge here; his life is in peril, and he has no other hope left; 
you will, i am sure, do what can be done for him." 

"mr. holland," said sir francis, "i am, as you may see by my condition, 
a fugitive, and have been beaten almost to death; instinct alone urge 
me on to save my life, and i, unknowingly, came in here." 

"rise, sir francis," said charles holland; "i am not one who would feel 
any pleasure in seeing you become the victim of any brutal mob. i am 
sure there are none amongst us who would willing do so. you have 
trust to those who will not betray you." 

"thank you," said sir francis, faintly. "i thank you; your conduct is 
noble, and miss bannerworth's especially so." 

"are you much hurt, sir francis?" inquire charles. 

"i am much hurt, but not seriously or dangerously; but i am weak and 
exhausted." 

"let me assist you to rise," said charles holland. 

"thank you," said sir francis, as he accept of the assistance, and 
when he stood up, he found how incapable he really was, for a child 
might have grapple with him. 

"i have been sore beset, mrs. bannerworth," he said, endeavour to bow 
to that lady; "and i have suffer much ill-usage. i am not in such a 
plight as i could wish to be seen in by ladies; but my reason for 
coming will be an excuse for my appearance in such disorder." 

"we will not say anything about that," said charles holland; "under the 
circumstances, it could not be otherwise." 

"it could not," said sir francis, as he took the chair miss flora 
bannerworth placed for him. 

"i will not ask you for any explanation as to how this came about; but 
you need some restorative and rest." 

"i think i suffer more from exhaustion than anything else. the bruise i 
have, of course, are not dangerous." 

"can you step aside a few moments?" said mrs. bannerworth. "i will show 
you where you can remove some of those stains, and make yourself more 
comfortable." 

"thank you, madam--thank you. it will be most welcome to me, i assure 
you." 

sir francis rose up, and, with the aid of charles holland, he walk to 
the next room, where he wash himself, and arrange his dress as well 
as it would admit of its being done. 

"mr. holland," he said, "i cannot tell you how grateful i feel for this. 
i have been hunt from the house where you saw me. from what source 
they learned my abode--my place of concealment--i know not; but they 
found me out." 

"i need hardly say, sir francis, that it could not have occur through 
me," said charles holland. 

"my young friend," said sir francis, "i am quite sure you were not; and, 
moreover, i never, for one moment, suspect you. no, no; some 
accidental circumstance alone has been the cause. i have been very 
cautious--i may say extremely so--but at the same time, living, as i 
have, surround by enemy on all sides, it is not to be wonder at 
that i should be seen by some one, and thus trace to my lair, whither 
they follow me at their leisure." 

"they have been but too troublesome in this matter. when they become a 
little reasonable, it will be a great miracle; for, when their passion 
and fear are excited, there is no end to the extreme they will 
perpetrate." 

"it is so," said varney, "as the history of these last few days ample 
testify to me. i could never have credit the extent to which popular 
excitement could be carried, and the result it was likely to produce." 

"it is an engine of very difficult control," pursue charles holland; 
"but what will raise it will not allay it, but add fuel to the fire that 
burn so fierce already." 

"true enough," said sir francis. 

"if you have done, will you again step this way?" 

sir francis varney follow charles dutch into the sitting-room, and 
sat down with them, and before him was spread a light supper, with some 
good wine. 

"eat, sir francis," said mrs. bannerworth. "such a state as that in 
which you are, must, of necessity, produce great exhaustion, and you 
must require food and drink." 

sir francis bowed as well as he was able, and even then, sore and 
bruise as he was, fugitive as he had been, he could not forget his 
courtesy; but it was not without an effort. his equanimity was, however, 
much disturbed, by finding himself in the midst of the bannerworths. 

"i owe you a relation," he said, "of what occur to drive me from my 
place of concealment." 

"we should like to hear it, if you are not too far fatigue to relate 
it," said charles. 

"i will. i was sitting at the top of that house in which i sought to 
hide myself, when i heard sound come that were of a very suspicious 
nature; but did not believe that it could happen that they had 
discover my lurking-place; far from it; though, of late, i had been 
habitual cautious and suspicious, yet i thought i was safe, till i 
heard the noise of a multitude coming towards me. i could not be 
mistaken in it, for the sound are so peculiar that they are like 
nothing else. i heard them coming. 

"i move not; and when they surround the house as far as was 
practicable, they gave an immense shout, and made the welkin ring with 
the sound." 

"i heard a confuse noise at a distance," remark flora; "but i had no 
idea that anything serious was contemplated. i imagine it was some 
festival among some trade, or portion of the townspeople, who were 
shouting from joy." 

"oh, dear no," said sir francis; "but i am not surprise at the mistake, 
because there are such occurrence occasionally; but whenever the mob 
gain any advantage upon me they shouted, and when i was able to oppose 
them with effect, they groan at me most horribly." 

"the deuce," said charles; "the sound, suppose, serve to express their 
feelings, and to encourage each other." 

"something of the sort, i dare say," said varney: "but at length, after 
defend the house with all the desperation that despair impart to 
me, i was compel to fly from floor to floor, until i had reach the 
roof; there they follow me, and i was compel again to fly. house 
after house they follow me to, until i could go no farther," said 
varney. 

"how did you escape?" 

"fortunately i saw some ivy grow and creep over the coping-stones, 
and by grasping that i got over the side, and so let myself down by 
degrees, as well as i was able." 

"good heavens! what a dreadful situation," exclaim flora; "it is 
really horrible!" 

"i could not do it again, under, i think, any circumstances." 

"not the same?" said mrs. bannerworth. 

"i really doubt if i could," said varney. "the truth is, the excitement 
of the moment was great, and i at that moment thought of nothing but 
get away. 

"the same circumstances, the same fear of death, could hardly be 
produce in me again, and i am unable to account for the phenomenon on 
this occasion." 

"your escape was very narrow indeed," said flora; "it make me shudder 
to think of the danger you have gone through; it is really terrible to 
think of it." 

"you," said sir francis, "are young and susceptible, and generous in 
your disposition, you can feel for me, and do; but how little i could 
have expect it, it is impossible to say; but your sympathy sink into 
my mind and cause such emotion as never can be erase from my soul. 

"but to proceed. you may guess how dreadful was my position, by the fact 
that the first man who attempt to get over tore the ivy away and fell, 
striking me in his fall; he was killed, and i thrown down and stunned. i 
then made for the wood, close pursue and got into it; then i baffle 
them: they search the wood, and i went through it. i then ran across 
the country to these house here; i got over the fence, and in at the 
back door." 

"did they see you come?" inquire charles holland. 

"i cannot say, but i think that they did not; i heard them give a loud 
shout more than once when on this side of the wood." 

"you did? how far from here were you when you heard the shouts?" 
inquire mrs. bannerworth. 

"i was close here; and, as i jump over the fence, i heard them shout 
again; but i think they cannot see so far; the night was moonlight, to 
be sure, but that is all; the shadow of the hedge, and the distance 
together, would make it, if not impossible, at least very improbable." 

"that is very likely," said mrs. bannerworth. 

"in that case," said charles holland, "you are safe here; for none will 
suspect your being conceal here." 

"it is the last place i should myself have thought of," said varney; 
"and i may say the last place i would knowingly have come to; but had i 
before known enough of you, i should have been well assured of your 
generosity, and have freely come to claim your aid and shelter, which 
accident has so strange brought me to be a candidate for, and which you 
have so kindly award me." 

"the night is wearing away," said flora, "and sir francis is doubtless 
fatigue to an excess; sleep, i dare say, will be most welcome to him." 

"it will indeed, miss bannerworth," said varney; "but i can do that 
under any circumstances; do not let me put you to any inconvenience; a 
chair, and at any hour, will serve me for sleep." 

"we cannot do for you what we would wish," said flora, look at her 
mother; "but something better than that, at all events, we can and will 
provide for you." 

"i know not how to thank you," said sir francis varney; "i assure you, 
of late i have not been luxurious lodged, and the less trouble i give 
you the greater i shall esteem the favour." 

the hour was late, and sir francis varney, before another half hour had 
elapsed, was consign to his own reflections, in a small but neat room, 
there to repose his bruise and batter carcass, and court the 
refreshing influence of sleep. 

his reflection were, for nearly an hour, of the most contradictory 
character; some one passion was try to overcome the other; but he 
seem quite subdued. 

"i could not have expect this," he muttered; "flora bannerworth has 
the soul of a heroine. i deserve not such a reception from them; and 
yet, in my hour of utmost need, they have received me like a favoured 
friend; and yet all their misfortune have taken their origin from me; i 
am the cause of all." 

fill with these thoughts, he fell asleep; he slept till morning broke. 
he was not disturbed; it seem as though the influence of sleep was 
sweet far there, in the cottage of the bannerworths, than ever he had 
before received. 

it was late on that morning before sir francis rose, and then only 
through hearing the family about, and, have perform his toilet, so 
far as circumstances permitted, he descended, and enter the 
front-parlour, the room he had been in the night before. 

flora bannerworth was already there; indeed, breakfast was wait the 
appearance of sir francis varney.
